<span id="key_concepts.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="key_concepts.xhtml_key-concepts" class="section">

# Key Concepts

The following key concepts will help new users understand build123d
quickly.

<div id="key_concepts.xhtml_topology" class="section">

<span id="key_concepts.xhtml_id1"></span>

## Topology

Topology, in the context of 3D modeling and computational geometry, is
the branch of mathematics that deals with the properties and
relationships of geometric objects that are preserved under continuous
deformations. In the context of CAD and modeling software like
build123d, topology refers to the hierarchical structure of geometric
elements (vertices, edges, faces, etc.) and their relationships in a 3D
model. This structure defines how the components of a model are
connected, enabling operations like Boolean operations, transformations,
and analysis of complex shapes. Topology provides a formal framework for
understanding and manipulating geometric data in a consistent and
reliable manner.

The following are the topological objects that compose build123d
objects:

<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Vertex"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Vertex"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Vertex</code></span></a>  
A Vertex is a data structure representing a 0D topological element. It
defines a precise point in 3D space, often at the endpoints or
intersections of edges in a 3D model. These vertices are part of the
topological structure used to represent complex shapes in build123d.

<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Edge"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Edge"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Edge</code></span></a>  
An Edge in build123d is a fundamental geometric entity representing a 1D
element in a 3D model. It defines the shape and position of a 1D curve
within the model. Edges play a crucial role in defining the boundaries
of faces and in constructing complex 3D shapes.

<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Wire"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Wire"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Wire</code></span></a>  
A Wire in build123d is a topological construct that represents a
connected sequence of Edges, forming a 1D closed or open loop within a
3D model. Wires define the boundaries of faces and can be used to create
complex shapes, making them essential for modeling in build123d.

<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Face"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Face</code></span></a>  
A Face in build123d represents a 2D surface in a 3D model. It defines
the boundary of a region and can have associated geometric and
topological data. Faces are vital for shaping solids, providing surfaces
where other elements like edges and wires are connected to form complex
structures.

<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shell"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shell"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Shell</code></span></a>  
A Shell in build123d represents a collection of Faces, defining a
closed, connected volume in 3D space. It acts as a container for
organizing and grouping faces into a single shell, essential for
defining complex 3D shapes like solids or assemblies within the
build123d modeling framework.

<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Solid"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Solid"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Solid</code></span></a>  
A Solid in build123d is a 3D geometric entity that represents a bounded
volume with well-defined interior and exterior surfaces. It encapsulates
a closed and watertight shape, making it suitable for modeling solid
objects and enabling various Boolean operations such as union,
intersection, and subtraction.

<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Compound"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Compound"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Compound</code></span></a>  
A Compound in build123d is a container for grouping multiple geometric
shapes. It can hold various types of entities, such as vertices, edges,
wires, faces, shells, or solids, into a single structure. This makes it
a versatile tool for managing and organizing complex assemblies or
collections of shapes within a single container.

<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Shape</code></span></a>  
A Shape in build123d represents a fundamental building block in 3D
modeling. It encompasses various topological elements like vertices,
edges, wires, faces, shells, solids, and compounds. The Shape class is
the base class for all of the above topological classes.

One can use the
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape.show_topology"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape.show_topology"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">show_topology()</code></span></a>
method to display the topology of a shape as shown here for a unit cube:

<div class="highlight-default notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    Solid                      at 0x7f94c55430f0, Center(0.5, 0.5, 0.5)
    └── Shell                  at 0x7f94b95835f0, Center(0.5, 0.5, 0.5)
        ├── Face               at 0x7f94b95836b0, Center(0.0, 0.5, 0.5)
        │   └── Wire           at 0x7f94b9583730, Center(0.0, 0.5, 0.5)
        │       ├── Edge       at 0x7f94b95838b0, Center(0.0, 0.0, 0.5)
        │       │   ├── Vertex at 0x7f94b9583470, Center(0.0, 0.0, 1.0)
        │       │   └── Vertex at 0x7f94b9583bb0, Center(0.0, 0.0, 0.0)
        │       ├── Edge       at 0x7f94b9583a30, Center(0.0, 0.5, 1.0)
        │       │   ├── Vertex at 0x7f94b9583030, Center(0.0, 1.0, 1.0)
        │       │   └── Vertex at 0x7f94b9583e70, Center(0.0, 0.0, 1.0)
        │       ├── Edge       at 0x7f94b9583770, Center(0.0, 1.0, 0.5)
        │       │   ├── Vertex at 0x7f94b9583bb0, Center(0.0, 1.0, 1.0)
        │       │   └── Vertex at 0x7f94b9583e70, Center(0.0, 1.0, 0.0)
        │       └── Edge       at 0x7f94b9583db0, Center(0.0, 0.5, 0.0)
        │           ├── Vertex at 0x7f94b9583e70, Center(0.0, 1.0, 0.0)
        │           └── Vertex at 0x7f94b95862f0, Center(0.0, 0.0, 0.0)
    ...
        └── Face               at 0x7f94b958d3b0, Center(0.5, 0.5, 1.0)
            └── Wire           at 0x7f94b958d670, Center(0.5, 0.5, 1.0)
                ├── Edge       at 0x7f94b958e130, Center(0.0, 0.5, 1.0)
                │   ├── Vertex at 0x7f94b958e330, Center(0.0, 1.0, 1.0)
                │   └── Vertex at 0x7f94b958e770, Center(0.0, 0.0, 1.0)
                ├── Edge       at 0x7f94b958e630, Center(0.5, 1.0, 1.0)
                │   ├── Vertex at 0x7f94b958e8b0, Center(1.0, 1.0, 1.0)
                │   └── Vertex at 0x7f94b958ea70, Center(0.0, 1.0, 1.0)
                ├── Edge       at 0x7f94b958e7b0, Center(1.0, 0.5, 1.0)
                │   ├── Vertex at 0x7f94b958ebb0, Center(1.0, 1.0, 1.0)
                │   └── Vertex at 0x7f94b958ed70, Center(1.0, 0.0, 1.0)
                └── Edge       at 0x7f94b958eab0, Center(0.5, 0.0, 1.0)
                    ├── Vertex at 0x7f94b958eeb0, Center(1.0, 0.0, 1.0)
                    └── Vertex at 0x7f94b9592170, Center(0.0, 0.0, 1.0)

</div>

</div>

Users of build123d will often reference topological objects as part of
the process of creating the object as described below.

</div>

<div id="key_concepts.xhtml_location" class="section">

## Location

A <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Location"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Location"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Location</code></span></a>
represents a combination of translation and rotation applied to a
topological or geometric object. It encapsulates information about the
spatial orientation and position of a shape within its reference
coordinate system. This allows for efficient manipulation of shapes
within complex assemblies or transformations. The location is typically
used to position shapes accurately within a 3D scene, enabling
operations like assembly, and boolean operations. It’s an essential
component in build123d for managing the spatial relationships of
geometric entities, providing a foundation for precise 3D modeling and
engineering applications.

The topological classes (sub-classes of
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Shape</code></span></a>)
and the geometric classes
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Axis"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Axis"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Axis</code></span></a>
and <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Plane"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Plane"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Plane</code></span></a>
all have a <span class="pre">`location`</span> property. The
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Location"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Location"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Location</code></span></a>
class itself has <span class="pre">`position`</span> and
<span class="pre">`orientation`</span> properties that have setters and
getters as shown below:

<div class="highlight-pycon notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    >>> from build123d import *
    >>> # Create an object and extract its location
    >>> b = Box(1, 1, 1)
    >>> box_location = b.location
    >>> box_location
    (p=(0.00, 0.00, 0.00), o=(-0.00, 0.00, -0.00))
    >>> # Set position and orientation independently
    >>> box_location.position = (1, 2, 3)
    >>> box_location.orientation = (30, 40, 50)
    >>> box_location.position
    Vector: (1.0, 2.0, 3.0)
    >>> box_location.orientation
    Vector: (29.999999999999993, 40.00000000000002, 50.000000000000036)

</div>

</div>

Combining the getter and setter enables relative changes as follows:

<div class="highlight-pycon notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    >>> # Relative change
    >>> box_location.position += (3, 2, 1)
    >>> box_location.position
    Vector: (4.0, 4.0, 4.0)

</div>

</div>

There are also four methods that are used to change the location of
objects:

- <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape.locate"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Shape.locate"><span class="pre"><code
  class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">locate()</code></span></a> -
  absolute change of this object

- <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape.located"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Shape.located"><span class="pre"><code
  class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">located()</code></span></a> -
  absolute change of copy of this object

- <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape.move"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Shape.move"><span class="pre"><code
  class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">move()</code></span></a> -
  relative change of this object

- <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape.moved"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Shape.moved"><span class="pre"><code
  class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">moved()</code></span></a> -
  relative change of copy of this object

Locations can be combined with the <span class="pre">`*`</span> operator
and have their direction flipped with the <span class="pre">`-`</span>
operator.

</div>

<div id="key_concepts.xhtml_selectors" class="section">

## Selectors

When using a GUI based CAD system the user will often click on a feature
to select it for some operation. How does a user “click” when CAD is
done entirely in code? Selectors are recipes for how to isolate a
feature from a design using python filter and sorting methods typically
implemented as a set of custom python operations.

<div id="key_concepts.xhtml_quick-reference" class="section">

### Quick Reference

The following tables describes the build123d selectors:

| Selector | Applicability | Description | Example |
|----|----|----|----|
| vertices() | BuildLine, BuildSketch, BuildPart | Vertex extraction | <cite>part.vertices()</cite> |
| edges() | BuildLine, BuildSketch, BuildPart | Edge extraction | <cite>part.edges()</cite> |
| wires() | BuildLine, BuildSketch, BuildPart | Wire extraction | <cite>part.wires()</cite> |
| faces() | BuildSketch, BuildPart | Face extraction | <cite>part.faces()</cite> |
| solids() | BuildPart | Solid extraction | <cite>part.solids()</cite> |

| Operator | Operand | Method | Description | Example |
|----|----|----|----|----|
| \> | SortBy, Axis | sort_by | Sort ShapeList by operand | <cite>part.vertices() \> Axis.Z</cite> |
| \< | SortBy, Axis | sort_by | Reverse sort ShapeList by operand | <cite>part.faces() \< Axis.Z</cite> |
| \>\> | SortBy, Axis | group_by | Group ShapeList by operand and return last value | <cite>part.solids() \>\> Axis.X</cite> |
| \<\< | SortBy, Axis | group_by | Group ShapeList by operand and return first value | <cite>part.faces() \<\< Axis.Y</cite> |
| \| | Axis, Plane, GeomType | filter_by | Filter and sort ShapeList by Axis, Plane, or GeomType | <cite>part.faces() \| Axis.Z</cite> |
| \[\] |  |  | Standard python list indexing and slicing | <cite>part.faces()\[-2:\]</cite> |
|  | Axis | filter_by_position | Filter ShapeList by Axis & mix / max values | <cite>part.faces()..filter_by_position(Axis.Z, 1, 2, inclusive=(False, True))</cite> |

The operand types are: Axis, Plane, SortBy, and GeomType. An Axis is a
base object with an origin and a direction with several predefined
values such as <span class="pre">`Axis.X`</span>,
<span class="pre">`Axis.Y`</span>, and
<span class="pre">`Axis.Z`</span>; however, any Axis could be used as an
operand (e.g. <span class="pre">`Axis((1,2,3),(0.5,0,-0.5))`</span> is
valid) - see <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Axis"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Axis"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Axis</code></span></a>
for a complete description. A Plane is a coordinate system defined by an
origin, x_dir (X direction), y_dir (Y direction), and z_dir (Z
direction). See <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Plane"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Plane"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Plane</code></span></a>
for a complete description. Filtering by a Plane will return faces/edges
parallel to it. SortBy and GeomType are python Enum class described
here:

<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.GeomType"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_enums.GeomType"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">GeomType</code></span></a>  
BEZIER, BSPLINE, CIRCLE, CONE, CYLINDER, ELLIPSE, EXTRUSION, HYPERBOLA,
LINE, OFFSET, OTHER, PARABOLA, PLANE, REVOLUTION, SPHERE, TORUS

<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.SortBy"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_enums.SortBy"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">SortBy</code></span></a>  
LENGTH, RADIUS, AREA, VOLUME, DISTANCE

</div>

<div id="key_concepts.xhtml_shapelist-class" class="section">

### ShapeList Class

The builders include methods to extract Edges, Faces, Solids, Vertices,
or Wires from the objects they are building. All of these methods return
objects of a subclass of <cite>list</cite>, a
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.ShapeList"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.ShapeList"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">ShapeList</code></span></a>
with custom filtering and sorting methods and operations as follows.

</div>

<div id="key_concepts.xhtml_custom-sorting-and-filtering"
class="section">

### Custom Sorting and Filtering

It is important to note that standard list methods such as
<cite>sorted</cite> or <cite>filtered</cite> can be used to easily build
complex selectors beyond what is available with the predefined sorts and
filters. Here is an example of a custom filters:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildSketch() as din:
        ...
        outside_vertices = filter(
            lambda v: (v.Y == 0.0 or v.Y == height)
            and -overall_width / 2 < v.X < overall_width / 2,
            din.vertices(),
        )

</div>

</div>

The <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.ShapeList.filter_by"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.ShapeList.filter_by"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">filter_by()</code></span></a>
method can take lambda expressions as part of a fluent chain of
operations which enables integration of custom filters into a larger
change of selectors as shown in this example:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    obj = Box(1, 1, 1) - Cylinder(0.2, 1)
    faces_with_holes = obj.faces().filter_by(lambda f: f.inner_wires())

</div>

</div>

![](_images/custom_selector.png)

Here the two faces with “inner_wires” (i.e. holes) have been selected
independent of orientation.

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<span id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml_key-concepts-builder-mode"
class="section">

# Key Concepts (builder mode)

There are two primary APIs provided by build123d: builder and algebra.
The builder API may be easier for new users as it provides some
assistance and shortcuts; however, if you know what a Quaternion is you
might prefer the algebra API which allows CAD objects to be created in
the style of mathematical equations. Both API can be mixed in the same
model with the exception that the algebra API can’t be used from within
a builder context. As with music, there is no “best” genre or API, use
the one you prefer or both if you like.

The following key concepts will help new users understand build123d
quickly.

<div id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml_understanding-the-builder-paradigm"
class="section">

## Understanding the Builder Paradigm

The **Builder** paradigm in build123d provides a powerful and intuitive
way to construct complex geometric models. At its core, the Builder
works like adding a column of numbers on a piece of paper: a running
“total” is maintained internally as each new object is added or
modified. This approach simplifies the process of constructing models by
breaking it into smaller, incremental steps.

<div id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml_how-the-builder-works"
class="section">

### How the Builder Works

When using a Builder (such as **BuildLine**, **BuildSketch**, or
**BuildPart**), the following principles apply:

1.  **Running Total**: - The Builder maintains an internal “total,”
    which represents the current state of the object being built. - Each
    operation updates this total by combining the new object with the
    existing one.

2.  **Combination Modes**: - Just as numbers in a column may have a
    <cite>+</cite> or <cite>-</cite> sign to indicate addition or
    subtraction, Builders use **modes** to control how each object is
    combined with the current total. - Common modes include:

    > <div>
    >
    > - **ADD**: Adds the new object to the current total.
    >
    > - **SUBTRACT**: Removes the new object from the current total.
    >
    > - **INTERSECT**: Keeps only the overlapping regions of the new
    >   object and the current total.
    >
    > - **REPLACE**: Entirely replace the running total.
    >
    > - **PRIVATE**: Don’t change the running total at all.
    >
    > </div>

    - The mode can be set dynamically for each operation, allowing for
      flexible and precise modeling.

3.  **Extracting the Result**: - At the end of the building process, the
    final object is accessed through the Builder’s attributes, such as
    <span class="pre">`.line`</span>,
    <span class="pre">`.sketch`</span>, or
    <span class="pre">`.part`</span>, depending on the Builder type. -
    For example:

    > <div>
    >
    > - **BuildLine**: Use <span class="pre">`.line`</span> to retrieve
    >   the final wireframe geometry.
    >
    > - **BuildSketch**: Use <span class="pre">`.sketch`</span> to
    >   extract the completed 2D profile.
    >
    > - **BuildPart**: Use <span class="pre">`.part`</span> to obtain
    >   the 3D solid.
    >
    > </div>

</div>

<div id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml_example-workflow" class="section">

### Example Workflow

Here is an example of using a Builder to create a simple part:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *

    # Using BuildPart to create a 3D model
    with BuildPart() as example_part:
        with BuildSketch() as base_sketch:
            Rectangle(20, 20)
        extrude(amount=10)  # Create a base block
        with BuildSketch(Plane(example_part.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z).last)) as cut_sketch:
            Circle(5)
        extrude(amount=-5, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)  # Subtract a cylinder

    # Access the final part
    result_part = example_part.part

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml_key-concepts" class="section">

### Key Concepts

- **Incremental Construction**: Builders allow you to build objects
  step-by-step, maintaining clarity and modularity.

- **Dynamic Mode Switching**: The **mode** parameter gives you precise
  control over how each operation modifies the current total.

- **Seamless Extraction**: The Builder paradigm simplifies the retrieval
  of the final object, ensuring that you always have access to the most
  up-to-date result.

</div>

<div id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml_analogy-adding-numbers-on-paper"
class="section">

### Analogy: Adding Numbers on Paper

Think of the Builder as a running tally when adding numbers on a piece
of paper:

- Each number represents an operation or object.

- The <span class="pre">`+`</span> or <span class="pre">`-`</span> sign
  corresponds to the **ADD** or **SUBTRACT** mode.

- At the end, the total is the sum of all operations, which you can
  retrieve by referencing the Builder’s output.

By adopting this approach, build123d ensures a natural, intuitive
workflow for constructing 2D and 3D models.

</div>

</div>

<div id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml_builders" class="section">

## Builders

The three builders, <span class="pre">`BuildLine`</span>,
<span class="pre">`BuildSketch`</span>, and
<span class="pre">`BuildPart`</span> are tools to create new objects -
not the objects themselves. Each of the objects and operations
applicable to these builders create objects of the standard CadQuery
Direct API, most commonly <span class="pre">`Compound`</span> objects.
This is opposed to CadQuery’s Fluent API which creates objects of the
<span class="pre">`Workplane`</span> class which frequently needed to be
converted back to base class for further processing.

One can access the objects created by these builders by referencing the
appropriate instance variable. For example:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as my_part:
        ...

    show_object(my_part.part)

</div>

</div>

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildSketch() as my_sketch:
        ...

    show_object(my_sketch.sketch)

</div>

</div>

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildLine() as my_line:
        ...

    show_object(my_line.line)

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml_implicit-builder-instance-variables"
class="section">

## Implicit Builder Instance Variables

One might expect to have to reference a builder’s instance variable when
using objects or operations that impact that builder like this:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as part_builder:
        Box(part_builder, 10,10,10)

</div>

</div>

Instead, build123d determines from the scope of the object or operation
which builder it applies to thus eliminating the need for the user to
provide this information - as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as part_builder:
        Box(10,10,10)
        with BuildSketch() as sketch_builder:
            Circle(2)

</div>

</div>

In this example, <span class="pre">`Box`</span> is in the scope of
<span class="pre">`part_builder`</span> while
<span class="pre">`Circle`</span> is in the scope of
<span class="pre">`sketch_builder`</span>.

</div>

<div id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml_workplanes" class="section">

## Workplanes

As build123d is a 3D CAD package one must be able to position objects
anywhere. As one frequently will work in the same plane for a sequence
of operations, the first parameter(s) of the builders is a (sequence of)
workplane(s) which is (are) used to aid in the location of features. The
default workplane in most cases is the
<span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span> where a tuple of numbers represent
positions on the x and y axes. However workplanes can be generated on
any plane which allows users to put a workplane where they are working
and then work in local 2D coordinate space.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart(Plane.XY) as example:
        ... # a 3D-part
        with BuildSketch(example.faces().sort_by(sort_by=Axis.Z)[0]) as bottom:
            ...
        with BuildSketch(Plane.XZ) as vertical:
            ...
        with BuildSketch(example.faces().sort_by(sort_by=Axis.Z)[-1]) as top:
            ...

</div>

</div>

When <span class="pre">`BuildPart`</span> is invoked it creates the
workplane provided as a parameter (which has a default of the
<span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span>). The
<span class="pre">`bottom`</span> sketch is therefore created on the
<span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span> but with the normal reversed to
point down. Subsequently the user has created the
<span class="pre">`vertical`</span>
(<span class="pre">`Plane.XZ`</span>) sketch. All objects or operations
within the scope of a workplane will automatically be orientated with
respect to this plane so the user only has to work with local
coordinates.

As shown above, workplanes can be created from faces as well. The
<span class="pre">`top`</span> sketch is positioned on top of
<span class="pre">`example`</span> by selecting its faces and finding
the one with the greatest z value.

One is not limited to a single workplane at a time. In the following
example all six faces of the first box are used to define workplanes
which are then used to position rotated boxes.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    import build123d as bd

    with bd.BuildPart() as bp:
        bd.Box(3, 3, 3)
        with bd.BuildSketch(*bp.faces()):
            bd.Rectangle(1, 2, rotation=45)
        bd.extrude(amount=0.1)

</div>

</div>

This is the result:

<img src="_images/boxes_on_faces.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/boxes_on_faces.svg" />

</div>

<div id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml_locations-context" class="section">

<span id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml_location-context-link"></span>

## Locations Context

When positioning objects or operations within a builder Location
Contexts are used. These function in a very similar was to the builders
in that they create a context where one or more locations are active
within a scope. For example:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart():
        with Locations((0,10),(0,-10)):
            Box(1,1,1)
            with GridLocations(x_spacing=5, y_spacing=5, x_count=2, y_count=2):
                Sphere(1)
            Cylinder(1,1)

</div>

</div>

In this example <span class="pre">`Locations`</span> creates two
positions on the current workplane at (0,10) and (0,-10). Since
<span class="pre">`Box`</span> is within the scope of
<span class="pre">`Locations`</span>, two boxes are created at these
locations. The <span class="pre">`GridLocations`</span> context creates
four positions which apply to the <span class="pre">`Sphere`</span>. The
<span class="pre">`Cylinder`</span> is out of the scope of
<span class="pre">`GridLocations`</span> but in the scope of
<span class="pre">`Locations`</span> so two cylinders are created.

Note that these contexts are creating Location objects not just simple
points. The difference isn’t obvious until the
<span class="pre">`PolarLocations`</span> context is used which can also
rotate objects within its scope - much as the hour and minute indicator
on an analogue clock.

Also note that the locations are local to the current location(s) - i.e.
<span class="pre">`Locations`</span> can be nested. It’s easy for a user
to retrieve the global locations:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with Locations(Plane.XY, Plane.XZ):
        locs = GridLocations(1, 1, 2, 2)
        for l in locs:
            print(l)

</div>

</div>

<div class="highlight-default notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    Location(p=(-0.50,-0.50,0.00), o=(0.00,-0.00,0.00))
    Location(p=(-0.50,0.50,0.00), o=(0.00,-0.00,0.00))
    Location(p=(0.50,-0.50,0.00), o=(0.00,-0.00,0.00))
    Location(p=(0.50,0.50,0.00), o=(0.00,-0.00,0.00))
    Location(p=(-0.50,-0.00,-0.50), o=(90.00,-0.00,0.00))
    Location(p=(-0.50,0.00,0.50), o=(90.00,-0.00,0.00))
    Location(p=(0.50,0.00,-0.50), o=(90.00,-0.00,0.00))
    Location(p=(0.50,0.00,0.50), o=(90.00,-0.00,0.00))

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml_operation-inputs" class="section">

## Operation Inputs

When one is operating on an existing object, e.g. adding a fillet to a
part, an iterable of objects is often required (often a ShapeList).

Here is the definition of
<a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.fillet"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_generic.fillet"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">fillet()</code></span></a>
to help illustrate:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    def fillet(
        objects: Union[Union[Edge, Vertex], Iterable[Union[Edge, Vertex]]],
        radius: float,
    ):

</div>

</div>

To use this fillet operation, an edge or vertex or iterable of edges or
vertices must be provided followed by a fillet radius with or without
the keyword as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as pipes:
        Box(10, 10, 10, rotation=(10, 20, 30))
        ...
        fillet(pipes.edges(Select.LAST), radius=0.2)

</div>

</div>

Here the fillet accepts the iterable ShapeList of edges from the last
operation of the <span class="pre">`pipes`</span> builder and a radius
is provided as a keyword argument.

</div>

<div id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml_combination-modes" class="section">

## Combination Modes

Almost all objects or operations have a <span class="pre">`mode`</span>
parameter which is defined by the <span class="pre">`Mode`</span> Enum
class as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    class Mode(Enum):
        ADD = auto()
        SUBTRACT = auto()
        INTERSECT = auto()
        REPLACE = auto()
        PRIVATE = auto()

</div>

</div>

The <span class="pre">`mode`</span> parameter describes how the user
would like the object or operation to interact with the object within
the builder. For example, <span class="pre">`Mode.ADD`</span> will
integrate a new object(s) in with an existing
<span class="pre">`part`</span>. Note that a part doesn’t necessarily
have to be a single object so multiple distinct objects could be added
resulting is multiple objects stored as a
<span class="pre">`Compound`</span> object. As one might expect
<span class="pre">`Mode.SUBTRACT`</span>,
<span class="pre">`Mode.INTERSECT`</span>, and
<span class="pre">`Mode.REPLACE`</span> subtract, intersect, or replace
(from) the builder’s object. <span class="pre">`Mode.PRIVATE`</span>
instructs the builder that this object should not be combined with the
builder’s object in any way.

Most commonly, the default <span class="pre">`mode`</span> is
<span class="pre">`Mode.ADD`</span> but this isn’t always true. For
example, the <span class="pre">`Hole`</span> classes use a default
<span class="pre">`Mode.SUBTRACT`</span> as they remove a volume from
the part under normal circumstances. However, the
<span class="pre">`mode`</span> used in the
<span class="pre">`Hole`</span> classes can be specified as
<span class="pre">`Mode.ADD`</span> or
<span class="pre">`Mode.INTERSECT`</span> to help in inspection or
debugging.

</div>

<div id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml_using-locations-rotating-objects"
class="section">

## Using Locations & Rotating Objects

build123d stores points (to be specific
<span class="pre">`Location`</span> (s)) internally to be used as
positions for the placement of new objects. By default, a single
location will be created at the origin of the given workplane such that:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as pipes:
        Box(10, 10, 10, rotation=(10, 20, 30))

</div>

</div>

will create a single 10x10x10 box centered at (0,0,0) - by default
objects are centered. One can create multiple objects by pushing points
prior to creating objects as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as pipes:
        with Locations((-10, -10, -10), (10, 10, 10)):
            Box(10, 10, 10, rotation=(10, 20, 30))

</div>

</div>

which will create two boxes.

To orient a part, a <span class="pre">`rotation`</span> parameter is
available on <span class="pre">`` BuildSketch` ``</span> and
<span class="pre">`BuildPart`</span> APIs. When working in a sketch, the
rotation is a single angle in degrees so the parameter is a float. When
working on a part, the rotation is a three dimensional
<span class="pre">`Rotation`</span> object of the form
<span class="pre">`Rotation(<about`</span>` `<span class="pre">`x>,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`<about`</span>` `<span class="pre">`y>,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`<about`</span>` `<span class="pre">`z>)`</span>
although a simple three tuple of floats can be used as input. As 3D
rotations are not cumulative, one can combine rotations with the
<cite>\*</cite> operator like this:
<span class="pre">`Rotation(10,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`20,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`30)`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Rotation(0,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`90,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`0)`</span>
to generate any desired rotation.

<div class="admonition hint">

Hint

Experts Only

<span class="pre">`Locations`</span> will accept
<span class="pre">`Location`</span> objects for input which allows one
to specify both the position and orientation. However, the orientation
is often determined by the <span class="pre">`Plane`</span> that an
object was created on. <span class="pre">`Rotation`</span> is a subclass
of <span class="pre">`Location`</span> and therefore will also accept a
position component.

</div>

</div>

<div id="key_concepts_builder.xhtml_builder-s-pending-objects"
class="section">

## Builder’s Pending Objects

When a builder exits, it will push the object created back to its parent
if there was one. Here is an example:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    height, width, thickness, f_rad = 60, 80, 20, 10

    with BuildPart() as pillow_block:
        with BuildSketch() as plan:
            Rectangle(width, height)
            fillet(plan.vertices(), radius=f_rad)
        extrude(amount=thickness)

</div>

</div>

<span class="pre">`BuildSketch`</span> exits after the
<span class="pre">`fillet`</span> operation and when doing so it
transfers the sketch to the <span class="pre">`pillow_block`</span>
instance of <span class="pre">`BuildPart`</span> as the internal
instance variable <span class="pre">`pending_faces`</span>. This allows
the <span class="pre">`extrude`</span> operation to be immediately
invoked as it extrudes these pending faces into
<span class="pre">`Solid`</span> objects. Likewise,
<span class="pre">`loft`</span> would take all of the
<span class="pre">`pending_faces`</span> and attempt to create a single
<span class="pre">`Solid`</span> object from them.

Normally the user will not need to interact directly with pending
objects; however, one can see pending Edges and Faces with
<span class="pre">`<builder_instance>.pending_edges`</span> and
<span class="pre">`<builder_instance>.pending_faces`</span> attributes.
In the above example, by adding a
<span class="pre">`print(pillow_block.pending_faces)`</span> prior to
the <span class="pre">`extrude(amount=thickness)`</span> the pending
<span class="pre">`Face`</span> from the
<span class="pre">`BuildSketch`</span> will be displayed.

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<span id="key_concepts_algebra.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="key_concepts_algebra.xhtml_key-concepts-algebra-mode"
class="section">

# Key Concepts (algebra mode)

Build123d’s algebra mode works on objects of the classes
<span class="pre">`Shape`</span>, <span class="pre">`Part`</span>,
<span class="pre">`Sketch`</span> and <span class="pre">`Curve`</span>
and is based on two concepts:

1.  **Object arithmetic**

2.  **Placement arithmetic**

<div id="key_concepts_algebra.xhtml_object-arithmetic" class="section">

## Object arithmetic

- Creating a box and a cylinder centered at
  <span class="pre">`(0,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`0,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`0)`</span>

  <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

  <div class="highlight">

      b = Box(1, 2, 3)
      c = Cylinder(0.2, 5)

  </div>

  </div>

- Fusing a box and a cylinder

  <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

  <div class="highlight">

      r = Box(1, 2, 3) + Cylinder(0.2, 5)

  </div>

  </div>

- Cutting a cylinder from a box

  <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

  <div class="highlight">

      r = Box(1, 2, 3) - Cylinder(0.2, 5)

  </div>

  </div>

- Intersecting a box and a cylinder

  <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

  <div class="highlight">

      r = Box(1, 2, 3) & Cylinder(0.2, 5)

  </div>

  </div>

**Notes:**

- <cite>b</cite>, <cite>c</cite> and <cite>r</cite> are instances of
  class <span class="pre">`Compound`</span> and can be viewed with every
  viewer that can show <span class="pre">`build123d.Compound`</span>
  objects.

- A discussion around performance can be found in
  <a href="#algebra_performance.xhtml_algebra-performance"
  class="reference internal"><span class="std std-ref">Performance
  considerations in algebra mode</span></a>.

- A mathematically formal definition of the algebra can be found in
  <a href="#algebra_definition.xhtml_algebra-definition"
  class="reference internal"><span class="std std-ref">Algebraic
  definition</span></a>.

</div>

<div id="key_concepts_algebra.xhtml_placement-arithmetic"
class="section">

## Placement arithmetic

A <span class="pre">`Part`</span>, <span class="pre">`Sketch`</span> or
<span class="pre">`Curve`</span> does not have any location or rotation
parameter. The rationale is that an object defines its topology (shape,
sizes and its center), but does not know where in space it will be
located. Instead, it will be relocated with the
<span class="pre">`*`</span> operator onto a plane and to location
relative to the plane (similar <span class="pre">`moved`</span>).

The generic forms of object placement are:

1.  Placement on <span class="pre">`plane`</span> or at
    <span class="pre">`location`</span> relative to XY plane:

    > <div>
    >
    > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
    >
    > <div class="highlight">
    >
    >     plane * alg_compound
    >     location * alg_compound
    >
    > </div>
    >
    > </div>
    >
    > </div>

2\. Placement on the <span class="pre">`plane`</span> and then moved
relative to the <span class="pre">`plane`</span> by
<span class="pre">`location`</span> (the location is relative to the
local coordinate system of the plane).

> <div>
>
> <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
>
> <div class="highlight">
>
>     plane * location * alg_compound
>
> </div>
>
> </div>
>
> </div>

Details can be found in
<a href="#location_arithmetic.xhtml_location-arithmetics"
class="reference internal"><span class="std std-ref">Location arithmetic
for algebra mode</span></a>.

Examples:

- Box on the <span class="pre">`XY`</span> plane, centered at <cite>(0,
  0, 0)</cite> (both forms are equivalent):

  <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

  <div class="highlight">

      Plane.XY * Box(1, 2, 3)

      Box(1, 2, 3)

  </div>

  </div>

  Note: On the <span class="pre">`XY`</span> plane no placement is
  needed (mathematically
  <span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>
  will not change the location of an object).

- Box on the <span class="pre">`XY`</span> plane centered at <cite>(0,
  1, 0)</cite> (all three are equivalent):

  <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

  <div class="highlight">

      Plane.XY * Pos(0, 1, 0) * Box(1, 2, 3)

      Pos(0, 1, 0) * Box(1, 2, 3)

      Pos(Y=1) * Box(1, 2, 3)

  </div>

  </div>

  Note: Again, <span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span> can be omitted.

- Box on plane <span class="pre">`Plane.XZ`</span>:

  <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

  <div class="highlight">

      Plane.XZ * Box(1, 2, 3)

  </div>

  </div>

- Box on plane <span class="pre">`Plane.XZ`</span> with a location
  <span class="pre">`(X=1,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Y=2,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Z=3)`</span>
  relative to the <span class="pre">`XZ`</span> plane, i.e., using the
  x-, y- and z-axis of the <span class="pre">`XZ`</span> plane:

  <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

  <div class="highlight">

      Plane.XZ * Pos(1, 2, 3) * Box(1, 2, 3)

  </div>

  </div>

- Box on plane <span class="pre">`Plane.XZ`</span> moved to
  <span class="pre">`(X=1,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Y=2,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Z=3)`</span>
  relative to this plane and rotated there by the angles <cite>(X=0,
  Y=100, Z=45)</cite> around <span class="pre">`Plane.XZ`</span> axes:

  <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

  <div class="highlight">

      Plane.XZ * Pos(1, 2, 3) * Rot(0, 100, 45) * Box(1, 2, 3)

      Location((1, 2, 3), (0, 100, 45)) * Box(1, 2, 3)

  </div>

  </div>

  Note:
  <span class="pre">`Pos`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Rot`</span>
  is the same as using <span class="pre">`Location`</span> directly

- Box on plane <span class="pre">`Plane.XZ`</span> rotated on this plane
  by the angles
  <span class="pre">`(X=0,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Y=100,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Z=45)`</span>
  (using the x-, y- and z-axis of the <span class="pre">`XZ`</span>
  plane) and then moved to
  <span class="pre">`(X=1,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Y=2,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Z=3)`</span>
  relative to the <span class="pre">`XZ`</span> plane:

  <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

  <div class="highlight">

      Plane.XZ * Rot(0, 100, 45) * Pos(0,1,2) * Box(1, 2, 3)

  </div>

  </div>

</div>

<div id="key_concepts_algebra.xhtml_combing-both-concepts"
class="section">

## Combing both concepts

**Object arithmetic** and **Placement at locations** can be combined:

> <div>
>
> <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
>
> <div class="highlight">
>
>     b = Plane.XZ * Rot(X=30) * Box(1, 2, 3) + Plane.YZ * Pos(X=-1) * Cylinder(0.2, 5)
>
> </div>
>
> </div>
>
> </div>

**Note:** In Python <span class="pre">`*`</span> binds stronger then
<span class="pre">`+`</span>, <span class="pre">`-`</span>,
<span class="pre">`&`</span>, hence brackets are not needed.

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<span id="moving_objects.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="moving_objects.xhtml_moving-objects" class="section">

# Moving Objects

In build123d, there are several methods to move objects. These methods
vary based on the mode of operation and provide flexibility for object
placement and orientation. Below, we outline the three main approaches
to moving objects: builder mode, algebra mode, and direct manipulation
methods.

<div id="moving_objects.xhtml_builder-mode" class="section">

## Builder Mode

In builder mode, object locations are defined before the objects
themselves are created. This approach ensures that objects are
positioned correctly during the construction process. The following
tools are commonly used to specify locations:

1.  <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.Locations"
    class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
    title="build_common.Locations"><span class="pre"><code
    class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Locations</code></span></a>
    Use this to define a specific location for the objects within the
    <cite>with</cite> block.

2.  <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.GridLocations"
    class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
    title="build_common.GridLocations"><span class="pre"><code
    class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">GridLocations</code></span></a>
    Arrange objects in a grid pattern.

3.  <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.PolarLocations"
    class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
    title="build_common.PolarLocations"><span class="pre"><code
    class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">PolarLocations</code></span></a>
    Position objects in a circular pattern.

4.  <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.HexLocations"
    class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
    title="build_common.HexLocations"><span class="pre"><code
    class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">HexLocations</code></span></a>
    Arrange objects in a hexagonal grid.

<div class="admonition note">

Note

The location(s) of an object must be defined prior to its creation when
using builder mode.

</div>

Example:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with Locations((10, 20, 30)):
        Box(5, 5, 5)

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="moving_objects.xhtml_algebra-mode" class="section">

## Algebra Mode

In algebra mode, object movement is expressed using algebraic
operations. The <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Pos"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Pos"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Pos</code></span></a>
function, short for Position, represents a location, which can be
combined with objects or planes to define placement.

1.  <span class="pre">`Pos()`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`shape`</span>:
    Applies a position to a shape.

2.  <span class="pre">`Plane()`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Pos()`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`shape`</span>:
    Combines a plane with a position and applies it to a shape.

Rotation is an important concept in this mode. A
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Rotation"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Rotation"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Rotation</code></span></a>
represents a location with orientation values set, which can be used to
define a new location or modify an existing one.

Example:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    rotated_box = Rotation(45, 0, 0) * box

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="moving_objects.xhtml_direct-manipulation-methods"
class="section">

## Direct Manipulation Methods

The following methods allow for direct manipulation of a shape’s
location and orientation after it has been created. These methods offer
a mix of absolute and relative transformations.

<div id="moving_objects.xhtml_position" class="section">

### Position

- **Absolute Position:** Set the position directly.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    shape.position = (x, y, z)

</div>

</div>

- **Relative Position:** Adjust the position incrementally.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    shape.position += (x, y, z)
    shape.position -= (x, y, z)

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="moving_objects.xhtml_orientation" class="section">

### Orientation

- **Absolute Orientation:** Set the orientation directly.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    shape.orientation = (X, Y, Z)

</div>

</div>

- **Relative Orientation:** Adjust the orientation incrementally.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    shape.orientation += (X, Y, Z)
    shape.orientation -= (X, Y, Z)

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="moving_objects.xhtml_movement-methods" class="section">

### Movement Methods

- **Relative Move:**

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    shape.move(Location)

</div>

</div>

- **Relative Move of Copy:**

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    relocated_shape = shape.moved(Location)

</div>

</div>

- **Absolute Move:**

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    shape.locate(Location)

</div>

</div>

- **Absolute Move of Copy:**

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    relocated_shape = shape.located(Location)

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="moving_objects.xhtml_transformation-a-k-a-translation-and-rotation"
class="section">

### Transformation a.k.a. Translation and Rotation

<div class="admonition note">

Note

These methods don’t work in the same way as the previous methods in that
they don’t just change the object’s internal
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Location"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Location"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Location</code></span></a>
but transform the base object itself which is quite slow and potentially
problematic.

</div>

- **Translation:** Move a shape relative to its current position.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    relocated_shape = shape.translate(x, y, z)

</div>

</div>

- **Rotation:** Rotate a shape around a specified axis by a given angle.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    rotated_shape = shape.rotate(Axis, angle_in_degrees)

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<span id="OpenSCAD.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="OpenSCAD.xhtml_transitioning-from-openscad" class="section">

# Transitioning from OpenSCAD

Welcome to build123d! If you’re familiar with OpenSCAD, you’ll notice
key differences in how models are constructed. This guide is designed to
help you adapt your design approach and understand the fundamental
differences in modeling philosophies. While OpenSCAD relies heavily on
Constructive Solid Geometry (CSG) to combine primitive 3D shapes like
cubes and spheres, build123d encourages a more flexible and efficient
workflow based on building lower-dimensional objects.

<div id="OpenSCAD.xhtml_why-transition-to-build123d" class="section">

## Why Transition to build123d?

Transitioning to build123d allows you to harness a modern and efficient
approach to 3D modeling. By starting with lower-dimensional objects and
leveraging powerful transformation tools, you can create precise,
complex designs with ease. This workflow emphasizes modularity and
maintainability, enabling quick modifications and reducing computational
complexity.

</div>

<div id="OpenSCAD.xhtml_moving-beyond-constructive-solid-geometry-csg"
class="section">

## Moving Beyond Constructive Solid Geometry (CSG)

OpenSCAD’s modeling paradigm heavily relies on Constructive Solid
Geometry (CSG) to build models by combining and subtracting 3D solids.
While build123d supports similar operations, its design philosophy
encourages a fundamentally different, often more efficient approach:
starting with lower-dimensional entities like faces and edges and then
transforming them into solids.

<div id="OpenSCAD.xhtml_why-transition-away-from-csg" class="section">

### Why Transition Away from CSG?

CSG is a powerful method for creating 3D models, but it has limitations
when dealing with complex designs. build123d’s approach offers several
advantages:

- **Simplified Complexity Management**: Working with 2D profiles and
  faces instead of directly manipulating 3D solids simplifies your
  workflow. In large models, the number of operations on solids can grow
  exponentially, making it difficult to manage and debug. Building with
  2D profiles helps keep designs modular and organized.

- **Improved Robustness**: Operations on 2D profiles are inherently less
  computationally intensive and less error-prone than equivalent
  operations on 3D solids. This robustness ensures smoother workflows
  and reduces the likelihood of failing operations in complex models.

- **Enhanced Efficiency**: Constructing models from 2D profiles using
  operations like **extruding**, **lofting**, **sweeping**, or
  **revolving** is computationally faster. These methods also provide
  greater design flexibility, enabling you to create intricate forms
  with ease.

- **Better Precision and Control**: Starting with 2D profiles allows for
  more precise geometric control. Constraints, dimensions, and
  relationships between entities can be established more effectively in
  2D, ensuring a solid foundation for your 3D design.

</div>

</div>

<div id="OpenSCAD.xhtml_using-a-more-traditional-cad-design-workflow"
class="section">

## Using a More Traditional CAD Design Workflow

Most industry-standard CAD packages recommend starting with a sketch (a
2D object) and transforming it into a 3D model—a design philosophy that
is central to build123d.

In build123d, the design process typically begins with defining the
outline of an object. This might involve creating a complex 1D object
using **BuildLine**, which provides tools for constructing intricate
wireframe geometries. The next step involves converting these 1D objects
into 2D sketches using **BuildSketch**, which offers a wide range of 2D
primitives and advanced capabilities, such as:

- **make_face**: Converts a 1D **BuildLine** object into a planar 2D
  face.

- **make_hull**: Generates a convex hull from a 1D **BuildLine** object.

Once a 2D profile is created, it can be transformed into 3D objects in a
**BuildPart** context using operations such as:

- **Extrusion**: Extends a 2D profile along a straight path to create a
  3D shape.

- **Revolution**: Rotates a 2D profile around an axis to form a
  symmetrical 3D object.

- **Lofting**: Connects multiple 2D profiles along a path to create
  smooth transitions between shapes.

- **Sweeping**: Moves a 2D profile along a defined path to create a 3D
  form.

<div id="OpenSCAD.xhtml_refining-the-model" class="section">

### Refining the Model

After creating the initial 3D shape, you can refine the model by adding
details or making modifications using build123d’s advanced features,
such as:

- **Fillets and Chamfers**: Smooth or bevel edges to enhance the design.

- **Boolean Operations**: Combine, subtract, or intersect 3D shapes to
  achieve the desired geometry.

</div>

<div id="OpenSCAD.xhtml_example-comparison" class="section">

### Example Comparison

To illustrate the advantages of this approach, compare a simple model in
OpenSCAD and build123d of a piece of angle iron:

**OpenSCAD Approach**

<div class="highlight-openscad notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    $fn = 100; // Increase the resolution for smooth fillets

    // Dimensions
    length = 100;  // 10 cm long
    width = 30;    // 3 cm wide
    thickness = 4; // 4 mm thick
    fillet = 5;    // 5 mm fillet radius
    delta = 0.001; // a small number

    // Create the angle iron
    difference() {
        // Outer shape
        cube([width, length, width], center = false);
        // Inner shape
        union() {
            translate([thickness+fillet,-delta,thickness+fillet])
                rotate([-90,0,0])
                    cylinder(length+2*delta, fillet,fillet);
            translate([thickness,-delta,thickness+fillet])
                cube([width-thickness,length+2*delta,width-fillet],center=false);
            translate([thickness+fillet,-delta,thickness])
                cube([width-fillet,length+2*delta,width-thickness],center=false);

        }
    }

</div>

</div>

**build123d Approach**

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    # Builder mode
    with BuildPart() as angle_iron:
        with BuildSketch() as profile:
            Rectangle(3 * CM, 4 * MM, align=Align.MIN)
            Rectangle(4 * MM, 3 * CM, align=Align.MIN)
        extrude(amount=10 * CM)
        fillet(angle_iron.edges().filter_by(lambda e: e.is_interior), 5 * MM)

</div>

</div>

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    # Algebra mode
    profile = Rectangle(3 * CM, 4 * MM, align=Align.MIN)
    profile += Rectangle(4 * MM, 3 * CM, align=Align.MIN)
    angle_iron = extrude(profile, 10 * CM)
    angle_iron = fillet(angle_iron.edges().filter_by(lambda e: e.is_interior), 5 * MM)

</div>

</div>

![](_images/AngleIron.png)

OpenSCAD and build123d offer distinct paradigms for creating 3D models,
as demonstrated by the angle iron example. OpenSCAD relies on
Constructive Solid Geometry (CSG) operations, combining and subtracting
3D shapes like cubes and cylinders. Fillets are approximated by manually
adding high-resolution cylinders, making adjustments cumbersome and less
precise. This static approach can handle simple models but becomes
challenging for complex or iterative designs.

In contrast, build123d emphasizes a profile-driven workflow. It starts
with a 2D sketch, defining the geometry’s outline, which is then
extruded or otherwise transformed into a 3D model. Features like fillets
are applied dynamically by querying topological elements, such as edges,
using intuitive filtering methods. This approach ensures precision and
flexibility, making changes straightforward without the need for manual
repositioning or realignment.

The build123d methodology is computationally efficient, leveraging
mathematical precision for features like fillets. By separating the
design into manageable steps—sketching, extruding, and refining—it
aligns with traditional CAD practices and enhances readability,
modularity, and maintainability. Unlike OpenSCAD, build123d’s dynamic
querying of topological features allows for easy updates and
adjustments, making it better suited for modern, complex, and iterative
design workflows.

In summary, build123d’s sketch-based paradigm and topological querying
capabilities provide superior precision, flexibility, and efficiency
compared to OpenSCAD’s static, CSG-centric approach, making it a better
choice for robust and adaptable CAD modeling.

</div>

</div>

<div id="OpenSCAD.xhtml_tips-for-transitioning" class="section">

## Tips for Transitioning

- **Think in Lower Dimensions**: Begin with 1D curves or 2D sketches as
  the foundation and progressively build upwards into 3D shapes.

- **Leverage Topological References**: Use build123d’s powerful selector
  system to reference features of existing objects for creating new
  ones. For example, apply inside or outside fillets and chamfers to
  vertices and edges of an existing part with precision.

- **Operational Equivalency and Beyond**: Build123d provides equivalents
  to almost all features available in OpenSCAD, with the exception of
  the 3D **minkowski** operation. However, a 2D equivalent,
  **make_hull**, is available in build123d. Beyond operational
  equivalency, build123d offers a wealth of additional functionality,
  including advanced features like topological queries, dynamic
  filtering, and robust tools for creating complex geometries. By
  exploring build123d’s extensive operations, you can unlock new
  possibilities and take your designs far beyond the capabilities of
  OpenSCAD.

- **Explore the Documentation**: Dive into build123d’s comprehensive API
  documentation to unlock its full potential and discover advanced
  features.

By shifting your design mindset from solid-based CSG to a profile-driven
approach, you can fully harness build123d’s capabilities to create
precise, efficient, and complex models. Welcome aboard, and happy
designing!

</div>

<div id="OpenSCAD.xhtml_conclusion" class="section">

## Conclusion

While OpenSCAD and build123d share the goal of empowering users to
create parametric 3D models, their approaches differ significantly.
Embracing build123d’s workflow of building with lower-dimensional
objects and applying extrusion, lofting, sweeping, or revolution will
unlock its full potential and lead to better design outcomes.

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

  >         extrude(amount=2 * thickness)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > This time we can first create a 2D
  > <a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_sketch.Circle"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="objects_sketch.Circle"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Circle</code></span></a>
  > with a subtracted <span class="pre">`` Rectangle` ``</span> and then
  > use the <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_part.extrude"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="operations_part.extrude"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">extrude()</code></span></a>
  > operation for parts.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     sk3 = Circle(width) - Rectangle(length / 2, width / 2)
  >     ex3 = extrude(sk3, amount=2 * thickness)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_building-profiles-using-lines-and-arcs"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-4"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id5" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">4. Building Profiles using lines and arcs</a>

Sometimes you need to build complex profiles using lines and arcs. This
example builds a prismatic solid from 2D operations. It is not necessary
to create variables for the line segments, but it will be useful in a
later example.

<img src="_images/general_ex4.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex4.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <a href="#build_sketch.xhtml_build_sketch.BuildSketch"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_sketch.BuildSketch"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">BuildSketch</code></span></a>
  > operates on closed Faces, and the operation
  > <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_sketch.make_face"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="operations_sketch.make_face"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">make_face()</code></span></a>
  > is used to convert the pending line segments from
  > <a href="#build_line.xhtml_build_line.BuildLine"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_line.BuildLine"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">BuildLine</code></span></a>
  > into a closed Face.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex4:
  >         with BuildSketch() as ex4_sk:
  >             with BuildLine() as ex4_ln:
  >                 l1 = Line((0, 0), (length, 0))
  >                 l2 = Line((length, 0), (length, width))
  >                 l3 = ThreePointArc((length, width), (width, width * 1.5), (0.0, width))
  >                 l4 = Line((0.0, width), (0, 0))
  >             make_face()
  >         extrude(amount=thickness)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > We start with an empty
  > <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Curve"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="topology.Curve"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Curve</code></span></a>
  > and add lines to it (note that
  > <span class="pre">`Curve()`</span>` `<span class="pre">`+`</span>` `<span class="pre">`[line1,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`line2,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`line3]`</span>
  > is much more efficient than
  > <span class="pre">`line1`</span>` `<span class="pre">`+`</span>` `<span class="pre">`line2`</span>` `<span class="pre">`+`</span>` `<span class="pre">`line3`</span>,
  > see <a href="#algebra_performance.xhtml_algebra-performance"
  > class="reference internal"><span class="std std-ref">Performance
  > considerations in algebra mode</span></a>). The operation
  > <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_sketch.make_face"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="operations_sketch.make_face"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">make_face()</code></span></a>
  > is used to convert the line segments into a Face.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     lines = Curve() + [
  >         Line((0, 0), (length, 0)),
  >         Line((length, 0), (length, width)),
  >         ThreePointArc((length, width), (width, width * 1.5), (0.0, width)),
  >         Line((0.0, width), (0, 0)),
  >     ]
  >     sk4 = make_face(lines)
  >     ex4 = extrude(sk4, thickness)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

Note that to build a closed face it requires line segments that form a
closed shape.

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_moving-the-current-working-point"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-5"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id6" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">5. Moving the current working point</a>

<img src="_images/general_ex5.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex5.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > Using <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.Locations"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_common.Locations"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Locations</code></span></a>
  > we can place one (or multiple) objects at one (or multiple) places.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b, c, d = 90, 45, 15, 7.5
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex5:
  >         with BuildSketch() as ex5_sk:
  >             Circle(a)
  >             with Locations((b, 0.0)):
  >                 Rectangle(c, c, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
  >             with Locations((0, b)):
  >                 Circle(d, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
  >         extrude(amount=c)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > Using the pattern
  > <span class="pre">`Pos(x,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`y,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`z=0)`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`obj`</span>
  > (with <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Pos"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="geometry.Pos"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">geometry.Pos</code></span></a>)
  > we can move an object to the provided position. Using
  > <span class="pre">`Rot(x_angle,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`y_angle,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`z_angle)`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`obj`</span>
  > (with <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Rot"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="geometry.Rot"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">geometry.Rot</code></span></a>)
  > would rotate the object.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b, c, d = 90, 45, 15, 7.5
  >
  >     sk5 = Circle(a) - Pos(b, 0.0) * Rectangle(c, c) - Pos(0.0, b) * Circle(d)
  >     ex5 = extrude(sk5, c)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_using-point-lists" class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-6"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id7" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">6. Using Point Lists</a>

Sometimes you need to create a number of features at various
<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.Locations"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_common.Locations"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Locations</code></span></a>.

<img src="_images/general_ex6.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex6.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > You can use a list of points to construct multiple objects at once.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b, c = 80, 60, 10
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex6:
  >         with BuildSketch() as ex6_sk:
  >             Circle(a)
  >             with Locations((b, 0), (0, b), (-b, 0), (0, -b)):
  >                 Circle(c, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
  >         extrude(amount=c)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > You can use loops to iterate over these Locations or list
  > comprehensions as in the example.
  >
  > The algebra operations are vectorized, which means
  > <span class="pre">`obj`</span>` `<span class="pre">`-`</span>` `<span class="pre">`[obj1,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`obj2,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`obj3]`</span>
  > is short for
  > <span class="pre">`obj`</span>` `<span class="pre">`-`</span>` `<span class="pre">`obj1`</span>` `<span class="pre">`-`</span>` `<span class="pre">`obj2`</span>` `<span class="pre">`-`</span>` `<span class="pre">`ob3`</span>
  > (and more efficient, see
  > <a href="#algebra_performance.xhtml_algebra-performance"
  > class="reference internal"><span class="std std-ref">Performance
  > considerations in algebra mode</span></a>).
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b, c = 80, 60, 10
  >
  >     sk6 = [loc * Circle(c) for loc in Locations((b, 0), (0, b), (-b, 0), (0, -b))]
  >     ex6 = extrude(Circle(a) - sk6, c)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_polygons" class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-7"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id8" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">7. Polygons</a>

<img src="_images/general_ex7.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex7.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > You can create
  > <a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_sketch.RegularPolygon"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="objects_sketch.RegularPolygon"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">RegularPolygon</code></span></a>
  > for each stack point if you would like.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b, c = 60, 80, 5
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex7:
  >         with BuildSketch() as ex7_sk:
  >             Rectangle(a, b)
  >             with Locations((0, 3 * c), (0, -3 * c)):
  >                 RegularPolygon(radius=2 * c, side_count=6, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
  >         extrude(amount=c)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > You can apply locations to
  > <a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_sketch.RegularPolygon"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="objects_sketch.RegularPolygon"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">RegularPolygon</code></span></a>
  > instances for each location via loops or list comprehensions.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b, c = 60, 80, 5
  >
  >     polygons = [
  >         loc * RegularPolygon(radius=2 * c, side_count=6)
  >         for loc in Locations((0, 3 * c), (0, -3 * c))
  >     ]
  >     sk7 = Rectangle(a, b) - polygons
  >     ex7 = extrude(sk7, amount=c)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_polylines" class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-8"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id9" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">8. Polylines</a>

<a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_curve.Polyline"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="objects_curve.Polyline"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Polyline</code></span></a>
allows creating a shape from a large number of chained points connected
by lines. This example uses a polyline to create one half of an i-beam
shape, which is <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.mirror"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_generic.mirror"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">mirror()</code></span></a>
ed to create the final profile.

<img src="_images/general_ex8.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex8.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     (L, H, W, t) = (100.0, 20.0, 20.0, 1.0)
  >     pts = [
  >         (0, H / 2.0),
  >         (W / 2.0, H / 2.0),
  >         (W / 2.0, (H / 2.0 - t)),
  >         (t / 2.0, (H / 2.0 - t)),
  >         (t / 2.0, (t - H / 2.0)),
  >         (W / 2.0, (t - H / 2.0)),
  >         (W / 2.0, H / -2.0),
  >         (0, H / -2.0),
  >     ]
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex8:
  >         with BuildSketch(Plane.YZ) as ex8_sk:
  >             with BuildLine() as ex8_ln:
  >                 Polyline(pts)
  >                 mirror(ex8_ln.line, about=Plane.YZ)
  >             make_face()
  >         extrude(amount=L)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     (L, H, W, t) = (100.0, 20.0, 20.0, 1.0)
  >     pts = [
  >         (0, H / 2.0),
  >         (W / 2.0, H / 2.0),
  >         (W / 2.0, (H / 2.0 - t)),
  >         (t / 2.0, (H / 2.0 - t)),
  >         (t / 2.0, (t - H / 2.0)),
  >         (W / 2.0, (t - H / 2.0)),
  >         (W / 2.0, H / -2.0),
  >         (0, H / -2.0),
  >     ]
  >
  >     ln = Polyline(pts)
  >     ln += mirror(ln, Plane.YZ)
  >
  >     sk8 = make_face(Plane.YZ * ln)
  >     ex8 = extrude(sk8, -L).clean()
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_selectors-fillets-and-chamfers"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-9"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id10" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">9. Selectors, Fillets, and Chamfers</a>

This example introduces multiple useful and important concepts. Firstly
<a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.chamfer"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_generic.chamfer"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">chamfer()</code></span></a>
and <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.fillet"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_generic.fillet"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">fillet()</code></span></a>
can be used to “bevel” and “round” edges respectively. Secondly, these
two methods require an edge or a list of edges to operate on. To select
all edges, you could simply pass in
<span class="pre">`ex9.edges()`</span>.

<img src="_images/general_ex9.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex9.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex9:
  >         Box(length, width, thickness)
  >         chamfer(ex9.edges().group_by(Axis.Z)[-1], length=4)
  >         fillet(ex9.edges().filter_by(Axis.Z), radius=5)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     ex9 = Part() + Box(length, width, thickness)
  >     ex9 = chamfer(ex9.edges().group_by(Axis.Z)[-1], length=4)
