  >     ex9 = fillet(ex9.edges().filter_by(Axis.Z), radius=5)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

Note that
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.ShapeList.group_by"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.ShapeList.group_by"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">group_by()</code></span></a>
<span class="pre">`(Axis.Z)`</span> returns a list of lists of edges
that is grouped by their z-position. In this case we want to use the
<span class="pre">`[-1]`</span> group which, by convention, will be the
highest z-dimension group.

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_select-last-and-hole"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-10"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id11" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">10. Select Last and Hole</a>

<img src="_images/general_ex10.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex10.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > Using <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Select"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_enums.Select"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Select</code></span></a>
  > <span class="pre">`.LAST`</span> you can select the most recently
  > modified edges. It is used to perform a
  > <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.fillet"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="operations_generic.fillet"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">fillet()</code></span></a>
  > in this example. This example also makes use of
  > <a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_part.Hole"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="objects_part.Hole"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Hole</code></span></a>
  > which automatically cuts through the entire part.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex10:
  >         Box(length, width, thickness)
  >         Hole(radius=width / 4)
  >         fillet(ex10.edges(Select.LAST).group_by(Axis.Z)[-1], radius=2)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > Using the pattern
  > <span class="pre">`snapshot`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`obj.edges()`</span>
  > before and
  > <span class="pre">`last_edges`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`obj.edges()`</span>` `<span class="pre">`-`</span>` `<span class="pre">`snapshot`</span>
  > after an operation allows to select the most recently modified edges
  > (same for <span class="pre">`faces`</span>,
  > <span class="pre">`vertices`</span>, …). It is used to perform a
  > <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.fillet"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="operations_generic.fillet"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">fillet()</code></span></a>
  > in this example. This example also makes use of
  > <a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_part.Hole"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="objects_part.Hole"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Hole</code></span></a>.
  > Different to the *context mode*, you have to add the
  > <span class="pre">`depth`</span> of the whole.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     ex10 = Part() + Box(length, width, thickness)
  >
  >     snapshot = ex10.edges()
  >     ex10 -= Hole(radius=width / 4, depth=thickness)
  >     last_edges = ex10.edges() - snapshot
  >     ex10 = fillet(last_edges.group_by(Axis.Z)[-1], 2)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_use-a-face-as-a-plane-for-buildsketch-and-introduce-gridlocations"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-11"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id12" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">11. Use a face as a plane for BuildSketch and
introduce GridLocations</a>

<img src="_images/general_ex11.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex11.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <a href="#build_sketch.xhtml_build_sketch.BuildSketch"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_sketch.BuildSketch"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">BuildSketch</code></span></a>
  > accepts a Plane or a Face, so in this case we locate the Sketch on
  > the top of the part. Note that the face used as input to BuildSketch
  > needs to be Planar or unpredictable behavior can result.
  > Additionally
  > <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.GridLocations"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_common.GridLocations"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">GridLocations</code></span></a>
  > can be used to create a grid of points that are simultaneously used
  > to place 4 pentagons.
  >
  > Lastly, <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_part.extrude"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="operations_part.extrude"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">extrude()</code></span></a>
  > can be used with a negative amount and
  > <span class="pre">`Mode.SUBTRACT`</span> to cut these from the
  > parent.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex11:
  >         Box(length, width, thickness)
  >         chamfer(ex11.edges().group_by(Axis.Z)[-1], length=4)
  >         fillet(ex11.edges().filter_by(Axis.Z), radius=5)
  >         Hole(radius=width / 4)
  >         fillet(ex11.edges(Select.LAST).sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1], radius=2)
  >         with BuildSketch(ex11.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]) as ex11_sk:
  >             with GridLocations(length / 2, width / 2, 2, 2):
  >                 RegularPolygon(radius=5, side_count=5)
  >         extrude(amount=-thickness, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > The pattern
  > <span class="pre">`plane`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`obj`</span>
  > can be used to locate an object on a plane. Furthermore, the pattern
  > <span class="pre">`plane`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`location`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`obj`</span>
  > first places the object on a plane and then moves it relative to
  > plane according to <span class="pre">`location`</span>.
  >
  > <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.GridLocations"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_common.GridLocations"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">GridLocations</code></span></a>
  > creates a grid of points that can be used in loops or list
  > comprehensions as described earlier.
  >
  > Lastly, <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_part.extrude"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="operations_part.extrude"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">extrude()</code></span></a>
  > can be used with a negative amount and cut
  > (<span class="pre">`-`</span>) from the parent.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     ex11 = Part() + Box(length, width, thickness)
  >     ex11 = chamfer(ex11.edges().group_by()[-1], 4)
  >     ex11 = fillet(ex11.edges().filter_by(Axis.Z), 5)
  >     last = ex11.edges()
  >     ex11 -= Hole(radius=width / 4, depth=thickness)
  >     ex11 = fillet((ex11.edges() - last).sort_by().last, 2)
  >
  >     plane = Plane(ex11.faces().sort_by().last)
  >     polygons = Sketch() + [
  >         plane * loc * RegularPolygon(radius=5, side_count=5)
  >         for loc in GridLocations(length / 2, width / 2, 2, 2)
  >     ]
  >     ex11 -= extrude(polygons, -thickness)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

Note that the direction implied by positive or negative inputs to amount
is relative to the normal direction of the face or plane. As a result of
this, unexpected behavior can occur if the extrude direction and
mode/operation (ADD / <span class="pre">`+`</span> or SUBTRACT /
<span class="pre">`-`</span>) are not correctly set.

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_defining-an-edge-with-a-spline"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-12"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id13" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">12. Defining an Edge with a Spline</a>

This example defines a side using a spline curve through a collection of
points. Useful when you have an edge that needs a complex profile.

<img src="_images/general_ex12.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex12.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     pts = [
  >         (55, 30),
  >         (50, 35),
  >         (40, 30),
  >         (30, 20),
  >         (20, 25),
  >         (10, 20),
  >         (0, 20),
  >     ]
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex12:
  >         with BuildSketch() as ex12_sk:
  >             with BuildLine() as ex12_ln:
  >                 l1 = Spline(pts)
  >                 l2 = Line((55, 30), (60, 0))
  >                 l3 = Line((60, 0), (0, 0))
  >                 l4 = Line((0, 0), (0, 20))
  >             make_face()
  >         extrude(amount=10)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     pts = [
  >         (55, 30),
  >         (50, 35),
  >         (40, 30),
  >         (30, 20),
  >         (20, 25),
  >         (10, 20),
  >         (0, 20),
  >     ]
  >
  >     l1 = Spline(pts)
  >     l2 = Line(l1 @ 0, (60, 0))
  >     l3 = Line(l2 @ 1, (0, 0))
  >     l4 = Line(l3 @ 1, l1 @ 1)
  >
  >     sk12 = make_face([l1, l2, l3, l4])
  >     ex12 = extrude(sk12, 10)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_counterboreholes-countersinkholes-and-polarlocations"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-13"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id14" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">13. CounterBoreHoles, CounterSinkHoles, and
PolarLocations</a>

Counter-sink and counter-bore holes are useful for creating recessed
areas for fasteners.

<img src="_images/general_ex13.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex13.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > We use a face to establish a location for
  > <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.Locations"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_common.Locations"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Locations</code></span></a>.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b = 40, 4
  >     with BuildPart() as ex13:
  >         Cylinder(radius=50, height=10)
  >         with Locations(ex13.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]):
  >             with PolarLocations(radius=a, count=4):
  >                 CounterSinkHole(radius=b, counter_sink_radius=2 * b)
  >             with PolarLocations(radius=a, count=4, start_angle=45, angular_range=360):
  >                 CounterBoreHole(radius=b, counter_bore_radius=2 * b, counter_bore_depth=b)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > We use a face to establish a plane that is used later in the code
  > for locating objects onto this plane.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b = 40, 4
  >
  >     ex13 = Cylinder(radius=50, height=10)
  >     plane = Plane(ex13.faces().sort_by().last)
  >
  >     ex13 -= (
  >         plane
  >         * PolarLocations(radius=a, count=4)
  >         * CounterSinkHole(radius=b, counter_sink_radius=2 * b, depth=10)
  >     )
  >     ex13 -= (
  >         plane
  >         * PolarLocations(radius=a, count=4, start_angle=45, angular_range=360)
  >         * CounterBoreHole(
  >             radius=b, counter_bore_radius=2 * b, depth=10, counter_bore_depth=b
  >         )
  >     )
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.PolarLocations"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_common.PolarLocations"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">PolarLocations</code></span></a>
creates a list of points that are radially distributed.

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_position-on-a-line-with-and-introduce-sweep"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-14"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id15" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">14. Position on a line with ‘@’, ‘%’ and introduce
Sweep</a>

build123d includes a feature for finding the position along a line
segment. This is normalized between 0 and 1 and can be accessed using
the <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Mixin1D.position_at"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Mixin1D.position_at"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">position_at()</code></span></a>
(<cite>@</cite>) operator. Similarly the
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Mixin1D.tangent_at"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Mixin1D.tangent_at"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">tangent_at()</code></span></a>
(<cite>%</cite>) operator returns the line direction at a given point.

These two features are very powerful for chaining line segments together
without having to repeat dimensions again and again, which is error
prone, time consuming, and more difficult to maintain. The pending faces
must lie on the path, please see example 37 for a way to make this
placement easier.

<img src="_images/general_ex14.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex14.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > The <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.sweep"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="operations_generic.sweep"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">sweep()</code></span></a>
  > method takes any pending faces and sweeps them through the provided
  > path (in this case the path is taken from the pending edges from
  > <span class="pre">`ex14_ln`</span>).
  > <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_part.revolve"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="operations_part.revolve"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">revolve()</code></span></a>
  > requires a single connected wire.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b = 40, 20
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex14:
  >         with BuildLine() as ex14_ln:
  >             l1 = JernArc(start=(0, 0), tangent=(0, 1), radius=a, arc_size=180)
  >             l2 = JernArc(start=l1 @ 1, tangent=l1 % 1, radius=a, arc_size=-90)
  >             l3 = Line(l2 @ 1, l2 @ 1 + (-a, a))
  >         with BuildSketch(Plane.XZ) as ex14_sk:
  >             Rectangle(b, b)
  >         sweep()
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > The <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.sweep"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="operations_generic.sweep"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">sweep()</code></span></a>
  > method takes any faces and sweeps them through the provided path (in
  > this case the path is taken from
  > <span class="pre">`ex14_ln`</span>).
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b = 40, 20
  >
  >     l1 = JernArc(start=(0, 0), tangent=(0, 1), radius=a, arc_size=180)
  >     l2 = JernArc(start=l1 @ 1, tangent=l1 % 1, radius=a, arc_size=-90)
  >     l3 = Line(l2 @ 1, l2 @ 1 + (-a, a))
  >     ex14_ln = l1 + l2 + l3
  >
  >     sk14 = Plane.XZ * Rectangle(b, b)
  >     ex14 = sweep(sk14, path=ex14_ln)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

It is also possible to use tuple or
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Vector"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Vector"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Vector</code></span></a>
addition (and other vector math operations) as seen in the
<span class="pre">`l3`</span> variable.

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_mirroring-symmetric-geometry"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-15"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id16" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">15. Mirroring Symmetric Geometry</a>

Here mirror is used on the BuildLine to create a symmetric shape with
fewer line segment commands. Additionally the ‘@’ operator is used to
simplify the line segment commands.

<span class="pre">`(l4`</span>` `<span class="pre">`@`</span>` `<span class="pre">`1).Y`</span>
is used to extract the y-component of the
<span class="pre">`l4`</span>` `<span class="pre">`@`</span>` `<span class="pre">`1`</span>
vector.

<img src="_images/general_ex15.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex15.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b, c = 80, 40, 20
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex15:
  >         with BuildSketch() as ex15_sk:
  >             with BuildLine() as ex15_ln:
  >                 l1 = Line((0, 0), (a, 0))
  >                 l2 = Line(l1 @ 1, l1 @ 1 + (0, b))
  >                 l3 = Line(l2 @ 1, l2 @ 1 + (-c, 0))
  >                 l4 = Line(l3 @ 1, l3 @ 1 + (0, -c))
  >                 l5 = Line(l4 @ 1, (0, (l4 @ 1).Y))
  >                 mirror(ex15_ln.line, about=Plane.YZ)
  >             make_face()
  >         extrude(amount=c)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > Combine lines via the pattern
  > <span class="pre">`Curve()`</span>` `<span class="pre">`+`</span>` `<span class="pre">`[l1,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`l2,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`l3,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`l4,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`l5]`</span>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b, c = 80, 40, 20
  >
  >     l1 = Line((0, 0), (a, 0))
  >     l2 = Line(l1 @ 1, l1 @ 1 + (0, b))
  >     l3 = Line(l2 @ 1, l2 @ 1 + (-c, 0))
  >     l4 = Line(l3 @ 1, l3 @ 1 + (0, -c))
  >     l5 = Line(l4 @ 1, (0, (l4 @ 1).Y))
  >     ln = Curve() + [l1, l2, l3, l4, l5]
  >     ln += mirror(ln, Plane.YZ)
  >
  >     sk15 = make_face(ln)
  >     ex15 = extrude(sk15, c)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_mirroring-3d-objects"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-16"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id17" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">16. Mirroring 3D Objects</a>

Mirror can also be used with BuildPart (and BuildSketch) to mirror 3D
objects. The <span class="pre">`Plane.offset()`</span> method shifts the
plane in the normal direction (positive or negative).

<img src="_images/general_ex16.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex16.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex16_single:
  >         with BuildSketch(Plane.XZ) as ex16_sk:
  >             Rectangle(length, width)
  >             fillet(ex16_sk.vertices(), radius=length / 10)
  >             with GridLocations(x_spacing=length / 4, y_spacing=0, x_count=3, y_count=1):
  >                 Circle(length / 12, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
  >             Rectangle(length, width, align=(Align.MIN, Align.MIN), mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
  >         extrude(amount=length)
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex16:
  >         add(ex16_single.part)
  >         mirror(ex16_single.part, about=Plane.XY.offset(width))
  >         mirror(ex16_single.part, about=Plane.YX.offset(width))
  >         mirror(ex16_single.part, about=Plane.YZ.offset(width))
  >         mirror(ex16_single.part, about=Plane.YZ.offset(-width))
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     sk16 = Rectangle(length, width)
  >     sk16 = fillet(sk16.vertices(), length / 10)
  >
  >     circles = [loc * Circle(length / 12) for loc in GridLocations(length / 4, 0, 3, 1)]
  >
  >     sk16 = sk16 - circles - Rectangle(length, width, align=(Align.MIN, Align.MIN))
  >     ex16_single = extrude(Plane.XZ * sk16, length)
  >
  >     planes = [
  >         Plane.XY.offset(width),
  >         Plane.YX.offset(width),
  >         Plane.YZ.offset(width),
  >         Plane.YZ.offset(-width),
  >     ]
  >     objs = [mirror(ex16_single, plane) for plane in planes]
  >     ex16 = ex16_single + objs
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_mirroring-from-faces"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-17"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id18" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">17. Mirroring From Faces</a>

Here we select the farthest face in the Y-direction and turn it into a
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Plane"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Plane"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Plane</code></span></a>
using the <span class="pre">`Plane()`</span> class.

<img src="_images/general_ex17.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex17.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b = 30, 20
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex17:
  >         with BuildSketch() as ex17_sk:
  >             RegularPolygon(radius=a, side_count=5)
  >         extrude(amount=b)
  >         mirror(ex17.part, about=Plane(ex17.faces().group_by(Axis.Y)[0][0]))
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b = 30, 20
  >
  >     sk17 = RegularPolygon(radius=a, side_count=5)
  >     ex17 = extrude(sk17, amount=b)
  >     ex17 += mirror(ex17, Plane(ex17.faces().sort_by(Axis.Y).first))
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_creating-workplanes-on-faces"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-18"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id19" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">18. Creating Workplanes on Faces</a>

Here we start with an earlier example, select the top face, draw a
rectangle and then use Extrude with a negative distance.

<img src="_images/general_ex18.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex18.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > We then use <span class="pre">`Mode.SUBTRACT`</span> to cut it out
  > from the main body.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >     a, b = 4, 5
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex18:
  >         Box(length, width, thickness)
  >         chamfer(ex18.edges().group_by(Axis.Z)[-1], length=a)
  >         fillet(ex18.edges().filter_by(Axis.Z), radius=b)
  >         with BuildSketch(ex18.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]):
  >             Rectangle(2 * b, 2 * b)
  >         extrude(amount=-thickness, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > We then use <span class="pre">`-=`</span> to cut it out from the
  > main body.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >     a, b = 4, 5
  >
  >     ex18 = Part() + Box(length, width, thickness)
  >     ex18 = chamfer(ex18.edges().group_by()[-1], a)
  >     ex18 = fillet(ex18.edges().filter_by(Axis.Z), b)
  >
  >     sk18 = Plane(ex18.faces().sort_by().first) * Rectangle(2 * b, 2 * b)
  >     ex18 -= extrude(sk18, -thickness)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_locating-a-workplane-on-a-vertex"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-19"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id20" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">19. Locating a workplane on a vertex</a>

Here a face is selected and two different strategies are used to select
vertices. Firstly <span class="pre">`vtx`</span> uses
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.ShapeList.group_by"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.ShapeList.group_by"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">group_by()</code></span></a>
and <span class="pre">`Axis.X`</span> to select a particular vertex. The
second strategy uses a custom defined Axis
<span class="pre">`vtx2Axis`</span> that is pointing roughly in the
direction of a vertex to select, and then
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.ShapeList.sort_by"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.ShapeList.sort_by"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">sort_by()</code></span></a>
this custom Axis.

<img src="_images/general_ex19.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex19.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > Then the X and Y positions of these vertices are selected and passed
  > to <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.Locations"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_common.Locations"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Locations</code></span></a>
  > as center points for two circles that cut through the main part.
  > Note that if you passed the variable <span class="pre">`vtx`</span>
  > directly to
  > <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.Locations"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_common.Locations"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Locations</code></span></a>
  > then the part would be offset from the workplane by the vertex
  > z-position.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, thickness = 80.0, 10.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex19:
  >         with BuildSketch() as ex19_sk:
  >             RegularPolygon(radius=length / 2, side_count=7)
  >         extrude(amount=thickness)
  >         topf = ex19.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]
  >         vtx = topf.vertices().group_by(Axis.X)[-1][0]
  >         vtx2Axis = Axis((0, 0, 0), (-1, -0.5, 0))
  >         vtx2 = topf.vertices().sort_by(vtx2Axis)[-1]
  >         with BuildSketch(topf) as ex19_sk2:
  >             with Locations((vtx.X, vtx.Y), (vtx2.X, vtx2.Y)):
  >                 Circle(radius=length / 8)
  >         extrude(amount=-thickness, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > Then the X and Y positions of these vertices are selected and used
  > to move two circles that cut through the main part. Note that if you
  > passed the variable <span class="pre">`vtx`</span> directly to
  > <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Pos"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="geometry.Pos"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Pos</code></span></a>
  > then the part would be offset from the workplane by the vertex
  > z-position.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, thickness = 80.0, 10.0
  >
  >     ex19_sk = RegularPolygon(radius=length / 2, side_count=7)
  >     ex19 = extrude(ex19_sk, thickness)
  >
  >     topf = ex19.faces().sort_by().last
  >
  >     vtx = topf.vertices().group_by(Axis.X)[-1][0]
  >
  >     vtx2Axis = Axis((0, 0, 0), (-1, -0.5, 0))
  >     vtx2 = topf.vertices().sort_by(vtx2Axis)[-1]
  >
  >     ex19_sk2 = Circle(radius=length / 8)
  >     ex19_sk2 = Pos(vtx.X, vtx.Y) * ex19_sk2 + Pos(vtx2.X, vtx2.Y) * ex19_sk2
  >
  >     ex19 -= extrude(ex19_sk2, thickness)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_offset-sketch-workplane"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-20"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id21" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">20. Offset Sketch Workplane</a>

The <span class="pre">`plane`</span> variable is set to be coincident
with the farthest face in the negative x-direction. The resulting Plane
is offset from the original position.

<img src="_images/general_ex20.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex20.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex20:
  >         Box(length, width, thickness)
  >         plane = Plane(ex20.faces().group_by(Axis.X)[0][0])
  >         with BuildSketch(plane.offset(2 * thickness)):
  >             Circle(width / 3)
  >         extrude(amount=width)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     ex20 = Box(length, width, thickness)
  >     plane = Plane(ex20.faces().sort_by(Axis.X).first).offset(2 * thickness)
  >
  >     sk20 = plane * Circle(width / 3)
  >     ex20 += extrude(sk20, width)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_create-a-workplanes-in-the-center-of-another-shape"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-21"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id22" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">21. Create a Workplanes in the center of another
shape</a>

One cylinder is created, and then the origin and z_dir of that part are
used to create a new Plane for positioning another cylinder
perpendicular and halfway along the first.

<img src="_images/general_ex21.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex21.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     width, length = 10.0, 60.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex21:
  >         with BuildSketch() as ex21_sk:
  >             Circle(width / 2)
  >         extrude(amount=length)
  >         with BuildSketch(Plane(origin=ex21.part.center(), z_dir=(-1, 0, 0))):
  >             Circle(width / 2)
  >         extrude(amount=length)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     width, length = 10.0, 60.0
  >
  >     ex21 = extrude(Circle(width / 2), length)
  >     plane = Plane(origin=ex21.center(), z_dir=(-1, 0, 0))
  >     ex21 += plane * extrude(Circle(width / 2), length)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_rotated-workplanes"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-22"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id23" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">22. Rotated Workplanes</a>

It is also possible to create a rotated workplane, building upon some of
the concepts in an earlier example.

<img src="_images/general_ex22.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex22.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > Use the <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Plane.rotated"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="geometry.Plane.rotated"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">rotated()</code></span></a>
  > method to rotate the workplane.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex22:
  >         Box(length, width, thickness)
  >         pln = Plane(ex22.faces().group_by(Axis.Z)[0][0]).rotated((0, -50, 0))
  >         with BuildSketch(pln) as ex22_sk:
  >             with GridLocations(length / 4, width / 4, 2, 2):
  >                 Circle(thickness / 4)
  >         extrude(amount=-100, both=True, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > Use the operator <span class="pre">`*`</span> to relocate the plane
  > (post-multiplication!).
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     ex22 = Box(length, width, thickness)
  >     plane = Plane((ex22.faces().group_by(Axis.Z)[0])[0]) * Rot(0, 50, 0)
  >
  >     holes = Sketch() + [
  >         plane * loc * Circle(thickness / 4)
  >         for loc in GridLocations(length / 4, width / 4, 2, 2)
  >     ]
  >     ex22 -= extrude(holes, -100, both=True)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.GridLocations"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_common.GridLocations"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">GridLocations</code></span></a>
places 4 Circles on 4 points on this rotated workplane, and then the
Circles are extruded in the “both” (positive and negative) normal
direction.

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_revolve" class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-23"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id24" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">23. Revolve</a>

Here we build a sketch with a
<a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_curve.Polyline"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="objects_curve.Polyline"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Polyline</code></span></a>,
<a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_curve.Line"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="objects_curve.Line"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Line</code></span></a>,
and a <a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_sketch.Circle"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="objects_sketch.Circle"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Circle</code></span></a>.
It is absolutely critical that the sketch is only on one side of the
axis of rotation before Revolve is called. To that end,
<span class="pre">`split`</span> is used with
<span class="pre">`Plane.ZY`</span> to keep only one side of the Sketch.

It is highly recommended to view your sketch before you attempt to call
revolve.

<img src="_images/general_ex23.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex23.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     pts = [
  >         (-25, 35),
  >         (-25, 0),
  >         (-20, 0),
  >         (-20, 5),
  >         (-15, 10),
  >         (-15, 35),
  >     ]
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex23:
  >         with BuildSketch(Plane.XZ) as ex23_sk:
  >             with BuildLine() as ex23_ln:
  >                 l1 = Polyline(pts)
  >                 l2 = Line(l1 @ 1, l1 @ 0)
  >             make_face()
  >             with Locations((0, 35)):
  >                 Circle(25)
  >             split(bisect_by=Plane.ZY)
  >         revolve(axis=Axis.Z)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     pts = [
  >         (-25, 35),
  >         (-25, 0),
  >         (-20, 0),
  >         (-20, 5),
  >         (-15, 10),
  >         (-15, 35),
  >     ]
  >
  >     l1 = Polyline(pts)
  >     l2 = Line(l1 @ 1, l1 @ 0)
  >     sk23 = make_face([l1, l2])
  >
  >     sk23 += Pos(0, 35) * Circle(25)
  >     sk23 = Plane.XZ * split(sk23, bisect_by=Plane.ZY)
  >
  >     ex23 = revolve(sk23, Axis.Z)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_loft" class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-24"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id25" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">24. Loft</a>

Loft is a very powerful tool that can be used to join dissimilar shapes.
In this case we make a conical-like shape from a circle and a rectangle
that is offset vertically. In this case
<a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_part.loft"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_part.loft"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">loft()</code></span></a>
automatically takes the pending faces that were added by the two
BuildSketches. Loft can behave unexpectedly when the input faces are not
parallel to each other.

<img src="_images/general_ex24.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex24.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex24:
  >         Box(length, length, thickness)
  >         with BuildSketch(ex24.faces().group_by(Axis.Z)[0][0]) as ex24_sk:
  >             Circle(length / 3)
  >         with BuildSketch(ex24_sk.faces()[0].offset(length / 2)) as ex24_sk2:
  >             Rectangle(length / 6, width / 6)
  >         loft()
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     ex24 = Box(length, length, thickness)
  >     plane = Plane(ex24.faces().sort_by().last)
  >
  >     faces = Sketch() + [
  >         plane * Circle(length / 3),
  >         plane.offset(length / 2) * Rectangle(length / 6, width / 6),
  >     ]
  >
  >     ex24 += loft(faces)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_offset-sketch" class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-25"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id26" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">25. Offset Sketch</a>

<img src="_images/general_ex25.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex25.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > BuildSketch faces can be transformed with a 2D
  > <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.offset"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="operations_generic.offset"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">offset()</code></span></a>.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     rad, offs = 50, 10
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex25:
  >         with BuildSketch() as ex25_sk1:
  >             RegularPolygon(radius=rad, side_count=5)
  >         with BuildSketch(Plane.XY.offset(15)) as ex25_sk2:
  >             RegularPolygon(radius=rad, side_count=5)
  >             offset(amount=offs)
  >         with BuildSketch(Plane.XY.offset(30)) as ex25_sk3:
  >             RegularPolygon(radius=rad, side_count=5)
  >             offset(amount=offs, kind=Kind.INTERSECTION)
  >         extrude(amount=1)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > Sketch faces can be transformed with a 2D
  > <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.offset"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="operations_generic.offset"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">offset()</code></span></a>.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     rad, offs = 50, 10
  >
  >     sk25_1 = RegularPolygon(radius=rad, side_count=5)
  >     sk25_2 = Plane.XY.offset(15) * RegularPolygon(radius=rad, side_count=5)
  >     sk25_2 = offset(sk25_2, offs)
  >     sk25_3 = Plane.XY.offset(30) * RegularPolygon(radius=rad, side_count=5)
  >     sk25_3 = offset(sk25_3, offs, kind=Kind.INTERSECTION)
  >
  >     sk25 = Sketch() + [sk25_1, sk25_2, sk25_3]
  >     ex25 = extrude(sk25, 1)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

They can be offset inwards or outwards, and with different techniques
for extending the corners (see
<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Kind"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_enums.Kind"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Kind</code></span></a>
in the Offset docs).

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_offset-part-to-create-thin-features"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-26"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id27" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">26. Offset Part To Create Thin features</a>

Parts can also be transformed using an offset, but in this case with a
3D <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.offset"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_generic.offset"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">offset()</code></span></a>.
Also commonly known as a shell, this allows creating thin walls using
very few operations. This can also be offset inwards or outwards. Faces
can be selected to be “deleted” using the
<span class="pre">`openings`</span> parameter of
<a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.offset"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_generic.offset"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">offset()</code></span></a>.

Note that self intersecting edges and/or faces can break both 2D and 3D
offsets.

<img src="_images/general_ex26.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex26.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness, wall = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0, 2.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex26:
  >         Box(length, width, thickness)
  >         topf = ex26.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]
  >         offset(amount=-wall, openings=topf)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness, wall = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0, 2.0
  >
  >     ex26 = Box(length, width, thickness)
  >     topf = ex26.faces().sort_by().last
  >     ex26 = offset(ex26, amount=-wall, openings=topf)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_splitting-an-object"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-27"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id28" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">27. Splitting an Object</a>

You can split an object using a plane, and retain either or both halves.
In this case we select a face and offset half the width of the box.

<img src="_images/general_ex27.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex27.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex27:
  >         Box(length, width, thickness)
  >         with BuildSketch(ex27.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[0]) as ex27_sk:
  >             Circle(width / 4)
  >         extrude(amount=-thickness, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
  >         split(bisect_by=Plane(ex27.faces().sort_by(Axis.Y)[-1]).offset(-width / 2))
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     ex27 = Box(length, width, thickness)
  >     sk27 = Plane(ex27.faces().sort_by().first) * Circle(width / 4)
  >     ex27 -= extrude(sk27, -thickness)
  >     ex27 = split(ex27, Plane(ex27.faces().sort_by(Axis.Y).last).offset(-width / 2))
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_locating-features-based-on-faces"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-28"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id29" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">28. Locating features based on Faces</a>

<img src="_images/general_ex28.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex28.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > We create a triangular prism with
  > <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Mode"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_enums.Mode"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Mode</code></span></a>
  > <span class="pre">`.PRIVATE`</span> and then later use the faces of
  > this object to cut holes in a sphere.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     width, thickness = 80.0, 10.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex28:
  >         with BuildSketch() as ex28_sk:
  >             RegularPolygon(radius=width / 4, side_count=3)
  >         ex28_ex = extrude(amount=thickness, mode=Mode.PRIVATE)
  >         midfaces = ex28_ex.faces().group_by(Axis.Z)[1]
  >         Sphere(radius=width / 2)
  >         for face in midfaces:
  >             with Locations(face):
  >                 Hole(thickness / 2)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > We create a triangular prism and then later use the faces of this
  > object to cut holes in a sphere.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     width, thickness = 80.0, 10.0
  >
  >     sk28 = RegularPolygon(radius=width / 4, side_count=3)
  >     tmp28 = extrude(sk28, thickness)
  >     ex28 = Sphere(radius=width / 2)
  >     for p in [Plane(face) for face in tmp28.faces().group_by(Axis.Z)[1]]:
  >         ex28 -= p * Hole(thickness / 2, depth=width)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

We are able to create multiple workplanes by looping over the list of
faces.

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_the-classic-occ-bottle"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-29"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id30" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">29. The Classic OCC Bottle</a>

build123d is based on the OpenCascade.org (OCC) modeling Kernel. Those
who are familiar with OCC know about the famous ‘bottle’ example. We use
a 3D Offset and the openings parameter to create the bottle opening.

<img src="_images/general_ex29.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex29.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     L, w, t, b, h, n = 60.0, 18.0, 9.0, 0.9, 90.0, 6.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex29:
  >         with BuildSketch(Plane.XY.offset(-b)) as ex29_ow_sk:
  >             with BuildLine() as ex29_ow_ln:
  >                 l1 = Line((0, 0), (0, w / 2))
  >                 l2 = ThreePointArc(l1 @ 1, (L / 2.0, w / 2.0 + t), (L, w / 2.0))
  >                 l3 = Line(l2 @ 1, ((l2 @ 1).X, 0, 0))
  >                 mirror(ex29_ow_ln.line)
  >             make_face()
  >         extrude(amount=h + b)
  >         fillet(ex29.edges(), radius=w / 6)
  >         with BuildSketch(ex29.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]):
  >             Circle(t)
  >         extrude(amount=n)
  >         necktopf = ex29.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]
  >         offset(ex29.solids()[0], amount=-b, openings=necktopf)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     L, w, t, b, h, n = 60.0, 18.0, 9.0, 0.9, 90.0, 8.0
  >
  >     l1 = Line((0, 0), (0, w / 2))
  >     l2 = ThreePointArc(l1 @ 1, (L / 2.0, w / 2.0 + t), (L, w / 2.0))
  >     l3 = Line(l2 @ 1, ((l2 @ 1).X, 0, 0))
  >     ln29 = l1 + l2 + l3
  >     ln29 += mirror(ln29)
  >     sk29 = make_face(ln29)
  >     ex29 = extrude(sk29, -(h + b))
  >     ex29 = fillet(ex29.edges(), radius=w / 6)
  >
  >     neck = Plane(ex29.faces().sort_by().last) * Circle(t)
  >     ex29 += extrude(neck, n)
  >     necktopf = ex29.faces().sort_by().last
  >     ex29 = offset(ex29, -b, openings=necktopf)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_bezier-curve" class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-30"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id31" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">30. Bezier Curve</a>

Here <span class="pre">`pts`</span> is used as an input to both
<a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_curve.Polyline"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="objects_curve.Polyline"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Polyline</code></span></a>
and <a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_curve.Bezier"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="objects_curve.Bezier"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Bezier</code></span></a>
and <span class="pre">`wts`</span> to Bezier alone. These two together
create a closed line that is made into a face and extruded.

<img src="_images/general_ex30.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex30.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     pts = [
  >         (0, 0),
  >         (20, 20),
  >         (40, 0),
  >         (0, -40),
  >         (-60, 0),
  >         (0, 100),
  >         (100, 0),
  >     ]
  >
  >     wts = [
  >         1.0,
  >         1.0,
  >         2.0,
  >         3.0,
  >         4.0,
  >         2.0,
  >         1.0,
  >     ]
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex30:
  >         with BuildSketch() as ex30_sk:
  >             with BuildLine() as ex30_ln:
  >                 l0 = Polyline(pts)
  >                 l1 = Bezier(pts, weights=wts)
  >             make_face()
  >         extrude(amount=10)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     pts = [
  >         (0, 0),
  >         (20, 20),
  >         (40, 0),
  >         (0, -40),
  >         (-60, 0),
  >         (0, 100),
  >         (100, 0),
  >     ]
  >
  >     wts = [
  >         1.0,
  >         1.0,
  >         2.0,
  >         3.0,
  >         4.0,
  >         2.0,
  >         1.0,
  >     ]
  >
  >     ex30_ln = Polyline(pts) + Bezier(pts, weights=wts)
  >     ex30_sk = make_face(ex30_ln)
  >     ex30 = extrude(ex30_sk, -10)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_nesting-locations" class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-31"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id32" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">31. Nesting Locations</a>

Locations contexts can be nested to create groups of shapes. Here 24
triangles, 6 squares, and 1 hexagon are created and then extruded.
Notably
<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.PolarLocations"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_common.PolarLocations"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">PolarLocations</code></span></a>
rotates any “children” groups by default.

<img src="_images/general_ex31.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex31.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b, c = 80.0, 5.0, 3.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex31:
  >         with BuildSketch() as ex31_sk:
  >             with PolarLocations(a / 2, 6):
  >                 with GridLocations(3 * b, 3 * b, 2, 2):
  >                     RegularPolygon(b, 3)
  >                 RegularPolygon(b, 4)
  >             RegularPolygon(3 * b, 6, rotation=30)
  >         extrude(amount=c)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b, c = 80.0, 5.0, 3.0
  >
  >     ex31 = Rot(Z=30) * RegularPolygon(3 * b, 6)
  >     ex31 += PolarLocations(a / 2, 6) * (
  >         RegularPolygon(b, 4) + GridLocations(3 * b, 3 * b, 2, 2) * RegularPolygon(b, 3)
  >     )
  >     ex31 = extrude(ex31, 3)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_python-for-loop" class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-32"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id33" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">32. Python For-Loop</a>

In this example, a standard python for-loop is used along with a list of
faces extracted from a sketch to progressively modify the extrusion
amount. There are 7 faces in the sketch, so this results in 7 separate
calls to <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_part.extrude"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_part.extrude"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">extrude()</code></span></a>.

<img src="_images/general_ex32.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex32.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Mode"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_enums.Mode"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Mode</code></span></a>
  > <span class="pre">`.PRIVATE`</span> is used in
  > <a href="#build_sketch.xhtml_build_sketch.BuildSketch"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_sketch.BuildSketch"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">BuildSketch</code></span></a>
  > to avoid adding these faces until the for-loop.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b, c = 80.0, 10.0, 1.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex32:
  >         with BuildSketch(mode=Mode.PRIVATE) as ex32_sk:
  >             RegularPolygon(2 * b, 6, rotation=30)
  >             with PolarLocations(a / 2, 6):
  >                 RegularPolygon(b, 4)
  >         for idx, obj in enumerate(ex32_sk.sketch.faces()):
  >             add(obj)
  >             extrude(amount=c + 3 * idx)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b, c = 80.0, 10.0, 1.0
  >
  >     ex32_sk = RegularPolygon(2 * b, 6, rotation=30)
  >     ex32_sk += PolarLocations(a / 2, 6) * RegularPolygon(b, 4)
  >     ex32 = Part() + [extrude(obj, c + 3 * idx) for idx, obj in enumerate(ex32_sk.faces())]
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_python-function-and-for-loop"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-33"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id34" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">33. Python Function and For-Loop</a>

Building on the previous example, a standard python function is used to
return a sketch as a function of several inputs to progressively modify
the size of each square.

<img src="_images/general_ex33.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex33.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > The function returns a
  > <a href="#build_sketch.xhtml_build_sketch.BuildSketch"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_sketch.BuildSketch"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">BuildSketch</code></span></a>.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b, c = 80.0, 5.0, 1.0
  >
  >
  >     def square(rad, loc):
  >         with BuildSketch() as sk:
  >             with Locations(loc):
  >                 RegularPolygon(rad, 4)
  >         return sk.sketch
  >
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex33:
  >         with BuildSketch(mode=Mode.PRIVATE) as ex33_sk:
  >             locs = PolarLocations(a / 2, 6)
  >             for i, j in enumerate(locs):
  >                 add(square(b + 2 * i, j))
  >         for idx, obj in enumerate(ex33_sk.sketch.faces()):
  >             add(obj)
  >             extrude(amount=c + 2 * idx)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > The function returns a <span class="pre">`Sketch`</span> object.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     a, b, c = 80.0, 5.0, 1.0
  >
  >
  >     def square(rad, loc):
  >         return loc * RegularPolygon(rad, 4)
  >
  >
  >     ex33 = Part() + [
  >         extrude(square(b + 2 * i, loc), c + 2 * i)
  >         for i, loc in enumerate(PolarLocations(a / 2, 6))
  >     ]
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_embossed-and-debossed-text"
class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-34"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id35" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">34. Embossed and Debossed Text</a>

<img src="_images/general_ex34.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex34.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > The text “Hello” is placed on top of a rectangle and embossed
  > (raised) by placing a BuildSketch on the top face
  > (<span class="pre">`topf`</span>). Note that
  > <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Align"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_enums.Align"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Align</code></span></a>
  > is used to control the text placement. We re-use the
  > <span class="pre">`topf`</span> variable to select the same face and
  > deboss (indented) the text “World”. Note that if we simply ran
  > <span class="pre">`BuildSketch(ex34.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1])`</span>
  > for both
  > <span class="pre">`ex34_sk1`</span>` `<span class="pre">`&`</span>` `<span class="pre">`2`</span>
  > it would incorrectly locate the 2nd “World” text on the top of the
  > “Hello” text.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness, fontsz, fontht = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0, 25.0, 4.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex34:
  >         Box(length, width, thickness)
  >         topf = ex34.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]
  >         with BuildSketch(topf) as ex34_sk:
  >             Text("Hello", font_size=fontsz, align=(Align.CENTER, Align.MIN))
  >         extrude(amount=fontht)
  >         with BuildSketch(topf) as ex34_sk2:
  >             Text("World", font_size=fontsz, align=(Align.CENTER, Align.MAX))
  >         extrude(amount=-fontht, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > The text “Hello” is placed on top of a rectangle and embossed
  > (raised) by placing a sketch on the top face
  > (<span class="pre">`topf`</span>). Note that
  > <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Align"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_enums.Align"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Align</code></span></a>
  > is used to control the text placement. We re-use the
  > <span class="pre">`topf`</span> variable to select the same face and
  > deboss (indented) the text “World”.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness, fontsz, fontht = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0, 25.0, 4.0
  >
  >     ex34 = Box(length, width, thickness)
  >     plane = Plane(ex34.faces().sort_by().last)
  >     ex34_sk = plane * Text("Hello", font_size=fontsz, align=(Align.CENTER, Align.MIN))
  >     ex34 += extrude(ex34_sk, amount=fontht)
  >     ex34_sk2 = plane * Text("World", font_size=fontsz, align=(Align.CENTER, Align.MAX))
  >     ex34 -= extrude(ex34_sk2, amount=-fontht)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_slots" class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-35"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id36" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">35. Slots</a>

<img src="_images/general_ex35.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex35.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > Here we create a
  > <a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_sketch.SlotCenterToCenter"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="objects_sketch.SlotCenterToCenter"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">SlotCenterToCenter</code></span></a>
  > and then use a <a href="#build_line.xhtml_build_line.BuildLine"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="build_line.BuildLine"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">BuildLine</code></span></a>
  > and <a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_curve.RadiusArc"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="objects_curve.RadiusArc"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">RadiusArc</code></span></a>
  > to create an arc for two instances of
  > <a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_sketch.SlotArc"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="objects_sketch.SlotArc"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">SlotArc</code></span></a>.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex35:
  >         Box(length, length, thickness)
  >         topf = ex35.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]
  >         with BuildSketch(topf) as ex35_sk:
  >             SlotCenterToCenter(width / 2, 10)
  >             with BuildLine(mode=Mode.PRIVATE) as ex35_ln:
  >                 RadiusArc((-width / 2, 0), (0, width / 2), radius=width / 2)
  >             SlotArc(arc=ex35_ln.edges()[0], height=thickness, rotation=0)
  >             with BuildLine(mode=Mode.PRIVATE) as ex35_ln2:
  >                 RadiusArc((0, -width / 2), (width / 2, 0), radius=-width / 2)
  >             SlotArc(arc=ex35_ln2.edges()[0], height=thickness, rotation=0)
  >         extrude(amount=-thickness, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > Here we create a
  > <a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_sketch.SlotCenterToCenter"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="objects_sketch.SlotCenterToCenter"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">SlotCenterToCenter</code></span></a>
  > and then use a <a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_curve.RadiusArc"
  > class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  > title="objects_curve.RadiusArc"><span class="pre"><code
  > class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">RadiusArc</code></span></a>
  > to create an arc for two instances of
  > <span class="pre">`SlotArc`</span>.
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
  >
  >     ex35 = Box(length, length, thickness)
  >     plane = Plane(ex35.faces().sort_by().last)
  >     ex35_sk = SlotCenterToCenter(width / 2, 10)
  >     ex35_ln = RadiusArc((-width / 2, 0), (0, width / 2), radius=width / 2)
  >     ex35_sk += SlotArc(arc=ex35_ln.edges()[0], height=thickness)
  >     ex35_ln2 = RadiusArc((0, -width / 2), (width / 2, 0), radius=-width / 2)
  >     ex35_sk += SlotArc(arc=ex35_ln2.edges()[0], height=thickness)
  >     ex35 -= extrude(plane * ex35_sk, -thickness)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

<div id="introductory_examples.xhtml_extrude-until" class="section">

<span id="introductory_examples.xhtml_ex-36"></span>

## <a href="#introductory_examples.xhtml_id37" class="toc-backref"
role="doc-backlink">36. Extrude Until</a>

Sometimes you will want to extrude until a given face that could be non
planar or where you might not know easily the distance you have to
extrude to. In such cases you can use
<a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_part.extrude"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_part.extrude"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">extrude()</code></span></a>
<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Until"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_enums.Until"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Until</code></span></a>
with <span class="pre">`Until.NEXT`</span> or
<span class="pre">`Until.LAST`</span>.

<img src="_images/general_ex36.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex36.svg" />

- **Builder mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     rad, rev = 6, 50
  >
  >     with BuildPart() as ex36:
  >         with BuildSketch() as ex36_sk:
  >             with Locations((0, rev)):
  >                 Circle(rad)
  >         revolve(axis=Axis.X, revolution_arc=180)
  >         with BuildSketch() as ex36_sk2:
  >             Rectangle(rad, rev)
  >         extrude(until=Until.NEXT)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

- **Algebra mode**

  > <div>
  >
  > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
  >
  > <div class="highlight">
  >
  >     rad, rev = 6, 50
  >
  >     ex36_sk = Pos(0, rev) * Circle(rad)
  >     ex36 = revolve(axis=Axis.X, profiles=ex36_sk, revolution_arc=180)
  >     ex36_sk2 = Rectangle(rad, rev)
  >     ex36 += extrude(ex36_sk2, until=Until.NEXT, target=ex36)
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>
  >
  > </div>

</div>

</div>
