<span id="tutorial_design.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="tutorial_design.xhtml_designing-a-part-in-build123d"
class="section">

<span id="tutorial_design.xhtml_design-tutorial"></span>

# Designing a Part in build123d

Designing a part with build123d involves a systematic approach that
leverages the power of 2D profiles, extrusions, and revolutions. Where
possible, always work in the lowest possible dimension, 1D lines before
2D sketches before 3D parts. The following guide will get you started:

*As an example, we’ll go through the design process for this bracket:*

<img src="_images/bracket_hand_drawing.jpg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/bracket_hand_drawing.jpg" />

<div id="tutorial_design.xhtml_step-1-examine-the-part-in-all-three-orientations"
class="section">

## Step 1. Examine the Part in All Three Orientations

Start by visualizing the part from the front, top, and side views.
Identify any symmetries in these orientations, as symmetries can
simplify the design by reducing the number of unique features you need
to model.

*In the following view of the bracket one can see two planes of symmetry
so we’ll only need to design one quarter of it.*

<img src="_images/bracket_with_symmetry.png" class="align-center"
alt="_images/bracket_with_symmetry.png" />

</div>

<div id="tutorial_design.xhtml_step-2-identify-rotational-symmetries"
class="section">

## Step 2. Identify Rotational Symmetries

Look for structures that could be created through the rotation of a 2D
shape. For instance, cylindrical or spherical features are often the
result of revolving a profile around an axis. Identify the axis of
rotation and make a note of it.

*There are no rotational structures in the example bracket.*

</div>

<div id="tutorial_design.xhtml_step-3-select-a-convenient-origin"
class="section">

## Step 3. Select a Convenient Origin

Choose an origin point that minimizes the need to move or transform
components later in the design process. Ideally, the origin should be
placed at a natural center of symmetry or a critical reference point on
the part.

*The planes of symmetry for the bracket was identified in step 1, making
it logical to place the origin at the intersection of these planes on
the bracket’s front face. Additionally, we’ll define the coordinate
system we’ll be working in: Plane.XY (the default), where the origin is
set at the global (0,0,0) position. In this system, the x-axis aligns
with the front of the bracket, and the z-axis corresponds to its width.
It’s important to note that all coordinate systems/planes in build123d
adhere to the* <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right-hand_rule"
class="reference external">right-hand rule</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right-hand_rule\]</span> *meaning the
y-axis is automatically determined by this convention.*

<img src="_images/bracket_with_origin.png" class="align-center"
alt="_images/bracket_with_origin.png" />

</div>

<div id="tutorial_design.xhtml_step-4-create-2d-profiles"
class="section">

## Step 4. Create 2D Profiles

Design the 2D profiles of your part in the appropriate orientation(s).
These profiles are the foundation of the part’s geometry and can often
represent cross-sections of the part. Mirror parts of profiles across
any axes of symmetry identified earlier.

*The 2D profile of the bracket is as follows:*

<img src="_images/bracket_sketch.png" class="align-center"
alt="_images/bracket_sketch.png" />

*The build123d code to generate this profile is as follows:*

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildSketch() as sketch:
        with BuildLine() as profile:
            FilletPolyline(
                (0, 0), (length / 2, 0), (length / 2, height), radius=bend_radius
            )
            offset(amount=thickness, side=Side.LEFT)
        make_face()
        mirror(about=Plane.YZ)

</div>

</div>

*This code creates a 2D sketch of a mirrored profile in the build123d
CAD system. Here’s a step-by-step explanation of what it does:*

> <div>
>
> with BuildSketch() as sketch:  
> *This starts a context for creating a 2D sketch, which defines the
> overall boundary and geometric features. The sketch will be stored in
> the variable sketch.*
>
> with BuildLine() as profile:  
> *This starts another context, this time for drawing lines (or
> profiles) within the sketch. The profile consists of connected line
> segments, arcs, or polylines.*
>
> FilletPolyline((0, 0), (length / 2, 0), (length / 2, height), radius=bend_radius)  
> *This object draws a polyline with three points: (0,0), (length/2, 0),
> and (length/2, height). A fillet (curved corner) with a radius of
> bend_radius is added where applicable between the segments of the
> polyline.*
>
> offset(amount=thickness, side=Side.LEFT)  
> *This applies an offset to the polyline created earlier. The offset
> creates a parallel line at a distance of thickness to the left side of
> the original polyline. This operation essentially thickens the profile
> by a given amount.*
>
> make_face()  
> *This command creates a 2D face from the closed profile. The offset
> operation ensures that the profile is closed, allowing the creation of
> a solid face from the boundary defined.*
>
> mirror(about=Plane.YZ)  
> *This mirrors the entire face about the YZ plane (which runs along the
> center of the sketch), creating a symmetrical counterpart of the face.
> The mirrored geometry will complete the final shape.*
>
> </div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_design.xhtml_step-5-use-extrusion-for-prismatic-features"
class="section">

## Step 5. Use Extrusion for Prismatic Features

For solid or prismatic shapes, extrude the 2D profiles along the
necessary axis. You can also combine multiple extrusions by intersecting
or unionizing them to form complex shapes. Use the resulting geometry as
sub-parts if needed.

*The next step in implementing our design in build123d is to convert the
above sketch into a part by extruding it as shown in this code:*

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as bracket:
        with BuildSketch() as sketch:
            with BuildLine() as profile:
                FilletPolyline(
                    (0, 0), (length / 2, 0), (length / 2, height), radius=bend_radius
                )
                offset(amount=thickness, side=Side.LEFT)
            make_face()
            mirror(about=Plane.YZ)
        extrude(amount=width / 2)
        mirror(about=Plane.XY)

</div>

</div>

*In this example, we’ve wrapped the sketch within a BuildPart context,
which is used for creating 3D parts. We utilized the extrude function to
extend the 2D sketch into a solid object, turning it into a 3D part.
Additionally, we applied the mirror function to replicate the partial
part across a plane of symmetry, ensuring a symmetrical design.*

</div>

<div id="tutorial_design.xhtml_step-6-generate-revolved-features"
class="section">

## Step 6. Generate Revolved Features

If any part of the geometry can be created by revolving a 2D profile
around an axis, use the revolve operation. This is particularly useful
for parts that include cylindrical, conical, or spherical features.
Combine these revolved sub-parts with existing features using additive,
subtractive, or intersecting operations.

*Our example has no revolved features.*

</div>

<div id="tutorial_design.xhtml_step-7-combine-sub-parts-intelligently"
class="section">

## Step 7. Combine Sub-parts Intelligently

When combining multiple sub-parts, keep in mind whether they need to be
added, subtracted, or intersected. Subtracting or intersecting can
create more refined details, while addition is useful for creating
complex assemblies.

*Out example only has one sub-part but further sub-parts could be
created in the BuildPart context by defining more sketches and extruding
or revolving them.*

</div>

<div id="tutorial_design.xhtml_step-8-apply-chamfers-and-fillets"
class="section">

## Step 8. Apply Chamfers and Fillets

Identify critical edges or vertices that need chamfering or filleting.
Use build123d’s selectors to apply these operations accurately. Always
visually inspect the results to ensure the correct edges have been
modified.

*The back corners of the bracket need to be rounded off or filleted so
the edges that define these corners need to be isolated. The following
code, placed to follow the previous code block, captures just these
edges:*

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    corners = bracket.edges().filter_by(Axis.X).group_by(Axis.Y)[-1]
    fillet(corners, fillet_radius)

</div>

</div>

*These lines isolates specific corner edges that are then filleted.*

> <div>
>
> corners = bracket.edges().filter_by(Axis.X).group_by(Axis.Y)\[-1\]  
> *This line is used to select specific edges from the 3D part (bracket)
> that was created by the extrusion.*
>
> - bracket.edges() *retrieves all the edges of the bracket part.*
>
> - filter_by(Axis.X) *filters the edges to only those that are aligned
>   along the X-axis.*
>
> - group_by(Axis.Y) *groups the edges by their positions along the
>   Y-axis. This operation essentially organizes the filtered X-axis
>   edges into groups based on their Y-coordinate positions.*
>
> - \[-1\] *selects the last group of edges along the Y-axis, which
>   corresponds to the back of the part - the edges we are looking for.*
>
> fillet(corners, fillet_radius)  
> *This function applies a fillet (a rounded edge) to the selected
> corners, with a specified radius (fillet_radius). The fillet smooths
> the sharp edges at the corners, giving the part a more refined shape.*
>
> </div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_design.xhtml_step-9-design-for-assembly"
class="section">

## Step 9. Design for Assembly

If the part is intended to connect with others, add features like
joints, holes, or other attachment points. Ensure that these features
are precisely located to ensure proper fitment and functionality in the
final assembly.

*Our example has two circular holes and a slot that need to be created.
First we’ll create the two circular holes:*

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with Locations(bracket.faces().sort_by(Axis.X)[-1]):
        Hole(hole_diameter / 2)

</div>

</div>

*This code creates a hole in a specific face of the bracket part.*

> <div>
>
> with Locations(bracket.faces().sort_by(Axis.X)\[-1\]):  
> *This context sets a location(s) for subsequent operations.*
>
> - bracket.faces() *retrieves all the faces of the bracket part.*
>
> - sort_by(Axis.X) *sorts these faces based on their position along the
>   X-axis (from one side of the bracket to the other).*
>
> - \[-1\] *selects the last face in this sorted list, which would be
>   the face farthest along the X-axis, the extreme right side of the
>   part.*
>
> - Locations() *creates a new local context or coordinate system at the
>   selected face, effectively setting this face as the working location
>   for any subsequent operations inside the with block.*
>
> Hole(hole_diameter / 2)  
> *This creates a hole in the selected face. The radius of the hole is
> specified as hole_diameter / 2. The hole is placed at the origin of
> the selected face, based on the local coordinate system created by
> Locations(). As the depth of the hole is not provided it is assumed to
> go entirely through the part.*
>
> </div>

*Next the slot needs to be created in the bracket with will be done by
sketching a slot on the front of the bracket and extruding the sketch
through the part.*

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildSketch(bracket.faces().sort_by(Axis.Y)[0]):
        SlotOverall(20 * MM, hole_diameter)
    extrude(amount=-thickness, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)

</div>

</div>

*Here’s a detailed explanation of what each part does:*

> <div>
>
> with BuildSketch(bracket.faces().sort_by(Axis.Y)\[0\]):  
> *This line sets up a sketching context.*
>
> - bracket.faces() *retrieves all the faces of the bracket part.*
>
> - sort_by(Axis.Y) *sorts the faces along the Y-axis, arranging them
>   from the lowest Y-coordinate to the highest.*
>
> - \[0\] *selects the first face in this sorted list, which is the one
>   located at the lowest Y-coordinate, the nearest face of the part.*
>
> - BuildSketch() *creates a new sketching context on this selected
>   face, where 2D geometry will be drawn.*
>
> SlotOverall(20, hole_diameter)  
> *This command draws a slot (a rounded rectangle or elongated hole) on
> the selected face. The slot has a total length of 20 mm and a width
> equal to hole_diameter. The slot is defined within the 2D sketch on
> the selected face of the bracket.*
>
> extrude(amount=-thickness, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)  
> extrude() *takes the 2D sketch (the slot) and extends it into the 3D
> space by a distance equal to -thickness, creating a cut into the part.
> The negative value (-thickness) indicates that the extrusion is
> directed inward into the part (a cut).* mode=Mode.SUBTRACT *specifies
> that the extrusion is a subtractive operation, meaning it removes
> material from the bracket, effectively cutting the slot through the
> face of the part.*
>
> </div>

*Although beyond the scope of this tutorial, joints could be defined for
each of the holes to allow programmatic connection to other parts.*

</div>

<div id="tutorial_design.xhtml_step-10-plan-for-parametric-flexibility"
class="section">

## Step 10. Plan for Parametric Flexibility

Wherever possible, make your design parametric, allowing dimensions and
features to be easily adjusted later. This flexibility can be crucial if
the design needs modifications or if variations of the part are needed.

*The dimensions of the bracket are defined as follows:*

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    thickness = 3 * MM
    width = 25 * MM
    length = 50 * MM
    height = 25 * MM
    hole_diameter = 5 * MM
    bend_radius = 5 * MM
    fillet_radius = 2 * MM

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_design.xhtml_step-11-test-fit-and-tolerances"
class="section">

## Step 11. Test Fit and Tolerances

Visualize the fit of the part within its intended assembly. Consider
tolerances for manufacturing, such as clearance between moving parts or
shrinkage for 3D-printed parts. Adjust the design as needed to ensure
real-world functionality.

</div>

<div id="tutorial_design.xhtml_summary" class="section">

## Summary

These steps should guide you through a logical and efficient workflow in
build123d (or any CAD tool), helping you to design parts with accuracy
and ease.

*The entire code block for the bracket example is shown here:*

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *
    from ocp_vscode import show_all

    thickness = 3 * MM
    width = 25 * MM
    length = 50 * MM
    height = 25 * MM
    hole_diameter = 5 * MM
    bend_radius = 5 * MM
    fillet_radius = 2 * MM

    with BuildPart() as bracket:
        with BuildSketch() as sketch:
            with BuildLine() as profile:
                FilletPolyline(
                    (0, 0), (length / 2, 0), (length / 2, height), radius=bend_radius
                )
                offset(amount=thickness, side=Side.LEFT)
            make_face()
            mirror(about=Plane.YZ)
        extrude(amount=width / 2)
        mirror(about=Plane.XY)
        corners = bracket.edges().filter_by(Axis.X).group_by(Axis.Y)[-1]
        fillet(corners, fillet_radius)
        with Locations(bracket.faces().sort_by(Axis.X)[-1]):
            Hole(hole_diameter / 2)
        with BuildSketch(bracket.faces().sort_by(Axis.Y)[0]):
            SlotOverall(20 * MM, hole_diameter)
        extrude(amount=-thickness, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)

    show_all()

</div>

</div>

<img src="_images/bracket.png" class="align-center"
alt="_images/bracket.png" />

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<span id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_selector-tutorial" class="section">

# Selector Tutorial

This tutorial provides a step by step guide in using selectors as we
create this part:

<img src="_images/selector_after.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/selector_after.svg" />

<div class="admonition note">

Note

One can see any object in the following tutorial by using the
<span class="pre">`ocp_vscode`</span> (or any other supported viewer) by
using the <span class="pre">`show(object_to_be_viewed)`</span> command.
Alternatively, the <span class="pre">`show_all()`</span> command will
display all objects that have been assigned an identifier.

</div>

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_step-1-setup" class="section">

## Step 1: Setup

Before getting to the CAD operations, this selector script needs to
import the build123d environment.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *
    from ocp_vscode import *

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_step-2-create-base-with-buildpart"
class="section">

## Step 2: Create Base with BuildPart

To start off, the part will be based on a cylinder so we’ll use the
<a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_part.Cylinder"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="objects_part.Cylinder"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Cylinder</code></span></a>
object of <a href="#build_part.xhtml_build_part.BuildPart"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_part.BuildPart"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">BuildPart</code></span></a>:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *
    from ocp_vscode import *

    with BuildPart() as example:
        Cylinder(radius=10, height=3)

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_step-3-place-sketch-on-top-of-base"
class="section">

## Step 3: Place Sketch on top of base

The next set of features in this design will be created on the top of
the cylinder and be described by a planar sketch
(<a href="#build_sketch.xhtml_build_sketch.BuildSketch"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_sketch.BuildSketch"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">BuildSketch</code></span></a>
is the tool for drawing on planar surfaces) , so we’ll create a sketch
centered on the top of the cylinder. To locate this sketch we’ll use the
cylinder’s top Face as shown here:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *
    from ocp_vscode import *

    with BuildPart() as example:
        Cylinder(radius=10, height=3)
        with BuildSketch(example.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]):

</div>

</div>

Here we’re using selectors to find that top Face - let’s break down
<span class="pre">`example.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]`</span>:

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_step-3a-extract-faces-from-a-part"
class="section">

### Step 3a: Extract Faces from a part

The first sub-step is the extraction of all of the Faces from the part
that we’re building. The
<a href="#build_part.xhtml_build_part.BuildPart"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_part.BuildPart"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">BuildPart</code></span></a>
instance was assigned the identifier <span class="pre">`example`</span>
so <span class="pre">`example.faces()`</span> will extract all of the
Faces from that part into a custom python
<span class="pre">`list`</span> - a
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.ShapeList"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.ShapeList"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">ShapeList</code></span></a>.

</div>

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_step-3b-get-top-face" class="section">

### Step 3b: Get top Face

The next sub-step is to sort the ShapeList of Faces by their position
with respect to the Z Axis. The <span class="pre">`sort_by`</span>
method will sort the list by relative position of the object’s center to
the <span class="pre">`Axis.Z`</span> and
<span class="pre">`[-1]`</span> selects the last item on that list - or
return the top Face of the <span class="pre">`example`</span> part.

</div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_step-4-create-hole-shape"
class="section">

## Step 4: Create hole shape

The object has a hexagonal hole in the top with a central cylinder which
we’ll describe in the sketch.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *
    from ocp_vscode import *

    with BuildPart() as example:
        Cylinder(radius=10, height=3)
        with BuildSketch(example.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]):
            RegularPolygon(radius=7, side_count=6)
            Circle(radius=4, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)

</div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_step-4a-draw-a-hexagon"
class="section">

### Step 4a: Draw a hexagon

We’ll create a hexagon with the use of
<a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_sketch.RegularPolygon"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="objects_sketch.RegularPolygon"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">RegularPolygon</code></span></a>
object with six sides.

</div>

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_step-4b-create-a-hole-in-the-hexagon"
class="section">

### Step 4b: Create a hole in the hexagon

To create the hole we’ll subtract a
<a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_sketch.Circle"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="objects_sketch.Circle"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Circle</code></span></a>
from the sketch by using <span class="pre">`mode=Mode.SUBTRACT`</span>.
The sketch now described the hexagonal hole that we want to make in the
<a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_part.Cylinder"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="objects_part.Cylinder"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Cylinder</code></span></a>.

</div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_step-5-create-the-hole"
class="section">

## Step 5: Create the hole

To create the hole we’ll
<a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_part.extrude"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_part.extrude"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-func docutils literal notranslate">extrude()</code></span></a>
the sketch we just created into the
<a href="#objects.xhtml_objects_part.Cylinder"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="objects_part.Cylinder"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Cylinder</code></span></a>
and subtract it.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *
    from ocp_vscode import *

    with BuildPart() as example:
        Cylinder(radius=10, height=3)
        with BuildSketch(example.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]):
            RegularPolygon(radius=7, side_count=6)
            Circle(radius=4, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
        extrude(amount=-2, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)

</div>

</div>

Note that <span class="pre">`amount=-2`</span> indicates extruding into
the part and - just like with the sketch -
<span class="pre">`mode=Mode.SUBTRACT`</span> instructs the builder to
subtract this hexagonal shape from the part under construction.

At this point the part looks like:

<img src="_images/selector_before.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/selector_before.svg" />

</div>

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_step-6-fillet-the-top-perimeter-edge"
class="section">

## Step 6: Fillet the top perimeter Edge

The final step is to apply a fillet to the top perimeter.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *
    from ocp_vscode import *

    with BuildPart() as example:
        Cylinder(radius=10, height=3)
        with BuildSketch(example.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]):
            RegularPolygon(radius=7, side_count=6)
            Circle(radius=4, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
        extrude(amount=-2, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
        fillet(
            example.edges()
            .filter_by(GeomType.CIRCLE)
            .sort_by(SortBy.RADIUS)[-2:]
            .sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1],
            radius=1,
        )

    show(example)

</div>

</div>

Here we’re using the
<a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.fillet"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_generic.fillet"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-func docutils literal notranslate">fillet()</code></span></a>
operation which needs two things: the edge(s) to fillet and the radius
of the fillet. To provide the edge, we’ll use more selectors as
described in the following sub-steps.

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_step-6a-extract-all-the-edges"
class="section">

### Step 6a: Extract all the Edges

Much like selecting Faces in Step 3a, we’ll select all of the
<span class="pre">`example`</span> part’s edges with
<span class="pre">`example.edges()`</span>.

</div>

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_step-6b-filter-the-edges-for-circles"
class="section">

### Step 6b: Filter the Edges for circles

Since we know that the edge we’re looking for is a circle, we can filter
the edges selected in Step 6a for just those that are of geometric type
<span class="pre">`CIRCLE`</span> with
<span class="pre">`example.edges().filter_by(GeomType.CIRCLE)`</span>.
This step removes all of the Edges of the hexagon hole.

</div>

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_step-6c-sort-the-circles-by-radius"
class="section">

### Step 6c: Sort the circles by radius

The perimeter are the largest circles - the central cylinder must be
excluded - so we’ll sort all of the circles by their radius with:
<span class="pre">`example.edges().filter_by(GeomType.CIRCLE).sort_by(SortBy.RADIUS)`</span>.

</div>

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_step-6d-slice-the-list-to-get-the-two-largest"
class="section">

### Step 6d: Slice the list to get the two largest

We know that the <span class="pre">`example`</span> part has two
perimeter circles so we’ll select just the top two edges from the sorted
circle list with:
<span class="pre">`example.edges().filter_by(GeomType.CIRCLE).sort_by(SortBy.RADIUS)[-2:]`</span>.
The syntax of this slicing operation is standard python list slicing.

</div>

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_step-6e-select-the-top-edge"
class="section">

### Step 6e: Select the top Edge

The last sub-step is to select the top perimeter edge, the one with the
greatest Z value which we’ll do with the
<span class="pre">`sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]`</span> method just like Step
3b - note that these methods work on all Shape objects (Edges, Wires,
Faces, Solids, and Compounds) - with:
<span class="pre">`example.edges().filter_by(GeomType.CIRCLE).sort_by(SortBy.RADIUS)[-2:].sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]`</span>.

</div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_selectors.xhtml_conclusion" class="section">

## Conclusion

By using selectors as we have in this example we’ve used methods of
identifying features that are robust to features changing within the
part. We’ve also avoided the classic CAD “Topological naming problem” by
never referring to features with names or tags that could become
obsolete as the part changes.

When possible, avoid using static list indices to refer to features
extracted from methods like <span class="pre">`edges()`</span> as the
order within the list is not guaranteed to remain the same.

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<span id="tutorial_lego.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="tutorial_lego.xhtml_lego-tutorial" class="section">

# Lego Tutorial

This tutorial provides a step by step guide to creating a script to
build a parametric Lego block as shown here:

<img src="_images/lego.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/lego.svg" />

<div id="tutorial_lego.xhtml_step-1-setup" class="section">

## Step 1: Setup

Before getting to the CAD operations, this Lego script needs to import
the build123d environment. There are over 100 python classes in
build123d so we’ll just import them all with a
<span class="pre">`from`</span>` `<span class="pre">`build123d`</span>` `<span class="pre">`import`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>
but <a href="#tips.xhtml_are-glob-imports-bad-practice"
class="reference internal"><span class="std std-ref">there are other
options</span></a> that we won’t explore here.

The dimensions of the Lego block follow. A key parameter is
<span class="pre">`pip_count`</span>, the length of the Lego blocks in
pips. This parameter must be at least 2.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *
    from ocp_vscode import show_object
    pip_count = 6

    lego_unit_size = 8
    pip_height = 1.8
    pip_diameter = 4.8
    block_length = lego_unit_size * pip_count
    block_width = 16
    base_height = 9.6
    block_height = base_height + pip_height
    support_outer_diameter = 6.5
    support_inner_diameter = 4.8
    ridge_width = 0.6
    ridge_depth = 0.3
    wall_thickness = 1.2

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_lego.xhtml_step-2-part-builder" class="section">

## Step 2: Part Builder

The Lego block will be created by the
<span class="pre">`BuildPart`</span> builder as it’s a discrete three
dimensional part; therefore, we’ll instantiate a
<span class="pre">`BuildPart`</span> with the name
<span class="pre">`lego`</span>.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as lego:

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_lego.xhtml_step-3-sketch-builder" class="section">

## Step 3: Sketch Builder

Lego blocks have quite a bit of internal structure. To create this
structure we’ll draw a two dimensional sketch that will later be
extruded into a three dimensional object. As this sketch will be part of
the lego part, we’ll create a sketch builder in the context of the part
builder as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as lego:
        # Draw the bottom of the block
        with BuildSketch() as plan:

</div>

</div>

Note that builder instance names are optional - we’ll use
<span class="pre">`plan`</span> to reference the sketch. Also note that
all sketch objects are filled or 2D faces not just perimeter lines.

</div>

<div id="tutorial_lego.xhtml_step-4-perimeter-rectangle"
class="section">

## Step 4: Perimeter Rectangle

The first object in the sketch is going to be a rectangle with the
dimensions of the outside of the Lego block. The following step is going
to refer to this rectangle, so it will be assigned the identifier
<span class="pre">`perimeter`</span>.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as lego:
        # Draw the bottom of the block
        with BuildSketch() as plan:
            # Start with a Rectangle the size of the block
            perimeter = Rectangle(width=block_length, height=block_width)

</div>

</div>

Once the <span class="pre">`Rectangle`</span> object is created the
sketch appears as follows:

<img src="_images/lego_step4.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/lego_step4.svg" />

</div>

<div id="tutorial_lego.xhtml_step-5-offset-to-create-walls"
class="section">

## Step 5: Offset to Create Walls

To create the walls of the block the rectangle that we’ve created needs
to be hollowed out. This will be done with the
<span class="pre">`Offset`</span> operation which is going to create a
new object from <span class="pre">`perimeter`</span>.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as lego:
        # Draw the bottom of the block
        with BuildSketch() as plan:
            # Start with a Rectangle the size of the block
            perimeter = Rectangle(width=block_length, height=block_width)
            # Subtract an offset to create the block walls
            offset(
                perimeter,
                -wall_thickness,
                kind=Kind.INTERSECTION,
                mode=Mode.SUBTRACT,
            )

</div>

</div>

The first parameter to <span class="pre">`Offset`</span> is the
reference object. The <span class="pre">`amount`</span> is a negative
value to indicate that the offset should be internal. The
<span class="pre">`kind`</span> parameter controls the shape of the
corners - <span class="pre">`Kind.INTERSECTION`</span> will create
square corners. Finally, the <span class="pre">`mode`</span> parameter
controls how this object will be placed in the sketch - in this case
subtracted from the existing sketch. The result is shown here:

<img src="_images/lego_step5.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/lego_step5.svg" />

Now the sketch consists of a hollow rectangle.

</div>

<div id="tutorial_lego.xhtml_step-6-create-internal-grid"
class="section">

## Step 6: Create Internal Grid

The interior of the Lego block has small ridges on all four internal
walls. These ridges will be created as a grid of thin rectangles so the
positions of the centers of these rectangles need to be defined. A pair
of <span class="pre">`GridLocations`</span> location contexts will
define these positions, one for the horizontal bars and one for the
vertical bars. As the <span class="pre">`Rectangle`</span> objects are
in the scope of a location context
(<span class="pre">`GridLocations`</span> in this case) that defined
multiple points, multiple rectangles are created.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as lego:
        # Draw the bottom of the block
        with BuildSketch() as plan:
            # Start with a Rectangle the size of the block
            perimeter = Rectangle(width=block_length, height=block_width)
            # Subtract an offset to create the block walls
            offset(
                perimeter,
                -wall_thickness,
                kind=Kind.INTERSECTION,
                mode=Mode.SUBTRACT,
            )
            # Add a grid of lengthwise and widthwise bars
            with GridLocations(x_spacing=0, y_spacing=lego_unit_size, x_count=1, y_count=2):
                Rectangle(width=block_length, height=ridge_width)
            with GridLocations(lego_unit_size, 0, pip_count, 1):
                Rectangle(width=ridge_width, height=block_width)

</div>

</div>

Here we can see that the first <span class="pre">`GridLocations`</span>
creates two positions which causes two horizontal rectangles to be
created. The second <span class="pre">`GridLocations`</span> works in
the same way but creates <span class="pre">`pip_count`</span> positions
and therefore <span class="pre">`pip_count`</span> rectangles. Note that
keyword parameter are optional in this case.

The result looks like this:

<img src="_images/lego_step6.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/lego_step6.svg" />

</div>

<div id="tutorial_lego.xhtml_step-7-create-ridges" class="section">

## Step 7: Create Ridges

To convert the internal grid to ridges, the center needs to be removed.
This will be done with another <span class="pre">`Rectangle`</span>.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as lego:
        # Draw the bottom of the block
        with BuildSketch() as plan:
            # Start with a Rectangle the size of the block
            perimeter = Rectangle(width=block_length, height=block_width)
            # Subtract an offset to create the block walls
            offset(
                perimeter,
                -wall_thickness,
                kind=Kind.INTERSECTION,
                mode=Mode.SUBTRACT,
            )
            # Add a grid of lengthwise and widthwise bars
            with GridLocations(x_spacing=0, y_spacing=lego_unit_size, x_count=1, y_count=2):
                Rectangle(width=block_length, height=ridge_width)
            with GridLocations(lego_unit_size, 0, pip_count, 1):
                Rectangle(width=ridge_width, height=block_width)
            # Subtract a rectangle leaving ribs on the block walls
            Rectangle(
                block_length - 2 * (wall_thickness + ridge_depth),
                block_width - 2 * (wall_thickness + ridge_depth),
                mode=Mode.SUBTRACT,
            )

</div>

</div>

The <span class="pre">`Rectangle`</span> is subtracted from the sketch
to leave the ridges as follows:

<img src="_images/lego_step7.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/lego_step7.svg" />

</div>

<div id="tutorial_lego.xhtml_step-8-hollow-circles" class="section">

## Step 8: Hollow Circles

Lego blocks use a set of internal hollow cylinders that the pips push
against to hold two blocks together. These will be created with
<span class="pre">`Circle`</span>.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as lego:
        # Draw the bottom of the block
        with BuildSketch() as plan:
            # Start with a Rectangle the size of the block
            perimeter = Rectangle(width=block_length, height=block_width)
            # Subtract an offset to create the block walls
            offset(
                perimeter,
                -wall_thickness,
                kind=Kind.INTERSECTION,
                mode=Mode.SUBTRACT,
            )
            # Add a grid of lengthwise and widthwise bars
            with GridLocations(x_spacing=0, y_spacing=lego_unit_size, x_count=1, y_count=2):
                Rectangle(width=block_length, height=ridge_width)
            with GridLocations(lego_unit_size, 0, pip_count, 1):
                Rectangle(width=ridge_width, height=block_width)
            # Subtract a rectangle leaving ribs on the block walls
            Rectangle(
                block_length - 2 * (wall_thickness + ridge_depth),
                block_width - 2 * (wall_thickness + ridge_depth),
                mode=Mode.SUBTRACT,
            )
            # Add a row of hollow circles to the center
            with GridLocations(
                x_spacing=lego_unit_size, y_spacing=0, x_count=pip_count - 1, y_count=1
            ):
                Circle(radius=support_outer_diameter / 2)
                Circle(radius=support_inner_diameter / 2, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)

</div>

</div>

Here another <span class="pre">`GridLocations`</span> is used to
position the centers of the circles. Note that since both
<span class="pre">`Circle`</span> objects are in the scope of the
location context, both Circles will be positioned at these locations.

Once the Circles are added, the sketch is complete and looks as follows:

<img src="_images/lego_step8.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/lego_step8.svg" />

</div>

<div id="tutorial_lego.xhtml_step-9-extruding-sketch-into-walls"
class="section">

## Step 9: Extruding Sketch into Walls

Now that the sketch is complete it needs to be extruded into the three
dimensional wall object.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as lego:
        # Draw the bottom of the block
        with BuildSketch() as plan:
            # Start with a Rectangle the size of the block
            perimeter = Rectangle(width=block_length, height=block_width)
            # Subtract an offset to create the block walls
            offset(
                perimeter,
                -wall_thickness,
                kind=Kind.INTERSECTION,
                mode=Mode.SUBTRACT,
            )
            # Add a grid of lengthwise and widthwise bars
            with GridLocations(x_spacing=0, y_spacing=lego_unit_size, x_count=1, y_count=2):
                Rectangle(width=block_length, height=ridge_width)
            with GridLocations(lego_unit_size, 0, pip_count, 1):
                Rectangle(width=ridge_width, height=block_width)
            # Subtract a rectangle leaving ribs on the block walls
            Rectangle(
                block_length - 2 * (wall_thickness + ridge_depth),
                block_width - 2 * (wall_thickness + ridge_depth),
                mode=Mode.SUBTRACT,
            )
            # Add a row of hollow circles to the center
            with GridLocations(
                x_spacing=lego_unit_size, y_spacing=0, x_count=pip_count - 1, y_count=1
            ):
                Circle(radius=support_outer_diameter / 2)
                Circle(radius=support_inner_diameter / 2, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
        # Extrude this base sketch to the height of the walls
        extrude(amount=base_height - wall_thickness)

</div>

</div>

Note how the <span class="pre">`Extrude`</span> operation is no longer
in the <span class="pre">`BuildSketch`</span> scope and has returned
back into the <span class="pre">`BuildPart`</span> scope. This causes
<span class="pre">`BuildSketch`</span> to exit and transfer the sketch
that we’ve created to <span class="pre">`BuildPart`</span> for further
processing by <span class="pre">`Extrude`</span>.

The result is:

<img src="_images/lego_step9.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/lego_step9.svg" />

</div>

<div id="tutorial_lego.xhtml_step-10-adding-a-top" class="section">

## Step 10: Adding a Top

Now that the walls are complete, the top of the block needs to be added.
Although this could be done with another sketch, we’ll add a box to the
top of the walls.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as lego:
        # Draw the bottom of the block
        with BuildSketch() as plan:
            # Start with a Rectangle the size of the block
            perimeter = Rectangle(width=block_length, height=block_width)
            # Subtract an offset to create the block walls
            offset(
                perimeter,
                -wall_thickness,
                kind=Kind.INTERSECTION,
                mode=Mode.SUBTRACT,
            )
            # Add a grid of lengthwise and widthwise bars
            with GridLocations(x_spacing=0, y_spacing=lego_unit_size, x_count=1, y_count=2):
                Rectangle(width=block_length, height=ridge_width)
            with GridLocations(lego_unit_size, 0, pip_count, 1):
                Rectangle(width=ridge_width, height=block_width)
            # Subtract a rectangle leaving ribs on the block walls
            Rectangle(
                block_length - 2 * (wall_thickness + ridge_depth),
                block_width - 2 * (wall_thickness + ridge_depth),
                mode=Mode.SUBTRACT,
            )
            # Add a row of hollow circles to the center
            with GridLocations(
                x_spacing=lego_unit_size, y_spacing=0, x_count=pip_count - 1, y_count=1
            ):
                Circle(radius=support_outer_diameter / 2)
                Circle(radius=support_inner_diameter / 2, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
        # Extrude this base sketch to the height of the walls
        extrude(amount=base_height - wall_thickness)
        # Create a box on the top of the walls
        with Locations((0, 0, lego.vertices().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1].Z)):
            # Create the top of the block
            Box(
                length=block_length,
                width=block_width,
                height=wall_thickness,
                align=(Align.CENTER, Align.CENTER, Align.MIN),
            )

</div>

</div>

To position the top, we’ll describe the top center of the lego walls
with a <span class="pre">`Locations`</span> context. To determine the
height we’ll extract that from the <span class="pre">`lego.part`</span>
by using the <span class="pre">`vertices()`</span> method which returns
a list of the positions of all of the vertices of the Lego block so far.
Since we’re interested in the top, we’ll sort by the vertical (Z) axis
and take the top of the list
<span class="pre">`sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]`</span>. Finally, the
<span class="pre">`Z`</span> property of this vertex will return just
the height of the top. Note that the <span class="pre">`X`</span> and
<span class="pre">`Y`</span> values are not used from the selected
vertex as there are no vertices in the center of the block.

Within the scope of this <span class="pre">`Locations`</span> context, a
<span class="pre">`Box`</span> is created, centered at the intersection
of the x and y axis but not in the z thus aligning with the top of the
walls.

The base is closed now as shown here:

<img src="_images/lego_step10.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/lego_step10.svg" />

</div>

<div id="tutorial_lego.xhtml_step-11-adding-pips" class="section">

## Step 11: Adding Pips

The final step is to add the pips to the top of the Lego block. To do
this we’ll create a new workplane on top of the block where we can
position the pips.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as lego:
        # Draw the bottom of the block
        with BuildSketch() as plan:
            # Start with a Rectangle the size of the block
            perimeter = Rectangle(width=block_length, height=block_width)
            # Subtract an offset to create the block walls
            offset(
                perimeter,
                -wall_thickness,
                kind=Kind.INTERSECTION,
                mode=Mode.SUBTRACT,
            )
            # Add a grid of lengthwise and widthwise bars
            with GridLocations(x_spacing=0, y_spacing=lego_unit_size, x_count=1, y_count=2):
                Rectangle(width=block_length, height=ridge_width)
            with GridLocations(lego_unit_size, 0, pip_count, 1):
                Rectangle(width=ridge_width, height=block_width)
            # Subtract a rectangle leaving ribs on the block walls
            Rectangle(
                block_length - 2 * (wall_thickness + ridge_depth),
                block_width - 2 * (wall_thickness + ridge_depth),
                mode=Mode.SUBTRACT,
            )
            # Add a row of hollow circles to the center
            with GridLocations(
                x_spacing=lego_unit_size, y_spacing=0, x_count=pip_count - 1, y_count=1
            ):
                Circle(radius=support_outer_diameter / 2)
                Circle(radius=support_inner_diameter / 2, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
        # Extrude this base sketch to the height of the walls
        extrude(amount=base_height - wall_thickness)
        # Create a box on the top of the walls
        with Locations((0, 0, lego.vertices().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1].Z)):
            # Create the top of the block
            Box(
                length=block_length,
                width=block_width,
                height=wall_thickness,
                align=(Align.CENTER, Align.CENTER, Align.MIN),
            )
        # Create a workplane on the top of the block
        with BuildPart(lego.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]):
            # Create a grid of pips
            with GridLocations(lego_unit_size, lego_unit_size, pip_count, 2):
                Cylinder(
                    radius=pip_diameter / 2,
                    height=pip_height,
                    align=(Align.CENTER, Align.CENTER, Align.MIN),
                )

</div>

</div>

In this case, the workplane is created from the top Face of the Lego
block by using the <span class="pre">`faces`</span> method and then
sorted vertically and taking the top one
<span class="pre">`sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]`</span>.

On the new workplane, a grid of locations is created and a number of
<span class="pre">`Cylinder`</span>’s are positioned at each location.

<img src="_images/lego.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/lego.svg" />

This completes the Lego block. To access the finished product, refer to
the builder’s internal object as shown here:

| Builder     | Object |
|-------------|--------|
| BuildLine   | line   |
| BuildSketch | sketch |
| BuildPart   | part   |

so in this case the Lego block is <span class="pre">`lego.part`</span>.
To display the part use
<span class="pre">`show_object(lego.part)`</span> or
<span class="pre">`show(lego.part)`</span> depending on the viewer. The
part could also be exported to a STL or STEP file by referencing
<span class="pre">`lego.part`</span>.

<div class="admonition note">

Note

Viewers that don’t directly support build123d my require a raw
OpenCascade object. In this case, append
<span class="pre">`.wrapped`</span> to the object (e.g.)
<span class="pre">`show_object(lego.part.wrapped)`</span>.

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<span id="tutorial_joints.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_joint-tutorial" class="section">

<span id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_id1"></span>

# Joint Tutorial

This tutorial provides a step by step guide in using
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Joint"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Joint"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Joint</code></span></a>’s
as we create a box with a hinged lid to illustrate the use of three
different <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Joint"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Joint"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Joint</code></span></a>
types.

<img src="_images/tutorial_joint.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/tutorial_joint.svg" />

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-1-setup" class="section">

## Step 1: Setup

Before getting to the CAD operations, this selector script needs to
import the build123d environment.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *
    from ocp_vscode import *

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-2-create-hinge" class="section">

## Step 2: Create Hinge

This example uses a common Butt Hinge to connect the lid to the box base
so a <span class="pre">`Hinge`</span> class is used to create that can
create either of the two hinge leaves. As the focus of this tutorial is
the joints and not the CAD operations to create objects, this code is
not described in detail.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    class Hinge(Compound):
        """Hinge

        Half a simple hinge with several joints. The joints are:
        - "leaf": RigidJoint where hinge attaches to object
        - "hinge_axis": RigidJoint (inner) or RevoluteJoint (outer)
        - "hole0", "hole1", "hole2": CylindricalJoints for attachment screws

        Args:
            width (float): width of one leaf
            length (float): hinge length
            barrel_diameter (float): size of hinge pin barrel
            thickness (float): hinge leaf thickness
            pin_diameter (float): hinge pin diameter
            inner (bool, optional): inner or outer half of hinge . Defaults to True.
        """

        def __init__(
            self,
            width: float,
            length: float,
            barrel_diameter: float,
            thickness: float,
            pin_diameter: float,
            inner: bool = True,
        ):
            # The profile of the hinge used to create the tabs
            with BuildPart() as hinge_profile:
                with BuildSketch():
                    for i, loc in enumerate(
                        GridLocations(0, length / 5, 1, 5, align=(Align.MIN, Align.MIN))
                    ):
                        if i % 2 == inner:
                            with Locations(loc):
                                Rectangle(width, length / 5, align=(Align.MIN, Align.MIN))
                    Rectangle(
                        width - barrel_diameter,
                        length,
                        align=(Align.MIN, Align.MIN),
                    )
                extrude(amount=-barrel_diameter)

            # The hinge pin
            with BuildPart() as pin:
                Cylinder(
                    radius=pin_diameter / 2,
                    height=length,
                    align=(Align.CENTER, Align.CENTER, Align.MIN),
                )
                with BuildPart(pin.part.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]) as pin_head:
                    Cylinder(
                        radius=barrel_diameter / 2,
                        height=pin_diameter,
                        align=(Align.CENTER, Align.CENTER, Align.MIN),
                    )
                fillet(
                    pin_head.edges(Select.LAST).filter_by(GeomType.CIRCLE),
                    radius=pin_diameter / 3,
                )

            # Either the external and internal leaf with joints
            with BuildPart() as leaf_builder:
                with BuildSketch():
                    with BuildLine():
                        l1 = Line((0, 0), (width - barrel_diameter / 2, 0))
                        l2 = RadiusArc(
                            l1 @ 1,
                            l1 @ 1 + Vector(0, barrel_diameter),
                            -barrel_diameter / 2,
                        )
                        l3 = RadiusArc(
                            l2 @ 1,
                            (
                                width - barrel_diameter,
                                barrel_diameter / 2,
                            ),
                            -barrel_diameter / 2,
                        )
                        l4 = Line(l3 @ 1, (width - barrel_diameter, thickness))
                        l5 = Line(l4 @ 1, (0, thickness))
                        Line(l5 @ 1, l1 @ 0)
                    make_face()
                    with Locations(
                        (width - barrel_diameter / 2, barrel_diameter / 2)
                    ) as pin_center:
                        Circle(pin_diameter / 2 + 0.1 * MM, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
                extrude(amount=length)
                add(hinge_profile.part, rotation=(90, 0, 0), mode=Mode.INTERSECT)

                # Create holes for fasteners
                with Locations(leaf_builder.part.faces().filter_by(Axis.Y)[-1]):
                    with GridLocations(0, length / 3, 1, 3):
                        holes = CounterSinkHole(3 * MM, 5 * MM)
                # Add the hinge pin to the external leaf
                if not inner:
                    with Locations(pin_center.locations[0]):
                        add(pin.part)

</div>

</div>

Once the two leaves have been created they will look as follows:

<img src="_images/tutorial_joint_outer_leaf.svg" style="width: 40%;"
alt="_images/tutorial_joint_outer_leaf.svg" />
<img src="_images/tutorial_joint_inner_leaf.svg" style="width: 40%;"
alt="_images/tutorial_joint_inner_leaf.svg" />

Note that the XYZ indicators and a circle around the hinge pin indicate
joints that are discussed below.

</div>

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-3-add-joints-to-the-hinge-leaf"
class="section">

## Step 3: Add Joints to the Hinge Leaf

The hinge includes five joints:

- A <span class="pre">`RigidJoint`</span> to attach the leaf

- A <span class="pre">`RigidJoint`</span> or
  <span class="pre">`RevoluteJoint`</span> as the hinge Axis

- Three <span class="pre">`CylindricalJoint`</span>’s for the
  countersunk screws

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-3a-leaf-joint" class="section">

### Step 3a: Leaf Joint

The first joint to add is a <span class="pre">`RigidJoint`</span> that
is used to fix the hinge leaf to the box or lid.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

                #
                # Leaf attachment
                RigidJoint(
                    label="leaf",
                    joint_location=Location(
                        (width - barrel_diameter, 0, length / 2), (90, 0, 0)
                    ),
                )

</div>

</div>

Each joint has a label which identifies it - here the string “leaf” is
used, the <span class="pre">`to_part`</span> binds the joint to
<span class="pre">`leaf_builder.part`</span> (i.e. the part being
built), and <span class="pre">`joint_location`</span> is specified as
middle of the leaf along the edge of the pin. Note that
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Location"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Location"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Location</code></span></a>
objects describe both a position and orientation which is why there are
two tuples (the orientation listed is rotate about the X axis 90
degrees).

</div>

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-3b-hinge-joint" class="section">

### Step 3b: Hinge Joint

The second joint to add is either a
<span class="pre">`RigidJoint`</span> (on the inner leaf) or a
<span class="pre">`RevoluteJoint`</span> (on the outer leaf) that
describes the hinge axis.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

                #
                # Leaf attachment
                RigidJoint(
                    label="leaf",
                    joint_location=Location(
                        (width - barrel_diameter, 0, length / 2), (90, 0, 0)
                    ),
                )
                # [Hinge Axis] (fixed with inner)
                if inner:
                    RigidJoint(
                        "hinge_axis",
                        joint_location=Location(
                            (width - barrel_diameter / 2, barrel_diameter / 2, 0)
                        ),
                    )
                else:
                    RevoluteJoint(
                        "hinge_axis",
                        axis=Axis(
                            (width - barrel_diameter / 2, barrel_diameter / 2, 0), (0, 0, 1)
                        ),
                        angular_range=(90, 270),
                    )

</div>

</div>

The inner leaf just pivots around the outer leaf and therefore the
simple <span class="pre">`RigidJoint`</span> is used to define the
Location of this pivot. The outer leaf contains the more complex
<span class="pre">`RevoluteJoint`</span> which defines an axis of
rotation and angular limits to that rotation (90 and 270 in this example
as the two leaves will interfere with each other outside of this range).
Note that the maximum angle must be greater than the minimum angle and
therefore may be greater than 360°. Other types of joints have linear
ranges as well as angular ranges.

</div>

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-3c-fastener-joints" class="section">

### Step 3c: Fastener Joints

The third set of joints to add are
<span class="pre">`CylindricalJoint`</span>’s that describe how the
countersunk screws used to attach the leaves move.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

                hole_locations = [hole.location for hole in holes]
                for hole, hole_location in enumerate(hole_locations):
                    CylindricalJoint(
                        label="hole" + str(hole),
                        axis=Axis(hole_location),
                        linear_range=(-2 * CM, 2 * CM),
                        angular_range=(0, 360),
                    )

</div>

</div>

Much like the <span class="pre">`RevoluteJoint`</span>, a
<span class="pre">`CylindricalJoint`</span> has an Axis of motion but
this type of joint allows both movement around and along this axis -
exactly as a screw would move. Here is the Axis is setup such that a
position of 0 aligns with the screw being fully set in the hole and
positive numbers indicate the distance the head of the screw is above
the leaf surface. One could have reversed the direction of the Axis such
that negative position values would correspond to a screw now fully in
the hole - whatever makes sense to the situation. The angular range of
this joint is set to (0°, 360°) as there is no limit to the angular
rotation of the screw (one could choose to model thread pitch and
calculate position from angle or vice-versa).

</div>

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-3d-call-super" class="section">

### Step 3d: Call Super

To finish off, the base class for the Hinge class is initialized:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

            super().__init__(leaf_builder.part.wrapped, joints=leaf_builder.part.joints)

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-3e-instantiate-hinge-leaves"
class="section">

### Step 3e: Instantiate Hinge Leaves

Now that the Hinge class is complete it can be used to instantiate the
two hinge leaves required to attach the box and lid together.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    hinge_inner = Hinge(
        width=5 * CM,
        length=12 * CM,
        barrel_diameter=1 * CM,
        thickness=2 * MM,
        pin_diameter=4 * MM,
    )
    hinge_outer = Hinge(
        width=5 * CM,
        length=12 * CM,
        barrel_diameter=1 * CM,
        thickness=2 * MM,
        pin_diameter=4 * MM,
        inner=False,
    )

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-4-create-the-box" class="section">

## Step 4: Create the Box

The box is created with <a href="#build_part.xhtml_build_part.BuildPart"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_part.BuildPart"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">BuildPart</code></span></a>
as a simple object - as shown below - let’s focus on the joint used to
attach the outer hinge leaf.

<img src="_images/tutorial_joint_box.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/tutorial_joint_box.svg" />

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as box_builder:
        box = Box(30 * CM, 30 * CM, 10 * CM)
        offset(amount=-1 * CM, openings=box_builder.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1])
        # Create a notch for the hinge
        with Locations((-15 * CM, 0, 5 * CM)):
            Box(2 * CM, 12 * CM, 4 * MM, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
        bbox = box.bounding_box()
        with Locations(
            Plane(origin=(bbox.min.X, 0, bbox.max.Z - 30 * MM), z_dir=(-1, 0, 0))
        ):
            with GridLocations(0, 40 * MM, 1, 3):
                Hole(3 * MM, 1 * CM)
        RigidJoint(
            "hinge_attachment",
            joint_location=Location((-15 * CM, 0, 4 * CM), (180, 90, 0)),
        )

</div>

</div>

Since the hinge will be fixed to the box another
<span class="pre">`RigidJoint`</span> is used mark where the hinge will
go. Note that the orientation of this
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Joint"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Joint"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Joint</code></span></a>
will control how the hinge leaf is attached and is independent of the
orientation of the hinge as it was constructed.

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-4a-relocate-box" class="section">

### Step 4a: Relocate Box

Note that the position and orientation of the box’s joints are given as
a global <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Location"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Location"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Location</code></span></a>
when created but will be translated to a relative
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Location"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Location"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Location</code></span></a>
internally to allow the
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Joint"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Joint"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Joint</code></span></a>
to “move” with the parent object. This allows users the freedom to
relocate objects without having to recreate or modify
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Joint"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Joint"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Joint</code></span></a>’s.
Here is the box is moved upwards to show this property.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    box = box_builder.part.moved(Location((0, 0, 5 * CM)))

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-5-create-the-lid" class="section">

## Step 5: Create the Lid

Much like the box, the lid is created in a
<a href="#build_part.xhtml_build_part.BuildPart"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_part.BuildPart"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">BuildPart</code></span></a>
context and is assigned a <span class="pre">`RigidJoint`</span>.

<img src="_images/tutorial_joint_lid.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/tutorial_joint_lid.svg" />

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as lid_builder:
        Box(30 * CM, 30 * CM, 1 * CM, align=(Align.MIN, Align.CENTER, Align.MIN))
        with Locations((2 * CM, 0, 0)):
            with GridLocations(0, 40 * MM, 1, 3):
                Hole(3 * MM, 1 * CM)
        RigidJoint(
            "hinge_attachment",
            joint_location=Location((0, 0, 0), (0, 0, 180)),
        )
    lid = lid_builder.part

</div>

</div>

Again, the original orientation of the lid and hinge inner leaf are not
important, when the joints are connected together the parts will move
into the correct position.

</div>

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-6-import-a-screw-and-bind-a-joint-to-it"
class="section">

## Step 6: Import a Screw and bind a Joint to it

<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Joint"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Joint"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Joint</code></span></a>’s
can be bound to simple objects the a
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Compound"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Compound"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Compound</code></span></a>
imported - in this case a screw.

- screw STEP model:
  <span class="pre">`M6-1x12-countersunk-screw.step`</span>

<img src="_images/tutorial_joint_m6_screw.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/tutorial_joint_m6_screw.svg" />

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    m6_screw = import_step("M6-1x12-countersunk-screw.step")
    m6_joint = RigidJoint("head", m6_screw, Location((0, 0, 0), (0, 0, 0)))

</div>

</div>

Here a simple <span class="pre">`RigidJoint`</span> is bound to the top
of the screw head such that it can be connected to the hinge’s
<span class="pre">`CylindricalJoint`</span>.

</div>

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-7-connect-the-joints-together"
class="section">

## Step 7: Connect the Joints together

This last step is the most interesting. Now that all of the joints have
been defined and bound to their parent objects, they can be connected
together.

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-7a-hinge-to-box" class="section">

### Step 7a: Hinge to Box

To start, the outer hinge leaf will be connected to the box, as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    box.joints["hinge_attachment"].connect_to(hinge_outer.joints["leaf"])

</div>

</div>

Here the <span class="pre">`hinge_attachment`</span> joint of the
<span class="pre">`box`</span> is connected to the
<span class="pre">`leaf`</span> joint of
<span class="pre">`hinge_outer`</span>. Note that the hinge leaf is the
object to move. Once this line is executed, we get the following:

<img src="_images/tutorial_joint_box_outer.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/tutorial_joint_box_outer.svg" />

</div>

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-7b-hinge-to-hinge" class="section">

### Step 7b: Hinge to Hinge

Next, the hinge inner leaf is connected to the hinge outer leaf which is
attached to the box.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    hinge_outer.joints["hinge_axis"].connect_to(hinge_inner.joints["hinge_axis"], angle=120)

</div>

</div>

As <span class="pre">`hinge_outer.joints["hinge_axis"]`</span> is a
<span class="pre">`RevoluteJoint`</span> there is an
<span class="pre">`angle`</span> parameter that can be set (angles
default to the minimum range value) - here to 120°. This is what that
looks like:

<img src="_images/tutorial_joint_box_outer_inner.svg"
class="align-center" alt="_images/tutorial_joint_box_outer_inner.svg" />

</div>

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-7c-lid-to-hinge" class="section">

### Step 7c: Lid to Hinge

Now the <span class="pre">`lid`</span> is connected to the
<span class="pre">`hinge_inner`</span>:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    hinge_inner.joints["leaf"].connect_to(lid.joints["hinge_attachment"])

</div>

</div>

which results in:

<img src="_images/tutorial_joint_box_outer_inner_lid.svg"
class="align-center"
alt="_images/tutorial_joint_box_outer_inner_lid.svg" />

Note how the lid is now in an open position. To close the lid just
change the above <span class="pre">`angle`</span> parameter from 120° to
90°.

</div>

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_step-7d-screw-to-hinge" class="section">

### Step 7d: Screw to Hinge

The last step in this example is to place a screw in one of the hinges:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    hinge_outer.joints["hole2"].connect_to(m6_joint, position=5 * MM, angle=30)

</div>

</div>

As the position is a positive number the screw is still proud of the
hinge face as shown here:

<img src="_images/tutorial_joint.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/tutorial_joint.svg" />

Try changing these position and angle values to “tighten” the screw.

</div>

</div>

<div id="tutorial_joints.xhtml_conclusion" class="section">

## Conclusion

Use a <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Joint"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Joint"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Joint</code></span></a>
to locate two objects relative to each other with some degree of motion.
Keep in mind that when using the <span class="pre">`connect_to`</span>
method, <span class="pre">`self`</span> is always fixed and
<span class="pre">`other`</span> will move to the appropriate
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Location"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Location"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Location</code></span></a>.

<div class="admonition note">

Note

The joint symbols can be displayed as follows (your viewer may use
<span class="pre">`show`</span> instead of
<span class="pre">`show_object`</span>):

<div class="highlight-python notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    show_object(box.joints["hinge_attachment"].symbol, name="box attachment point")

</div>

</div>

or

<div class="highlight-python notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    show_object(m6_joint.symbol, name="m6 screw symbol")

</div>

</div>

or, with the ocp_vscode viewer

<div class="highlight-python notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    show(box, render_joints=True)

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<div id="examples_1.xhtml_benchy" class="section">

<span id="examples_1.xhtml_examples-benchy"></span>

## Benchy

<img src="_images/example_benchy_01.png" class="align-center"
alt="_images/example_benchy_01.png" />

The Benchy examples shows how to import a STL model as a
<cite>Solid</cite> object with the class <cite>Mesher</cite> and modify
it by replacing chimney with a BREP version.

- Benchy STL model: <span class="pre">`low_poly_benchy.stl`</span>

<details class="sd-sphinx-override sd-dropdown sd-card sd-mb-3">

<summary class="sd-summary-title sd-card-header">

<span class="sd-summary-text">Gallery</span>
<span class="sd-summary-state-marker sd-summary-chevron-right">

<svg version="1.1" width="1.5em" height="1.5em" class="sd-octicon sd-octicon-chevron-right" viewbox="0 0 24 24" aria-hidden="true">

<path d="M8.72 18.78a.75.75 0 0 1 0-1.06L14.44 12 8.72 6.28a.751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018l6.25 6.25a.75.75 0 0 1 0 1.06l-6.25 6.25a.75.75 0 0 1-1.06 0Z"></path>
</svg>

</span>
</summary>

<div class="sd-summary-content sd-card-body docutils">

<img src="_images/example_benchy_02.png" class="align-center"
alt="_images/example_benchy_02.png" />
<img src="_images/example_benchy_03.png" class="align-center"
alt="_images/example_benchy_03.png" />

</div>

</details>

<details class="sd-sphinx-override sd-dropdown sd-card sd-mb-3">

<summary class="sd-summary-title sd-card-header">

<span class="sd-summary-text">🔨 Reference Implementation (Builder
Mode)</span>
<span class="sd-summary-state-marker sd-summary-chevron-right">

<svg version="1.1" width="1.5em" height="1.5em" class="sd-octicon sd-octicon-chevron-right" viewbox="0 0 24 24" aria-hidden="true">

<path d="M8.72 18.78a.75.75 0 0 1 0-1.06L14.44 12 8.72 6.28a.751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018l6.25 6.25a.75.75 0 0 1 0 1.06l-6.25 6.25a.75.75 0 0 1-1.06 0Z"></path>
</svg>

</span>
</summary>

<div class="sd-summary-content sd-card-body docutils">

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    # Import the benchy as a Solid model
    importer = Mesher()
    benchy_stl = importer.read("low_poly_benchy.stl")[0]

    with BuildPart() as benchy:
        add(benchy_stl)

        # Determine the plane that defines the top of the roof
        vertices = benchy.vertices()
        roof_vertices = vertices.filter_by_position(Axis.Z, 38, 42)
        roof_plane_vertices = [
            roof_vertices.group_by(Axis.Y, tol_digits=2)[-1].sort_by(Axis.X)[0],
            roof_vertices.sort_by(Axis.Z)[0],
            roof_vertices.group_by(Axis.Y, tol_digits=2)[0].sort_by(Axis.X)[0],
        ]
        roof_plane = Plane(
            Face(Wire.make_polygon([v.to_tuple() for v in roof_plane_vertices]))
        )
        # Remove the faceted smoke stack
        split(bisect_by=roof_plane, keep=Keep.BOTTOM)

        # Determine the position and size of the smoke stack
        smoke_stack_vertices = vertices.group_by(Axis.Z, tol_digits=0)[-1]
        smoke_stack_center = sum(
            [Vector(v.X, v.Y, v.Z) for v in smoke_stack_vertices], Vector()
        ) * (1 / len(smoke_stack_vertices))
        smoke_stack_radius = max(
            [
                (Vector(*v.to_tuple()) - smoke_stack_center).length
                for v in smoke_stack_vertices
            ]
        )

        # Create the new smoke stack
        with BuildSketch(Plane(smoke_stack_center)):
            Circle(smoke_stack_radius)
            Circle(smoke_stack_radius - 2 * MM, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
        extrude(amount=-3 * MM)
        with BuildSketch(Plane(smoke_stack_center)):
            Circle(smoke_stack_radius - 0.5 * MM)
            Circle(smoke_stack_radius - 2 * MM, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
        extrude(amount=roof_plane_vertices[1].Z - smoke_stack_center.Z)

    show(benchy)
