<div id="filter_examples.xhtml_all-edges-circle" class="section">

<span id="filter_examples.xhtml_filter-all-edges-circle"></span>

## All Edges Circle

In this complete bearing block, we want to add joints for the bearings.
These should be located in the counterbore recess. One way to locate the
joints is by finding faces with centers located where the joints need to
be located. Filtering for faces with only circular edges selects the
counterbore faces that meet the joint criteria.

<details class="sd-sphinx-override sd-dropdown sd-card sd-mb-3">

<summary class="sd-summary-title sd-card-header">

<span class="sd-summary-text">Setup</span>
<span class="sd-summary-state-marker sd-summary-chevron-right">

<svg version="1.1" width="1.5em" height="1.5em" class="sd-octicon sd-octicon-chevron-right" viewbox="0 0 24 24" aria-hidden="true">

<path d="M8.72 18.78a.75.75 0 0 1 0-1.06L14.44 12 8.72 6.28a.751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018l6.25 6.25a.75.75 0 0 1 0 1.06l-6.25 6.25a.75.75 0 0 1-1.06 0Z"></path>
</svg>

</span>
</summary>

<div class="sd-summary-content sd-card-body docutils">

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *

    with BuildPart() as part:
        with BuildSketch() as s:
            Rectangle(115, 50)
            with Locations((5 / 2, 0)):
                SlotOverall(90, 12, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
        extrude(amount=15)

        with BuildSketch(Plane.XZ.offset(50 / 2)) as s3:
            with Locations((-115 / 2 + 26, 15)):
                SlotOverall(42 + 2 * 26 + 12, 2 * 26, rotation=90)
        zz = extrude(amount=-12)
        split(bisect_by=Plane.XY)
        edgs = part.part.edges().filter_by(Axis.Y).group_by(Axis.X)[-2]
        fillet(edgs, 9)

        with Locations(zz.faces().sort_by(Axis.Y)[0]):
            with Locations((42 / 2 + 6, 0)):
                CounterBoreHole(24 / 2, 34 / 2, 4)
        mirror(about=Plane.XZ)

        with BuildSketch() as s4:
            RectangleRounded(115, 50, 6)
        extrude(amount=80, mode=Mode.INTERSECT)
        # fillet does not work right, mode intersect is safer

        with BuildSketch(Plane.YZ) as s4:
            with BuildLine() as bl:
                l1 = Line((0, 0), (18 / 2, 0))
                l2 = PolarLine(l1 @ 1, 8, 60, length_mode=LengthMode.VERTICAL)
                l3 = Line(l2 @ 1, (0, 8))
                mirror(about=Plane.YZ)
            make_face()
        extrude(amount=115 / 2, both=True, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)

</div>

</div>

</div>

</details>

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

        faces = part.faces().filter_by(
            lambda f: all(e.geom_type == GeomType.CIRCLE for e in f.edges())
        )
        for i, f in enumerate(faces):
            RigidJoint(f"bearing_bore_{i}", joint_location=f.center_location)

</div>

</div>

<div id="filter_examples.xhtml_axis-and-plane" class="section">

<span id="filter_examples.xhtml_filter-axis-plane"></span>

## Axis and Plane

Filtering by an Axis will select faces perpendicular to the axis.
Likewise filtering by Plane will select faces parallel to the plane.

<details class="sd-sphinx-override sd-dropdown sd-card sd-mb-3">

<summary class="sd-summary-title sd-card-header">

<span class="sd-summary-text">Setup</span>
<span class="sd-summary-state-marker sd-summary-chevron-right">

<svg version="1.1" width="1.5em" height="1.5em" class="sd-octicon sd-octicon-chevron-right" viewbox="0 0 24 24" aria-hidden="true">

<path d="M8.72 18.78a.75.75 0 0 1 0-1.06L14.44 12 8.72 6.28a.751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018l6.25 6.25a.75.75 0 0 1 0 1.06l-6.25 6.25a.75.75 0 0 1-1.06 0Z"></path>
</svg>

</span>
</summary>

<div class="sd-summary-content sd-card-body docutils">

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *

    with BuildPart() as part:
        Box(1, 1, 1)

</div>

</div>

</div>

</details>

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    part.faces().filter_by(Axis.Z)
    part.faces().filter_by(Plane.XY)

</div>

</div>

<figure class="align-center">
<img src="_images/filter_axisplane.png"
alt="../_images/filter_axisplane.png" />
</figure>

<div class="line-block">

<div class="line">

\

</div>

</div>

It might be useful to filter by an Axis or Plane in other ways. A lambda
can be used to accomplish this with feature properties or methods. Here,
we are looking for faces where the dot product of face normal and either
the axis direction or the plane normal is about to 0. The result is
faces parallel to the axis or perpendicular to the plane.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    part.faces().filter_by(lambda f: abs(f.normal_at().dot(Axis.Z.direction) < 1e-6)
    part.faces().filter_by(lambda f: abs(f.normal_at().dot(Plane.XY.z_dir)) < 1e-6)

</div>

</div>

<figure class="align-center">
<img src="_images/filter_dot_axisplane.png"
alt="../_images/filter_dot_axisplane.png" />
</figure>

<div class="line-block">

<div class="line">

\

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="filter_examples.xhtml_inner-wire-count" class="section">

<span id="filter_examples.xhtml_filter-inner-wire-count"></span>

## Inner Wire Count

This motor bracket imported from a step file needs joints for adding to
an assembly. Joints for the M3 clearance holes were already found by
using the cylindrical face’s axis of rotation, but the motor bore and
slots need specific placement. The motor bore can be found by filtering
for faces with 5 inner wires, sorting for the desired face, and then
filtering for the specific inner wire by radius.

- bracket STEP model: <span class="pre">`nema-17-bracket.step`</span>

<details class="sd-sphinx-override sd-dropdown sd-card sd-mb-3">

<summary class="sd-summary-title sd-card-header">

<span class="sd-summary-text">Setup</span>
<span class="sd-summary-state-marker sd-summary-chevron-right">

<svg version="1.1" width="1.5em" height="1.5em" class="sd-octicon sd-octicon-chevron-right" viewbox="0 0 24 24" aria-hidden="true">

<path d="M8.72 18.78a.75.75 0 0 1 0-1.06L14.44 12 8.72 6.28a.751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018l6.25 6.25a.75.75 0 0 1 0 1.06l-6.25 6.25a.75.75 0 0 1-1.06 0Z"></path>
</svg>

</span>
</summary>

<div class="sd-summary-content sd-card-body docutils">

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *

    bracket = import_step(os.path.join(working_path, "nema-17-bracket.step"))
    faces = bracket.faces()

    motor_mounts = faces.filter_by(GeomType.CYLINDER).filter_by(lambda f: f.radius == 3.3/2)
    for i, f in enumerate(motor_mounts):
        location = f.axis_of_rotation.location
        RigidJoint(f"motor_m3_{i}", bracket, joint_location=location)

</div>

</div>

</div>

</details>

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    motor_face = faces.filter_by(lambda f: len(f.inner_wires()) == 5).sort_by(Axis.X)[-1]
    motor_bore = motor_face.inner_wires().edges().filter_by(lambda e: e.radius == 16).edge()
    location = Location(motor_bore.arc_center, motor_bore.normal() * 90, Intrinsic.YXZ)
    RigidJoint(f"motor", bracket, joint_location=location)

</div>

</div>

<figure class="align-center">
<img src="_images/filter_inner_wire_count.png"
alt="../_images/filter_inner_wire_count.png" />
</figure>

<div class="line-block">

<div class="line">

\

</div>

</div>

Linear joints for the slots are appropriate for mating flexibility, but
require more than a single location. The slot arc centers can be used
for creating a linear joint axis and range. To do that we can filter for
faces with 6 inner wires, sort for and select the top face, and then
filter for the circular edges of the inner wires.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    mount_face = faces.filter_by(lambda f: len(f.inner_wires()) == 6).sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]
    mount_slots = mount_face.inner_wires().edges().filter_by(GeomType.CIRCLE)
    joint_edges = [
        Line(mount_slots[i].arc_center, mount_slots[i + 1].arc_center)
        for i in range(0, len(mount_slots), 2)
    ]
    for i, e in enumerate(joint_edges):
        LinearJoint(f"mount_m4_{i}", bracket, axis=Axis(e), linear_range=(0, e.length / 2))

</div>

</div>

<figure class="align-center">
<img src="_images/filter_inner_wire_count_linear.png"
alt="../_images/filter_inner_wire_count_linear.png" />
</figure>

<div class="line-block">

<div class="line">

\

<div id="filter_examples.xhtml_nested-filters" class="section">

<span id="filter_examples.xhtml_filter-nested"></span>

## Nested Filters

Filters can be nested to specify features by characteristics other than
their own, like child properties. Here we want to chamfer the mating
edges of the D bore and square shaft. A way to do this is first looking
for faces with only 2 line edges among the inner wires. The nested
filter captures the straight edges, while the parent filter selects
faces based on the count. Then, from those faces, we filter for the
wires with any line edges.

<details class="sd-sphinx-override sd-dropdown sd-card sd-mb-3">

<summary class="sd-summary-title sd-card-header">

<span class="sd-summary-text">Setup</span>
<span class="sd-summary-state-marker sd-summary-chevron-right">

<svg version="1.1" width="1.5em" height="1.5em" class="sd-octicon sd-octicon-chevron-right" viewbox="0 0 24 24" aria-hidden="true">

<path d="M8.72 18.78a.75.75 0 0 1 0-1.06L14.44 12 8.72 6.28a.751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018l6.25 6.25a.75.75 0 0 1 0 1.06l-6.25 6.25a.75.75 0 0 1-1.06 0Z"></path>
</svg>

</span>
</summary>

<div class="sd-summary-content sd-card-body docutils">

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *

    with BuildPart() as part:
        Cylinder(15, 2, align=(Align.CENTER, Align.CENTER, Align.MIN))
        with BuildSketch():
            RectangleRounded(10, 10, 2.5)
        extrude(amount=15)

        with BuildSketch():
            Circle(2.5)
            Rectangle(4, 5, mode=Mode.INTERSECT)
        extrude(amount=15, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)

        with GridLocations(20, 0, 2, 1):
            Hole(3.5 / 2)

</div>

</div>

</div>

</details>

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

        faces = part.faces().filter_by(
            lambda f: len(f.inner_wires().edges().filter_by(GeomType.LINE)) == 2
        )
        wires = faces.wires().filter_by(
            lambda w: any(e.geom_type == GeomType.LINE for e in w.edges())
        )
        chamfer(wires.edges(), 0.5)

</div>

</div>

<div id="filter_examples.xhtml_shape-properties" class="section">

<span id="filter_examples.xhtml_filter-shape-properties"></span>

## Shape Properties

Selected features can be quickly filtered by feature properties. First,
we filter by interior and exterior edges using the
<span class="pre">`Edge`</span>
<span class="pre">`is`</span>` `<span class="pre">`interior`</span>
property to apply different fillets accordingly. Then the
<span class="pre">`Face`</span> <span class="pre">`is_circular_*`</span>
properties are used to highlight the resulting fillets.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *
    from ocp_vscode import *

    with BuildPart() as open_box_builder:
        Box(20, 20, 5)
        offset(amount=-2, openings=open_box_builder.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1])
        inside_edges = open_box_builder.edges().filter_by(Edge.is_interior)
        fillet(inside_edges, 1.5)
        outside_edges = open_box_builder.edges().filter_by(Edge.is_interior, reverse=True)
        fillet(outside_edges, 0.5)

    open_box = open_box_builder.part
    open_box.color = Color(0xEDAE49)
    outside_fillets = Compound(open_box.faces().filter_by(Face.is_circular_convex))
    outside_fillets.color = Color(0xD1495B)
    inside_fillets = Compound(open_box.faces().filter_by(Face.is_circular_concave))
    inside_fillets.color = Color(0x00798C)

</div>

</div>

<div id="build_line.xhtml_buildline" class="section">

# BuildLine

BuildLine is a python context manager that is used to create one
dimensional objects - objects with the property of length but not area -
that are typically used as part of a BuildSketch sketch or a BuildPart
path.

The complete API for BuildLine is located at the end of this section.

<div id="build_line.xhtml_basic-functionality" class="section">

## Basic Functionality

The following is a simple BuildLine example:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildLine() as example_1:
        Line((0, 0), (2, 0))
        ThreePointArc((0, 0), (1, 1), (2, 0))

</div>

</div>

The <span class="pre">`with`</span> statement creates the
<span class="pre">`BuildLine`</span> context manager with the identifier
<span class="pre">`example_1`</span>. The objects and operations that
are within the scope (i.e. indented) of this context will contribute
towards the object being created by the context manager. For
<span class="pre">`BuildLine`</span>, this object is
<span class="pre">`line`</span> and it’s referenced as
<span class="pre">`example_1.line`</span>.

The first object in this example is a <span class="pre">`Line`</span>
object which is used to create a straight line from coordinates (0,0) to
(2,0) on the default XY plane. The second object is a
<span class="pre">`ThreePointArc`</span> that starts and ends at the two
ends of the line.

<img src="_images/buildline_example_1.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/buildline_example_1.svg" />

</div>

<div id="build_line.xhtml_constraints" class="section">

## Constraints

Building with constraints enables the designer to capture design intent
and add a high degree of robustness to their designs. The following
sections describe creating positional and tangential constraints as well
as using object attributes to enable this type of design.

<div id="build_line.xhtml_position-at-operator" class="section">

### @ <span class="pre">`position_at`</span> Operator

In the previous example, the <span class="pre">`ThreePointArc`</span>
started and ended at the two ends of the <span class="pre">`Line`</span>
but this was done by referring to the same point
<span class="pre">`(0,0)`</span> and <span class="pre">`(2,0)`</span>.
This can be improved upon by specifying constraints that lock the arc to
those two end points, as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildLine() as example_2:
        l1 = Line((0, 0), (2, 0))
        l2 = ThreePointArc(l1 @ 0, (1, 1), l1 @ 1)

</div>

</div>

Here instance variables <span class="pre">`l1`</span> and
<span class="pre">`l2`</span> are assigned to the two BuildLine objects
and the <span class="pre">`ThreePointArc`</span> references the
beginning of the straight line with
<span class="pre">`l1`</span>` `<span class="pre">`@`</span>` `<span class="pre">`0`</span>
and the end with
<span class="pre">`l1`</span>` `<span class="pre">`@`</span>` `<span class="pre">`1`</span>.
The <span class="pre">`@`</span> operator takes a float (or integer)
parameter between 0 and 1 and determines a position at this fractional
position along the line’s length.

This example can be improved on further by calculating the mid-point of
the arc as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildLine() as example_3:
        l1 = Line((0, 0), (2, 0))
        l2 = ThreePointArc(l1 @ 0, l1 @ 0.5 + (0, 1), l1 @ 1)

</div>

</div>

Here
<span class="pre">`l1`</span>` `<span class="pre">`@`</span>` `<span class="pre">`0.5`</span>
finds the center of <span class="pre">`l1`</span> while
<span class="pre">`l1`</span>` `<span class="pre">`@`</span>` `<span class="pre">`0.5`</span>` `<span class="pre">`+`</span>` `<span class="pre">`(0,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`1)`</span>
does a vector addition to generate the point
<span class="pre">`(1,1)`</span>.

To make the design even more parametric, the height of the arc can be
calculated from <span class="pre">`l1`</span> as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildLine() as example_4:
        l1 = Line((0, 0), (2, 0))
        l2 = ThreePointArc(l1 @ 0, l1 @ 0.5 + (0, l1.length / 2), l1 @ 1)

</div>

</div>

The arc height is now calculated as
<span class="pre">`(0,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`l1.length`</span>` `<span class="pre">`/`</span>` `<span class="pre">`2)`</span>
by using the <span class="pre">`length`</span> property of
<span class="pre">`Edge`</span> and <span class="pre">`Wire`</span>
shapes. At this point the <span class="pre">`ThreePointArc`</span> is
fully parametric and able to generate the same shape for any horizontal
line.

</div>

<div id="build_line.xhtml_tangent-at-operator" class="section">

### % <span class="pre">`tangent_at`</span> Operator

The other operator that is commonly used within BuildLine is
<span class="pre">`%`</span> the tangent at operator. Here is another
example:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildLine() as example_5:
        l1 = Line((0, 0), (5, 0))
        l2 = Line(l1 @ 1, l1 @ 1 + (0, l1.length - 1))
        l3 = JernArc(start=l2 @ 1, tangent=l2 % 1, radius=0.5, arc_size=90)
        l4 = Line(l3 @ 1, (0, l2.length + l3.radius))

</div>

</div>

which generates (note that the circles show line junctions):

<img src="_images/buildline_example_5.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/buildline_example_5.svg" />

The <span class="pre">`JernArc`</span> has the following parameters:

- <span class="pre">`start=l2`</span>` `<span class="pre">`@`</span>` `<span class="pre">`1`</span> -
  start the arc at the end of line <span class="pre">`l2`</span>,

- <span class="pre">`tangent=l2`</span>` `<span class="pre">`%`</span>` `<span class="pre">`1`</span> -
  the tangent of the arc at the start point is equal to the
  <span class="pre">`l2`</span>'s, tangent at its end (shown as a dashed
  line)

- <span class="pre">`radius=0.5`</span> - the radius of the arc, and

- <span class="pre">`arc_size=90`</span> the angular size of the arc.

The final line starts at the end of <span class="pre">`l3`</span> and
ends at a point calculated from the length of
<span class="pre">`l2`</span> and the radius of arc
<span class="pre">`l3`</span>.

Building with constraints as shown here will ensure that your designs
both fully represent design intent and are robust to design changes.

</div>

</div>

<div id="build_line.xhtml_buildline-to-buildsketch" class="section">

## BuildLine to BuildSketch

As mentioned previously, one of the two primary reasons to create
BuildLine objects is to use them in BuildSketch. When a BuildLine
context manager exits and is within the scope of a BuildSketch context
manager it will transfer the generated line to BuildSketch. The
BuildSketch <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_sketch.make_face"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_sketch.make_face"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">make_face()</code></span></a>
or <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_sketch.make_hull"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_sketch.make_hull"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">make_hull()</code></span></a>
operations are then used to transform the line (specifically a list of
Edges) into a Face - the native BuildSketch objects.

Here is an example of using BuildLine to create an object that otherwise
might be difficult to create:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildSketch() as example_6:
        with BuildLine() as club_outline:
            l0 = Line((0, -188), (76, -188))
            b0 = Bezier(l0 @ 1, (61, -185), (33, -173), (17, -81))
            b1 = Bezier(b0 @ 1, (49, -128), (146, -145), (167, -67))
            b2 = Bezier(b1 @ 1, (187, 9), (94, 52), (32, 18))
            b3 = Bezier(b2 @ 1, (92, 57), (113, 188), (0, 188))
            mirror(about=Plane.YZ)
        make_face()

</div>

</div>

which generates:

<img src="_images/buildline_example_6.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/buildline_example_6.svg" />

<div class="admonition note">

Note

SVG import to BuildLine

The BuildLine code used in this example was generated by translating a
SVG file into BuildLine source code with the
<a href="#import_export.xhtml_importers.import_svg_as_buildline_code"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="importers.import_svg_as_buildline_code"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-func docutils literal notranslate">import_svg_as_buildline_code()</code></span></a>
function. For example:

<div class="highlight-default notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    svg_code, builder_name = import_svg_as_buildline_code("club.svg")

</div>

</div>

would translate the “club.svg” image file’s paths into BuildLine code
much like that shown above. From there it’s easy for a user to add
constraints or otherwise enhance the original image and use it in their
design.

</div>

</div>

<div id="build_line.xhtml_buildline-to-buildpart" class="section">

## BuildLine to BuildPart

The other primary reasons to use BuildLine is to create paths for
BuildPart <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.sweep"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_generic.sweep"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">sweep()</code></span></a>
operations. Here some curved and straight segments define a path:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as example_7:
        with BuildLine() as example_7_path:
            l1 = RadiusArc((0, 0), (1, 1), 2)
            l2 = Spline(l1 @ 1, (2, 3), (3, 3), tangents=(l1 % 1, (0, -1)))
            l3 = Line(l2 @ 1, (3, 0))
        with BuildSketch(Plane(origin=l1 @ 0, z_dir=l1 % 0)) as example_7_section:
            Circle(0.1)
        sweep()

</div>

</div>

which generates:

<img src="_images/buildline_example_7.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/buildline_example_7.svg" />

There are few things to note from this example:

- The @ and % operators are used to create a plane normal to the
  beginning of the path with which to create the circular section used
  by the sweep operation (this plane is not one of the ordinal planes).

- Both the path generated by BuildLine and the section generated by
  BuildSketch have been transferred to BuildPart when each of them exit.

- The BuildPart <span class="pre">`Sweep`</span> operation is using the
  path and section previously transferred to it (as “pending” objects)
  as parameters of the sweep. The <span class="pre">`Sweep`</span>
  operation “consumes” these pending objects as to not interfere with
  subsequence operations.

</div>

<div id="build_line.xhtml_working-on-other-planes" class="section">

## Working on other Planes

So far all of the examples were created on
<span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span> - the default plane - which is
equivalent to global coordinates. Sometimes it’s convenient to work on
another plane, especially when creating paths for BuildPart
<span class="pre">`Sweep`</span> operations.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildLine(Plane.YZ) as example_8:
        l1 = Line((0, 0), (5, 0))
        l2 = Line(l1 @ 1, l1 @ 1 + (0, l1.length - 1))
        l3 = JernArc(start=l2 @ 1, tangent=l2 % 1, radius=0.5, arc_size=90)
        l4 = Line(l3 @ 1, (0, l2.length + l3.radius))

</div>

</div>

which generates:

<img src="_images/buildline_example_8.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/buildline_example_8.svg" />

Here the BuildLine object is created on
<span class="pre">`Plane.YZ`</span> just by specifying the working plane
during BuildLine initialization.

There are three rules to keep in mind when working with alternate planes
in BuildLine:

1.  <span class="pre">`BuildLine`</span> accepts a single
    <span class="pre">`Plane`</span> to work with as opposed to other
    Builders that accept more than one workplane.

2.  Values entered as tuples such as
    <span class="pre">`(1,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`2)`</span> or
    <span class="pre">`(1,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`2,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`3)`</span>
    will be localized to the current workplane. This rule applies to
    points and to the use of tuples to modify locations calculated with
    the <span class="pre">`@`</span> and <span class="pre">`%`</span>
    operators such as
    <span class="pre">`l1`</span>` `<span class="pre">`@`</span>` `<span class="pre">`1`</span>` `<span class="pre">`+`</span>` `<span class="pre">`(1,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`1)`</span>.
    For example, if the workplane is <span class="pre">`Plane.YZ`</span>
    the local value of
    <span class="pre">`(1,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`2)`</span> would
    be converted to
    <span class="pre">`(0,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`1,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`2)`</span>
    in global coordinates. Three tuples are converted as well -
    <span class="pre">`(1,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`2,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`3)`</span>
    on <span class="pre">`Plane.YZ`</span> would be
    <span class="pre">`(3,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`1,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`2)`</span>
    in global coordinates. Providing values in local coordinates allows
    the designer to automate such conversions.

3.  Values entered using the <span class="pre">`Vector`</span> class or
    those generated by the <span class="pre">`@`</span> operator are
    considered global values and are not localized. For example:
    <span class="pre">`Line(Vector(1,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`2,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`3),`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Vector(4,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`5,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`6))`</span>
    will generate the same line independent of the current workplane.
    It’s unlikely that users will need to use
    <span class="pre">`Vector`</span> values but the option is there.

Finally, BuildLine’s workplane need not be one of the predefined ordinal
planes, it could be one created from a surface of a BuildPart part that
is currently under construction.

</div>

<div id="build_line.xhtml_module-build_line" class="section">

<span id="build_line.xhtml_reference"></span>

## Reference

*<span class="pre">class</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">BuildLine</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">workplane:</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.topology.two_d.Face</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.geometry.Plane</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.geometry.Location</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">Plane((0</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">0</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">0)</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">(1</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">0</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">0)</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">(0</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">0</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">1))</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">mode:</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.build_enums.Mode</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">\<Mode.ADD\></span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>  
The BuildLine class is a subclass of Builder for building lines (objects
with length but not area or volume). It has an \_obj property that
returns the current line being built. The class overrides the faces and
solids methods of Builder since they don’t apply to lines.

BuildLine only works with a single workplane which is used to convert
tuples as inputs to global coordinates. For example:

<div class="highlight-default notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildLine(Plane.YZ) as radius_arc:
        RadiusArc((1, 2), (2, 1), 1)

</div>

</div>

creates an arc from global points (0, 1, 2) to (0, 2, 1). Note that
points entered as Vector(x, y, z) are considered global and are not
localized.

The workplane is also used to define planes parallel to the workplane
that arcs are created on.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **workplane**
  (*Union\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Face"><em>Face</em></a>*,*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Plane"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="geometry.Plane"><em>Plane</em></a>*,*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Location"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="geometry.Location"><em>Location</em></a>*\],* *optional*) –
  plane used when local coordinates are used and when creating arcs.
  Defaults to Plane.XY.

- **mode** (<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Mode"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_enums.Mode"><em>Mode</em></a>*,* *optional*) –
  combination mode. Defaults to Mode.ADD.

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">face</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="o"><span class="pre">\*</span></span><span class="n"><span class="pre">args</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>

<span id="build_sketch.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="build_sketch.xhtml_buildsketch" class="section">

# BuildSketch

BuildSketch is a python context manager that is used to create planar
two dimensional objects - objects with the property of area but not
volume - that are typically used as profiles for BuildPart operations
like <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_part.extrude"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_part.extrude"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-func docutils literal notranslate">extrude()</code></span></a>
or <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_part.revolve"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_part.revolve"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-func docutils literal notranslate">revolve()</code></span></a>.

The complete API for BuildSketch is located at the end of this section.

<div id="build_sketch.xhtml_basic-functionality" class="section">

## Basic Functionality

The following is a simple BuildSketch example:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    length, radius = 40.0, 60.0

    with BuildSketch() as circle_with_hole:
        Circle(radius=radius)
        Rectangle(width=length, height=length, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)

</div>

</div>

The <span class="pre">`with`</span> statement creates the
<span class="pre">`BuildSketch`</span> context manager with the
identifier <span class="pre">`circle_with_hole`</span>. The objects and
operations that are within the scope (i.e. indented) of this context
will contribute towards the object being created by the context manager.
For <span class="pre">`BuildSketch`</span>, this object is
<span class="pre">`sketch`</span> and it’s referenced as
<span class="pre">`circle_with_hole.sketch`</span>.

The first object in this example is a <span class="pre">`Circle`</span>
object which is used to create a filled circular shape on the default XY
plane. The second object is a <span class="pre">`Rectangle`</span> that
is subtracted from the circle as directed by the
<span class="pre">`mode=Mode.SUBTRACT`</span> parameter. A key aspect of
sketch objects is that they are all filled shapes and not just a shape
perimeter which enables combining subsequent shapes with different modes
(the valid values of Mode are <span class="pre">`ADD`</span>,
<span class="pre">`SUBTRACT`</span>,
<span class="pre">`INTERSECT`</span>,
<span class="pre">`REPLACE`</span>, and
<span class="pre">`PRIVATE`</span>).

<img src="_images/circle_with_hole.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/circle_with_hole.svg" />

</div>

<div id="build_sketch.xhtml_sketching-on-other-planes" class="section">

<span id="build_sketch.xhtml_id1"></span>

## Sketching on other Planes

Often when designing parts one needs to build on top of other features.
To facilitate doing this <span class="pre">`BuildSketch`</span> allows
one to create sketches on any Plane while allowing the designer to work
in a local X, Y coordinate system. It might be helpful to think of what
is happening with this metaphor:

1.  When instantiating <span class="pre">`BuildSketch`</span> one or
    more workplanes can be passed as parameters. These are the placement
    targets for the completed sketch.

2.  The designer draws on a flat “drafting table” which is
    <span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span>.

3.  Once the sketch is complete, it’s applied like a sticker to all of
    the workplanes passed in step 1.

As an example, let’s build the following simple control box with a
display on an angled plane:

<img src="_images/controller.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/controller.svg" />

Here is the code:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as controller:
        # Create the side view of the controller
        with BuildSketch(Plane.YZ) as profile:
            with BuildLine():
                Polyline((0, 0), (0, 40), (20, 80), (40, 80), (40, 0), (0, 0))
            # Create a filled face from the perimeter drawing
            make_face()
        # Extrude to create the basis controller shape
        extrude(amount=30, both=True)
        # Round off all the edges
        fillet(controller.edges(), radius=3)
        # Hollow out the controller
        offset(amount=-1, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
        # Extract the face that will house the display
        display_face = (
            controller.faces()
            .filter_by(GeomType.PLANE)
            .filter_by_position(Axis.Z, 50, 70)[0]
        )
        # Create a workplane from the face
        display_workplane = Plane(
            origin=display_face.center(), x_dir=(1, 0, 0), z_dir=display_face.normal_at()
        )
        # Place the sketch directly on the controller
        with BuildSketch(display_workplane) as display:
            RectangleRounded(40, 30, 2)
            with GridLocations(45, 35, 2, 2):
                Circle(1)
        # Cut the display sketch through the controller
        extrude(amount=-1, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)

</div>

</div>

The highlighted part of the code shows how a face is extracted from the
design, a workplane is constructed from this face and finally this
workplane is passed to <span class="pre">`BuildSketch`</span> as the
target for the complete sketch. Notice how the
<span class="pre">`display`</span> sketch uses local coordinates for its
features thus avoiding having the user to determine how to move and
rotate the sketch to get it where it should go.

Note that <span class="pre">`BuildSketch`</span> accepts a sequence
planes, faces and locations for workplanes so creation of an explicit
workplane is often not required. Being able to work on multiple
workplanes at once allows for features to be created on multiple side of
an object - say both the top and bottom - which is convenient for
symmetric parts.

</div>

<div id="build_sketch.xhtml_local-vs-global-sketches" class="section">

## Local vs. Global Sketches

In the above example the target for the sketch was not
<span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span> but a workplane passed by the user.
Internally <span class="pre">`BuildSketch`</span> is always creating the
sketch on <span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span> which one can see by
looking at the <span class="pre">`sketch_local`</span> property of your
sketch. For example, to display the local version of the
<span class="pre">`display`</span> sketch from above, one would use:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    show_object(display.sketch_local, name="sketch on Plane.XY")

</div>

</div>

while the sketches as applied to their target workplanes is accessible
through the <span class="pre">`sketch`</span> property, as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    show_object(display.sketch, name="sketch on target workplane(s)")

</div>

</div>

When using the <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.add"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_generic.add"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-func docutils literal notranslate">add()</code></span></a>
operation to add an external Face to a sketch the face will
automatically be reoriented to <span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span>
before being combined with the sketch. As Faces don’t provide an
x-direction it’s possible that the new Face may not be oriented as
expected. To reorient the Face manually to
<span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span> one can use the
<span class="pre">`to_local_coords()`</span> method as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    reoriented_face = plane.to_local_coords(face)

</div>

</div>

where <span class="pre">`plane`</span> is the plane that
<span class="pre">`face`</span> was constructed on.

</div>

<div id="build_sketch.xhtml_locating-features" class="section">

## Locating Features

Within a sketch features are positioned with
<span class="pre">`Locations`</span> contexts (see
<a href="#key_concepts_builder.xhtml_location-context-link"
class="reference internal"><span class="std std-ref">Location
Context</span></a>) on the current workplane(s). The following location
contexts are available within a sketch:

- <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.GridLocations"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_common.GridLocations"><span class="pre"><code
  class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">GridLocations</code></span></a>
  : a X/Y grid of locations

- <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.HexLocations"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_common.HexLocations"><span class="pre"><code
  class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">HexLocations</code></span></a>
  : a hex grid of locations ideal for nesting circles

- <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.Locations"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_common.Locations"><span class="pre"><code
  class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Locations</code></span></a>
  : a sequence of arbitrary locations

- <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_common.PolarLocations"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_common.PolarLocations"><span class="pre"><code
  class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">PolarLocations</code></span></a>
  : locations defined by radius and angle

Generally one would specify tuples of (X, Y) values when defining
locations but there are many options available to the user.

</div>

<div id="build_sketch.xhtml_module-build_sketch" class="section">

<span id="build_sketch.xhtml_reference"></span>

## Reference

*<span class="pre">class</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">BuildSketch</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">\*workplanes:</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.topology.two_d.Face</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.geometry.Plane</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.geometry.Location</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">mode:</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.build_enums.Mode</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">\<Mode.ADD\></span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>  
The BuildSketch class is a subclass of Builder for building planar 2D
sketches (objects with area but not volume) from faces or lines. It has
an \_obj property that returns the current sketch being built. The
sketch property consists of the sketch(es) applied to the input
workplanes while the sketch_local attribute is the sketch constructed on
Plane.XY. The class overrides the solids method of Builder since they
don’t apply to lines.

Note that all sketch construction is done within sketch_local on
Plane.XY. When objects are added to the sketch they must be coplanar to
Plane.XY, usually handled automatically but may need user input for
Edges and Wires since their construction plane isn’t always able to be
determined.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **workplanes**
  (*Union\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Face"><em>Face</em></a>*,*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Plane"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="geometry.Plane"><em>Plane</em></a>*,*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Location"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="geometry.Location"><em>Location</em></a>*\],* *optional*) –
  objects converted to plane(s) to place the sketch on. Defaults to
  Plane.XY.

- **mode** (<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Mode"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_enums.Mode"><em>Mode</em></a>*,* *optional*) –
  combination mode. Defaults to Mode.ADD.

<span id="build_part.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="build_part.xhtml_buildpart" class="section">

# BuildPart

BuildPart is a python context manager that is used to create three
dimensional objects - objects with the property of volume - that are
typically finished parts.

The complete API for BuildPart is located at the end of this section.

<div id="build_part.xhtml_basic-functionality" class="section">

## Basic Functionality

The following is a simple BuildPart example:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
    center_hole_dia = 22.0

    with BuildPart() as ex2:
        Box(length, width, thickness)
        Cylinder(radius=center_hole_dia / 2, height=thickness, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)

</div>

</div>

The <span class="pre">`with`</span> statement creates the
<span class="pre">`BuildPart`</span> context manager with the identifier
<span class="pre">`ex2`</span> (this code is the second of the
introductory examples). The objects and operations that are within the
scope (i.e. indented) of this context will contribute towards the object
being created by the context manager. For
<span class="pre">`BuildPart`</span>, this object is
<span class="pre">`part`</span> and it’s referenced as
<span class="pre">`ex2.part`</span>.

The first object in this example is a <span class="pre">`Box`</span>
object which is used to create a polyhedron with rectangular faces
centered on the default <span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span>. The second
object is a <span class="pre">`Cylinder`</span> that is subtracted from
the box as directed by the <span class="pre">`mode=Mode.SUBTRACT`</span>
parameter thus creating a hole.

<img src="_images/general_ex2.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/general_ex2.svg" />

</div>

<div id="build_part.xhtml_implicit-parameters" class="section">

## Implicit Parameters

The BuildPart context keeps track of pending objects such that they can
be used implicitly - there are a couple things to consider when deciding
how to proceed:

- For sketches, the planes that they were constructed on is maintained
  in internal data structures such that operations like
  <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_part.extrude"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="operations_part.extrude"><span class="pre"><code
  class="sourceCode python xref py py-func docutils literal notranslate">extrude()</code></span></a>
  will have a good reference for the extrude direction. One can pass a
  Face to extrude but it will then be forced to use the normal direction
  at the center of the Face as the extrude direction which unfortunately
  can be reversed in some circumstances.

- Implicit parameters save some typing but hide some functionality -
  users have to decide what works best for them.

This tea cup example uses implicit parameters - note the
<a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.sweep"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_generic.sweep"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-func docutils literal notranslate">sweep()</code></span></a>
operation on the last line:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *
    from ocp_vscode import show

    wall_thickness = 3 * MM
    fillet_radius = wall_thickness * 0.49

    with BuildPart() as tea_cup:
        # Create the bowl of the cup as a revolved cross section
        with BuildSketch(Plane.XZ) as bowl_section:
            with BuildLine():
                # Start & end points with control tangents
                s = Spline(
                    (30 * MM, 10 * MM),
                    (69 * MM, 105 * MM),
                    tangents=((1, 0.5), (0.7, 1)),
                    tangent_scalars=(1.75, 1),
                )
                # Lines to finish creating ½ the bowl shape
                Polyline(s @ 0, s @ 0 + (10 * MM, -10 * MM), (0, 0), (0, (s @ 1).Y), s @ 1)
            make_face()  # Create a filled 2D shape
        revolve(axis=Axis.Z)
        # Hollow out the bowl with openings on the top and bottom
        offset(amount=-wall_thickness, openings=tea_cup.faces().filter_by(GeomType.PLANE))
        # Add a bottom to the bowl
        with Locations((0, 0, (s @ 0).Y)):
            Cylinder(radius=(s @ 0).X, height=wall_thickness)
        # Smooth out all the edges
        fillet(tea_cup.edges(), radius=fillet_radius)

        # Determine where the handle contacts the bowl
        handle_intersections = [
            tea_cup.part.find_intersection_points(
                Axis(origin=(0, 0, vertical_offset), direction=(1, 0, 0))
            )[-1][0]
            for vertical_offset in [35 * MM, 80 * MM]
        ]
        # Create a path for handle creation
        with BuildLine(Plane.XZ) as handle_path:
            Spline(
                handle_intersections[0] - (wall_thickness / 2, 0),
                handle_intersections[0] + (35 * MM, 30 * MM),
                handle_intersections[0] + (40 * MM, 60 * MM),
                handle_intersections[1] - (wall_thickness / 2, 0),
                tangents=((1, 1.25), (-0.2, -1)),
            )
        # Align the cross section to the beginning of the path
        with BuildSketch(handle_path.line ^ 0) as handle_cross_section:
            RectangleRounded(wall_thickness, 8 * MM, fillet_radius)
        sweep()  # Sweep handle cross section along path

    assert abs(tea_cup.part.volume - 130326) < 1

    show(tea_cup, names=["tea cup"])

</div>

</div>

<a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.sweep"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_generic.sweep"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-func docutils literal notranslate">sweep()</code></span></a>
requires a 2D cross section -
<span class="pre">`handle_cross_section`</span> - and a path -
<span class="pre">`handle_path`</span> - which are both passed
implicitly.

<img src="_images/tea_cup.png" class="align-center"
alt="_images/tea_cup.png" />

</div>

<div id="build_part.xhtml_units" class="section">

## Units

Parts created with build123d have no inherent units associated with
them. However, when exporting parts to external formats like
<span class="pre">`STL`</span> or <span class="pre">`STEP`</span> the
units are assumed to be millimeters (mm). To be more explicit with units
one can use the technique shown in the above tea cup example where
linear dimensions are followed by
<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`MM`</span> which
multiplies the dimension by the <span class="pre">`MM`</span> scaling
factor - in this case <span class="pre">`1`</span>.

The following dimensional constants are pre-defined:

<div class="highlight-python notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    MM = 1
    CM = 10 * MM
    M = 1000 * MM
    IN = 25.4 * MM
    FT = 12 * IN
    THOU = IN / 1000

</div>

</div>

Some export formats like DXF have the ability to explicitly set the
units used.

</div>

<div id="build_part.xhtml_module-build_part" class="section">

<span id="build_part.xhtml_reference"></span>

## Reference

*<span class="pre">class</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">BuildPart</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">\*workplanes:</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.topology.two_d.Face</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.geometry.Plane</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.geometry.Location</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">mode:</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.build_enums.Mode</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">\<Mode.ADD\></span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>  
The BuildPart class is another subclass of Builder for building parts
(objects with the property of volume) from sketches or 3D objects. It
has an \_obj property that returns the current part being built, and
several pending lists for storing faces, edges, and planes that will be
integrated into the final part later. The class overrides the
\_add_to_pending method of Builder.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **workplanes** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Plane"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="geometry.Plane"><em>Plane</em></a>*,* *optional*) – initial
  plane to work on. Defaults to Plane.XY.

- **mode** (<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Mode"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_enums.Mode"><em>Mode</em></a>*,* *optional*) –
  combination mode. Defaults to Mode.ADD.

*<span class="pre">property</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">location</span></span>*<span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">Location</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\|</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">None</span>*  
Builder’s location

*<span class="pre">property</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">part</span></span>*<span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">Part</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\|</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">None</span>*  
Get the current part

*<span class="pre">property</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">pending_edges_as_wire</span></span>*<span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">Wire</span>*  
Return a wire representation of the pending edges

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<span id="joints.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="joints.xhtml_joints" class="section">

<span id="joints.xhtml_id1"></span>

# Joints

<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Joint"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Joint"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Joint</code></span></a>’s
enable Solid and Compound objects to be arranged relative to each other
in an intuitive manner - with the same degree of motion that is found
with the equivalent physical joints.
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Joint"

Objects may have many joints bound to them each with an identifying
label. All <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Joint"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Joint"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Joint</code></span></a>
objects have a <span class="pre">`symbol`</span> property that can be
displayed to help visualize their position and orientation (the
<a href="https://github.com/bernhard-42/vscode-ocp-cad-viewer"
class="reference external">ocp-vscode</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/bernhard-42/vscode-ocp-cad-viewer\]</span> viewer
has built-in support for displaying joints).

<div class="admonition note">

Note

If joints are created within the scope of a
<a href="#build_part.xhtml_build_part.BuildPart"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_part.BuildPart"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">BuildPart</code></span></a>
builder, the <span class="pre">`to_part`</span> parameter need not be
specified as the builder will, on exit, automatically transfer the
joints created in its scope to the part created.

</div>

The following sections provide more detail on the available joints and
describes how they are used.

<div id="joints.xhtml_rigid-joint" class="section">

<span id="joints.xhtml_module-joints"></span>

## Rigid Joint

A rigid joint positions two components relative to each another with no
freedom of movement. When a <a href="#joints.xhtml_joints.RigidJoint"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="joints.RigidJoint"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">RigidJoint</code></span></a>
is instantiated it’s assigned a <span class="pre">`label`</span>, a part
to bind to (<span class="pre">`to_part`</span>), and a
<span class="pre">`joint_location`</span> which defines both the
position and orientation of the joint (see
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Location"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Location"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Location</code></span></a>) -
as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    RigidJoint(label="outlet", to_part=pipe, joint_location=path.location_at(1))

</div>

</div>

Once a joint is bound to a part this way, the
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Joint.connect_to"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Joint.connect_to"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">connect_to()</code></span></a>
method can be used to repositioning another part relative to
<span class="pre">`self`</span> which stay fixed - as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    pipe.joints["outlet"].connect_to(flange_outlet.joints["pipe"])

</div>

</div>

<div class="admonition note">

Note

Within a part all of the joint labels must be unique.

</div>

The <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Joint.connect_to"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Joint.connect_to"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">connect_to()</code></span></a>
method only does a one time re-position of a part and does not bind them
in any way; however, putting them into an
<a href="#assemblies.xhtml_assembly" class="reference internal"><span
class="std std-ref">Assemblies</span></a> will maintain there relative
locations as will combining parts with boolean operations or within a
<a href="#build_part.xhtml_build_part.BuildPart"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_part.BuildPart"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">BuildPart</code></span></a>
context.

As a example of creating parts with joints and connecting them together,
consider the following code where flanges are attached to the ends of a
curved pipe:

![](_images/rigid_joints_pipe.png)

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    import copy
    from build123d import *
    from bd_warehouse.flange import WeldNeckFlange
    from bd_warehouse.pipe import PipeSection
    from ocp_vscode import *

    flange_inlet = WeldNeckFlange(nps="10", flange_class=300)
    flange_outlet = copy.copy(flange_inlet)

    with BuildPart() as pipe_builder:
        # Create the pipe
        with BuildLine():
            path = TangentArc((0, 0, 0), (2 * FT, 0, 1 * FT), tangent=(1, 0, 0))
        with BuildSketch(Plane(origin=path @ 0, z_dir=path % 0)):
            PipeSection("10", material="stainless", identifier="40S")
        sweep()

        # Add the joints
        RigidJoint(label="inlet", joint_location=-path.location_at(0))
        RigidJoint(label="outlet", joint_location=path.location_at(1))

    # Place the flanges at the ends of the pipe
    pipe_builder.part.joints["inlet"].connect_to(flange_inlet.joints["pipe"])
    pipe_builder.part.joints["outlet"].connect_to(flange_outlet.joints["pipe"])

    show(pipe_builder, flange_inlet, flange_outlet, render_joints=True)

</div>

</div>

Note how the locations of the joints are determined by the
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Mixin1D.location_at"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Mixin1D.location_at"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">location_at()</code></span></a>
method and how the <span class="pre">`-`</span> negate operator is used
to reverse the direction of the location without changing its position.
Also note that the <span class="pre">`WeldNeckFlange`</span> class
predefines two joints, one at the pipe end and one at the face end -
both of which are shown in the above image (generated by ocp-vscode with
the <span class="pre">`render_joints=True`</span> flag set in the
<span class="pre">`show`</span> function).

<div id="joints.xhtml_revolute-joint" class="section">

## Revolute Joint

Component rotates around axis like a hinge. The
<a href="#tutorial_joints.xhtml_joint-tutorial"
class="reference internal"><span class="std std-ref">Joint
Tutorial</span></a> covers Revolute Joints in detail.

During instantiation of a <a href="#joints.xhtml_joints.RevoluteJoint"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="joints.RevoluteJoint"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">RevoluteJoint</code></span></a>
there are three parameters not present with Rigid Joints:
<span class="pre">`axis`</span>,
<span class="pre">`angle_reference`</span>, and
<span class="pre">`range`</span> that allow the circular motion to be
fully defined.

When <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Joint.connect_to"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Joint.connect_to"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">connect_to()</code></span></a>
with a Revolute Joint, an extra <span class="pre">`angle`</span>
parameter is present which allows one to change the relative position of
joined parts by changing a single value.

<div id="joints.xhtml_linear-joint" class="section">

## Linear Joint

Component moves along a single axis as with a sliding latch shown here:

![](_images/joint-latch-slide.png)

The code to generate these components follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *
    from ocp_vscode import *

    with BuildPart() as latch:
        # Basic box shape to start with filleted corners
        Box(70, 30, 14)
        end = latch.faces().sort_by(Axis.X)[-1]  # save the end with the hole
        fillet(latch.edges().filter_by(Axis.Z), 2)
        fillet(latch.edges().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1], 1)
        # Make screw tabs
        with BuildSketch(latch.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[0]) as l4:
            with Locations((-30, 0), (30, 0)):
                SlotOverall(50, 10, rotation=90)
            Rectangle(50, 30)
            fillet(l4.vertices(Select.LAST), radius=2)
        extrude(amount=-2)
        with GridLocations(60, 40, 2, 2):
            Hole(2)
        # Create the hole from the end saved previously
        with BuildSketch(end) as slide_hole:
            add(end)
            offset(amount=-2)
            fillet(slide_hole.vertices(), 1)
        extrude(amount=-68, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
        # Slot for the handle to slide in
        with BuildSketch(latch.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]):
            SlotOverall(32, 8)
        extrude(amount=-2, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
        # The slider will move align the x axis 12mm in each direction
        LinearJoint("latch", axis=Axis.X, linear_range=(-12, 12))

    with BuildPart() as slide:
        # The slide will be a little smaller than the hole
        with BuildSketch() as s1:
            add(slide_hole.sketch)
            offset(amount=-0.25)
        # The extrusions aren't symmetric
        extrude(amount=46)
        extrude(slide.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[0], amount=20)
        # Round off the ends
        fillet(slide.edges().group_by(Axis.Z)[0], 1)
        fillet(slide.edges().group_by(Axis.Z)[-1], 1)
        # Create the knob
        with BuildSketch() as s2:
            with Locations((12, 0)):
                SlotOverall(15, 4, rotation=90)
            Rectangle(12, 7, align=(Align.MIN, Align.CENTER))
            fillet(s2.vertices(Select.LAST), 1)
            split(bisect_by=Plane.XZ)
        revolve(axis=Axis.X)
        # Align the joint to Plane.ZY flipped
        RigidJoint("slide", joint_location=Location(-Plane.ZY))

    # Position the slide in the latch: -12 >= position <= 12
    latch.part.joints["latch"].connect_to(slide.part.joints["slide"], position=12)

    # show(latch.part, render_joints=True)
    # show(slide.part, render_joints=True)
    show(latch.part, slide.part, render_joints=True)

</div>

</div>

<img src="_images/joint-latch.png" style="width: 65%;"
alt="_images/joint-latch.png" />
<img src="_images/joint-slide.png" style="width: 27.5%;"
alt="_images/joint-slide.png" />

Note how the slide is constructed in a different orientation than the
direction of motion. The three highlighted lines of code show how the
joints are created and connected together:

- The <a href="#joints.xhtml_joints.LinearJoint"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="joints.LinearJoint"><span class="pre"><code
  class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">LinearJoint</code></span></a>
  has an axis and limits of movement

- The <a href="#joints.xhtml_joints.RigidJoint"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="joints.RigidJoint"><span class="pre"><code
  class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">RigidJoint</code></span></a>
  has a single location, orientated such that the knob will ultimately
  be “up”

- The <span class="pre">`connect_to`</span> specifies a position that
  must be within the predefined limits.

The slider can be moved back and forth by just changing the
<span class="pre">`position`</span> value. Values outside of the limits
will raise an exception.

*<span class="pre">class</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">LinearJoint</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">label</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">str</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">to_part</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">Solid</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\|</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">Compound</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\|</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">None</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o"><span class="pre">=</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="default_value"><span class="pre">None</span></span>*, *<span <div id="joints.xhtml_ball-joint" class="section">

## Ball Joint

A component rotates around all 3 axes using a gimbal system (3 nested
rotations). A <a href="#joints.xhtml_joints.BallJoint"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="joints.BallJoint"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">BallJoint</code></span></a>
is found within a rod end as shown here:

![](_images/rod_end.png)

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *
    from bd_warehouse.thread import IsoThread
    from ocp_vscode import *

    # Create the thread so the min radius is available below
    thread = IsoThread(major_diameter=6, pitch=1, length=20, end_finishes=("fade", "raw"))
    inner_radius = 15.89 / 2
    inner_gap = 0.2

    with BuildPart() as rod_end:
        # Create the outer shape
        with BuildSketch():
            Circle(22.25 / 2)
            with Locations((0, -12)):
                Rectangle(8, 1)
            make_hull()
            split(bisect_by=Plane.YZ)
        revolve(axis=Axis.Y)
        # Refine the shape
        with BuildSketch(Plane.YZ) as s2:
            Rectangle(25, 8, align=(Align.MIN, Align.CENTER))
            Rectangle(9, 10, align=(Align.MIN, Align.CENTER))
            chamfer(s2.vertices(), 0.5)
        revolve(axis=Axis.Z, mode=Mode.INTERSECT)
        # Add the screw shaft
        Cylinder(
            thread.min_radius,
            30,
            rotation=(90, 0, 0),
            align=(Align.CENTER, Align.CENTER, Align.MIN),
        )
        # Cutout the ball socket
        Sphere(inner_radius, mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
        # Add thread
        with Locations((0, -30, 0)):
            add(thread, rotation=(-90, 0, 0))
        # Create the ball joint
        BallJoint(
            "socket",
            joint_location=Location(),
            angular_range=((-14, 14), (-14, 14), (0, 360)),
        )

    with BuildPart() as ball:
        Sphere(inner_radius - inner_gap)
        Box(50, 50, 13, mode=Mode.INTERSECT)
        Hole(4)
        ball.part.color = Color("aliceblue")
        RigidJoint("ball", joint_location=Location())

    rod_end.part.joints["socket"].connect_to(ball.part.joints["ball"], angles=(5, 10, 0))

    show(rod_end.part, ball.part, s2)

</div>

</div>

Note how limits are defined during the instantiation of the ball joint
when ensures that the pin or bolt within the rod end does not interfere
with the rod end itself. The <span class="pre">`connect_to`</span> sets
the three angles (only two are significant in this example).
