- **TypeError** – invalid other joint type

- **ValueError** – angles out of range

*<span class="pre">property</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">symbol</span></span>*<span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">Compound</span>*  
A CAD symbol representing joint as bound to part

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<span id="assemblies.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="assemblies.xhtml_assemblies" class="section">

<span id="assemblies.xhtml_assembly"></span>

# Assemblies

Most CAD designs consist of more than one part which are naturally
arranged in some type of assembly. Once parts have been assembled in a
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Compound"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Compound"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Compound</code></span></a>
object they can be treated as a unit - i.e.
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape.moved"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape.moved"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">moved()</code></span></a>
or exported.

To create an assembly in build123d, one needs to create a tree of parts
by simply assigning either a
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Compound"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Compound"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Compound</code></span></a>
object’s <span class="pre">`parent`</span> or
<span class="pre">`children`</span> attributes. To illustrate the
process, we’ll extend the
<a href="#tutorial_joints.xhtml_joint-tutorial"
class="reference internal"><span class="std std-ref">Joint
Tutorial</span></a>.

<div id="assemblies.xhtml_assigning-labels" class="section">

## Assigning Labels

In order keep track of objects one can assign a
<span class="pre">`label`</span> to all
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Shape</code></span></a>
objects. Here we’ll assign labels to all of the components that will be
part of the box assembly:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    box.label = "box"
    lid.label = "lid"
    hinge_outer.label = "outer hinge"
    hinge_inner.label = "inner hinge"
    m6_screw.label = "M6 screw"

</div>

</div>

The labels are just strings with no further limitations (they don’t have
to be unique within the assembly).

</div>

<div id="assemblies.xhtml_create-the-assembly-compound" class="section">

## Create the Assembly Compound

Creation of the assembly is done by simply creating a
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Compound"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Compound"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Compound</code></span></a>
object and assigning appropriate <span class="pre">`parent`</span> and
<span class="pre">`children`</span> attributes as shown here:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    box_assembly = Compound(label="assembly", children=[box, lid, hinge_inner, hinge_outer])

</div>

</div>

To display the topology of an assembly
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Compound"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Compound"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Compound</code></span></a>,
the <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape.show_topology"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape.show_topology"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">show_topology()</code></span></a>
method can be used as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    print(box_assembly.show_topology())

</div>

</div>

which results in:

<div class="highlight-default notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    assembly        Compound at 0x7fc8ee235760, Location(p=(0, 0, 0), o=(-0, 0, -0))
    ├── box         Compound at 0x7fc8ee2188b0, Location(p=(0, 0, 50), o=(-0, 0, -0))
    ├── lid         Compound at 0x7fc8ee228460, Location(p=(-26, 0, 181), o=(-180, 30, -0))
    ├── inner hinge Hinge    at 0x7fc9292c3f70, Location(p=(-119, 60, 122), o=(90, 0, -150))
    └── outer hinge Hinge    at 0x7fc9292c3f40, Location(p=(-150, 60, 50), o=(90, 0, 90))

</div>

</div>

To add to an assembly
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Compound"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Compound"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Compound</code></span></a>
one can change either <span class="pre">`children`</span> or
<span class="pre">`parent`</span> attributes.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    m6_screw.parent = box_assembly
    print(box_assembly.show_topology())

</div>

</div>

and now the screw is part of the assembly.

<div class="highlight-default notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    assembly        Compound at 0x7fc8ee235760, Location(p=(0, 0, 0), o=(-0, 0, -0))
    ├── box         Compound at 0x7fc8ee2188b0, Location(p=(0, 0, 50), o=(-0, 0, -0))
    ├── lid         Compound at 0x7fc8ee228460, Location(p=(-26, 0, 181), o=(-180, 30, -0))
    ├── inner hinge Hinge    at 0x7fc9292c3f70, Location(p=(-119, 60, 122), o=(90, 0, -150))
    ├── outer hinge Hinge    at 0x7fc9292c3f40, Location(p=(-150, 60, 50), o=(90, 0, 90))
    └── M6 screw    Compound at 0x7fc8ee235310, Location(p=(-157, -40, 70), o=(-0, -90, -60))

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="assemblies.xhtml_shallow-vs-deep-copies-of-shapes"
class="section">

<span id="assemblies.xhtml_shallow-copy"></span>

## Shallow vs. Deep Copies of Shapes

Build123d supports the standard python <span class="pre">`copy`</span>
module which provides two different types of copy operations
<span class="pre">`copy.copy()`</span> and
<span class="pre">`copy.deepcopy()`</span>.

Build123d’s implementation of <span class="pre">`deepcopy()`</span> for
the <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Shape</code></span></a>
class (e.g. <span class="pre">`Solid`</span>,
<span class="pre">`Face`</span>, etc.) does just that, creates a
complete copy of the original all the way down to the CAD object.
<span class="pre">`deepcopy`</span> is therefore suited to the case
where the copy will be subsequently modified to become its own unique
item.

However, when building an assembly a common use case is to include many
instances of an object, each one identical but in a different location.
This is where <span class="pre">`copy.copy()`</span> is very useful as
it copies all of the
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Shape</code></span></a>
except for the actual CAD object which instead is a reference to the
original (OpenCascade refers this as a
<span class="pre">`TShape`</span>). As it’s a reference any changes to
the original will be seen in all of the shallow copies.

Consider this example where 100 screws are added to an assembly:

<img src="_images/reference_assembly.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/reference_assembly.svg" />

<div class="highlight-default notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    screw = import_step("M6-1x12-countersunk-screw.step")
    locs = HexLocations(6, 10, 10).local_locations

    screw_copies = [copy.deepcopy(screw).locate(loc) for loc in locs]
    copy_assembly = Compound(children=screw_copies)
    export_step(copy_assembly, "copy_assembly.step")

</div>

</div>

which takes about 5 seconds to run (on an older computer) and produces a
file of size 51938 KB. However, if a shallow copy is used instead:

<div class="highlight-default notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    screw = import_step("M6-1x12-countersunk-screw.step")
    locs = HexLocations(6, 10, 10).local_locations

    screw_references = [copy.copy(screw).locate(loc) for loc in locs]
    reference_assembly = Compound(children=screw_references)
    export_step(reference_assembly, "reference_assembly.step")

</div>

</div>

this takes about ¼ second and produces a file of size 550 KB - just over
1% of the size of the <span class="pre">`deepcopy()`</span> version and
only 12% larger than the screw’s step file.

Using <span class="pre">`copy.copy()`</span> to create references to the
original CAD object for assemblies can substantially reduce the time and
resources used to create and store that assembly.

</div>

<div id="assemblies.xhtml_shapes-are-anytree-nodes" class="section">

## Shapes are Anytree Nodes

The build123d assembly constructs are built using the python
<a href="https://anytree.readthedocs.io/en/latest/"
class="reference external">anytree</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://anytree.readthedocs.io/en/latest/\]</span> package by making
the build123d <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Shape</code></span></a>
class a sub-class of anytree’s <span class="pre">`NodeMixin`</span>
class. Doing so adds the following attributes to
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Shape</code></span></a>:

- <span class="pre">`parent`</span> - Parent Node. On set, the node is
  detached from any previous parent node and attached to the new node.

- <span class="pre">`children`</span> - Tuple of all child nodes.

- <span class="pre">`path`</span> - Path of this
  <span class="pre">`Node`</span>.

- <span class="pre">`iter_path_reverse`</span> - Iterate up the tree
  from the current node.

- <span class="pre">`ancestors`</span> - All parent nodes and their
  parent nodes.

- <span class="pre">`descendants`</span> - All child nodes and all their
  child nodes.

- <span class="pre">`root`</span> - Tree Root Node.

- <span class="pre">`siblings`</span> - Tuple of nodes with the same
  parent.

- <span class="pre">`leaves`</span> - Tuple of all leaf nodes.

- <span class="pre">`is_leaf`</span> - <span class="pre">`Node`</span>
  has no children (External Node).

- <span class="pre">`is_root`</span> - <span class="pre">`Node`</span>
  is tree root.

- <span class="pre">`height`</span> - Number of edges on the longest
  path to a leaf <span class="pre">`Node`</span>.

- <span class="pre">`depth`</span> - Number of edges to the root
  <span class="pre">`Node`</span>.

<div class="admonition note">

Note

Changing the <span class="pre">`children`</span> attribute

Any iterator can be assigned to the <span class="pre">`children`</span>
attribute but subsequently the children are stored as immutable
<span class="pre">`tuple`</span> objects. To add a child to an existing
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Compound"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Compound"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Compound</code></span></a>
object, the <span class="pre">`children`</span> attribute will have to
be reassigned.

</div>

</div>

<div id="assemblies.xhtml_iterating-over-compounds" class="section">

<span id="assemblies.xhtml_pack"></span>

## Iterating Over Compounds

As Compounds are containers for shapes, build123d can iterate over these
as required. Complex nested assemblies (compounds within compounds) do
not need to be looped over with recursive functions. In the example
below, the variable total_volume holds the sum of all the volumes in
each solid in an assembly. Compare this to assembly3_volume which only
results in the volume of the top level part.

<div class="highlight-python notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    # [import]
    from build123d import *
    from ocp_vscode import *

    # Each assembly has a box and the previous assembly.
    assembly1 = Compound(label='Assembly1', children=[Box(1, 1, 1),])
    assembly2 = Compound(label='Assembly2', children=[assembly1, Box(1, 1, 1)])
    assembly3 = Compound(label='Assembly3', children=[assembly2, Box(1, 1, 1)])
    total_volume = sum(part.volume for part in assembly3.solids()) # 3
    assembly3_volume = assembly3.volume # 1

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="assemblies.xhtml_id1" class="section">

## pack

The <a href="#assemblies.xhtml_pack.pack"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="pack.pack"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">pack.pack()</code></span></a>
function arranges objects in a compact, non-overlapping layout within a
square(ish) 2D area. It is designed to minimize the space between
objects while ensuring that no two objects overlap.

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">pack</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">objects</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">Collection</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\[</span></span><span class="pre">Shape</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">padding</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">float</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">align_z</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">bool</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o"><span class="pre">=</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="default_value"><span class="pre">False</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span> <span class="sig-return"><span class="sig-return-icon">→</span> <span class="sig-return-typehint"><span class="pre">Collection</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\[</span></span><span class="pre">Shape</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span></span></span>  
Pack objects in a squarish area in Plane.XY.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **objects**
  (*Collection\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Shape"><em>Shape</em></a>*\]*) – objects to arrange

- **padding** (*float*) – space between objects

- **align_z** (*bool,* *optional*) – align shape bottoms to Plane.XY.
  Defaults to False.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
rearranged objects

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
*Collection*\[<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape"><em>Shape</em></a>\]

<div id="assemblies.xhtml_detailed-description" class="section">

### Detailed Description

The <span class="pre">`pack`</span> function uses a bin-packing
algorithm to efficiently place objects within a 2D plane, ensuring that
there is no overlap and that the space between objects is minimized.
This is particularly useful in scenarios where spatial efficiency is
crucial, such as layout design and object arrangement in constrained
spaces.

The function begins by calculating the bounding boxes for each object,
including the specified padding. It then uses a helper function
<span class="pre">`_pack2d`</span> to determine the optimal positions
for each object within the 2D plane. The positions are then translated
back to the original objects, ensuring that they are arranged without
overlapping.

</div>

<div id="assemblies.xhtml_usage-note" class="section">

### Usage Note

The <span class="pre">`align_z`</span> parameter is especially useful
when creating print-plates for 3D printing. By aligning the bottoms of
the shapes to the same XY plane, you ensure that the objects are
perfectly positioned for slicing software, which will no longer need to
perform this alignment for you. This can streamline the process and
improve the accuracy of the print setup.

</div>

<div id="assemblies.xhtml_example-usage" class="section">

### Example Usage

<div class="highlight-python notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    # [import]
    from build123d import *
    from ocp_vscode import *


    # [initial space]
    b1 = Box(100, 100, 100, align=(Align.CENTER, Align.CENTER, Align.MIN))
    b2 = Box(54, 54, 54, align=(Align.CENTER, Align.CENTER, Align.MAX), mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
    b3 = Box(34, 34, 34, align=(Align.MIN, Align.MIN, Align.CENTER), mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)
    b4 = Box(24, 24, 24, align=(Align.MAX, Align.MAX, Align.CENTER), mode=Mode.SUBTRACT)

</div>

</div>

<img src="_images/pack_demo_initial_state.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/pack_demo_initial_state.svg" />

<div class="highlight-python notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    # [pack 2D]

    xy_pack = pack(
        [b1, b2, b3, b4],
        padding=5,
        align_z=False
    )

</div>

</div>

<img src="_images/pack_demo_packed_xy.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/pack_demo_packed_xy.svg" />

<div class="highlight-python notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    # [Pack and align_z]

    z_pack = pack(
        [b1, b2, b3, b4],
        padding=5,
        align_z=True
    )

</div>

</div>

<img src="_images/pack_demo_packed_z.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/pack_demo_packed_z.svg" />

</div>

<div id="assemblies.xhtml_tip" class="section">

### Tip

If you place the arranged objects into a
<span class="pre">`Compound`</span>, you can easily determine their
bounding box and check whether the objects fit on your print bed.

<div class="highlight-python notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    # [bounding box]
    print(Compound(xy_pack).bounding_box())
    # bbox: 0.0 <= x <= 159.0, 0.0 <= y <= 129.0, -54.0 <= z <= 100.0

    print(Compound(z_pack).bounding_box())
    # bbox: 0.0 <= x <= 159.0, 0.0 <= y <= 129.0, 0.0 <= z <= 100.0

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<span id="tips.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="tips.xhtml_tips-best-practices-and-faq" class="section">

# Tips, Best Practices and FAQ

Although there are countless ways to create objects with build123d,
experience has proven that certain techniques can assist designers in
achieving their goals with the greatest efficiency. The following is a
description of these techniques.

<div id="tips.xhtml_can-t-get-there-from-here" class="section">

## Can’t Get There from Here

Unfortunately, it’s a reality that not all parts described using
build123d can be successfully constructed by the underlying CAD core.
Designers may have to explore different design approaches to get the
OpenCascade CAD core to successfully build the target object. For
instance, if a multi-section
<a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.sweep"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_generic.sweep"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-func docutils literal notranslate">sweep()</code></span></a>
operation fails, a <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_part.loft"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_part.loft"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-func docutils literal notranslate">loft()</code></span></a>
operation may be a viable alternative in certain situations. It’s
crucial to remember that CAD is a complex field and patience may be
required to achieve the desired results.

</div>

<div id="tips.xhtml_d-before-3d" class="section">

## 2D before 3D

When creating complex 3D objects, it is generally best to start with 2D
work before moving on to 3D. This is because 3D structures are much more
intricate, and 3D operations can be slower and more prone to failure.
For designers who come from a Constructive Solid Geometry (CSG)
background, such as OpenSCAD, this approach may seem counterintuitive.
On the other hand, designers from a GUI BREP CAD background, like Fusion
360 or SolidWorks, may find this approach more natural.

In practice, this means that 3D objects are often created by applying
operations like <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_part.extrude"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_part.extrude"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-func docutils literal notranslate">extrude()</code></span></a>
or <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_part.revolve"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_part.revolve"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-func docutils literal notranslate">revolve()</code></span></a>
to 2D sketches, as shown below:

<div class="highlight-python notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as my_part:
        with BuildSketch() as part_profile:
            ...
        extrude(amount=some_distance)
        ...

</div>

</div>

With this structure <span class="pre">`part_profile`</span> may have
many objects that are combined and modified by operations like
<a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_generic.fillet"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="operations_generic.fillet"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-func docutils literal notranslate">fillet()</code></span></a>
before being extruded to a 3D shape.

</div>

<div id="tips.xhtml_delay-chamfers-and-fillets" class="section">

## Delay Chamfers and Fillets

Chamfers and fillets can add complexity to a design by transforming
simple vertices or edges into arcs or non-planar faces. This can
significantly increase the complexity of the design. To avoid
unnecessary processing costs and potential errors caused by a needlessly
complicated design, it’s recommended to perform these operations towards
the end of the object’s design. This is especially true for 3D shapes,
as it is sometimes necessary to fillet or chamfer in the 2D design
phase. Luckily, these 2D fillets and chamfers are less likely to fail
than their 3D counterparts.

</div>

<div id="tips.xhtml_parameterize" class="section">

## Parameterize

One of the most powerful features of build123d is the ability to design
fully parameterized parts. While it may be faster to use a GUI CAD
package for the initial iteration of a part, subsequent iterations can
prove frustratingly difficult. By using variables for critical
dimensions and deriving other dimensions from these key variables, not
only can a single part be created, but a whole set of parts can be
readily available. When inevitable change requests arise, a simple
parameter adjustment may be all that’s required to make necessary
modifications.

</div>

<div id="tips.xhtml_use-shallow-copies" class="section">

## Use Shallow Copies

As discussed in the Assembly section, a
<a href="#assemblies.xhtml_shallow-copy"
class="reference internal"><span class="std std-ref">shallow
copy</span></a> of parts that are repeated in your design can make a
huge difference in performance and usability of your end design. Objects
like fasteners, bearings, chain links, etc. could be duplicated tens or
even hundreds of times otherwise. Use shallow copies where possible but
keep in mind that if one instance of the object changes all will change.

</div>

<div id="tips.xhtml_object-selection" class="section">

## Object Selection

When selecting features in a design it’s sometimes easier to select an
object from higher up in the topology first, then select the object from
there. For example let’s consider a plate with four chamfered holes like
this:

<img src="_images/plate.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/plate.svg" />

When selecting edges to be chamfered one might first select the face
that these edges belong to then select the edges as shown here:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    from build123d import *

    svg_opts = {"pixel_scale": 5, "show_axes": False, "show_hidden": True}

    length, width, thickness = 80.0, 60.0, 10.0
    hole_dia = 6.0

    with BuildPart() as plate:
        Box(length, width, thickness)
        with GridLocations(length - 20, width - 20, 2, 2):
            Hole(radius=hole_dia / 2)
        top_face: Face = plate.faces().sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]
        hole_edges = top_face.edges().filter_by(GeomType.CIRCLE)
        chamfer(hole_edges, length=1)

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="tips.xhtml_build123d-cadquery-integration" class="section">

## Build123d - CadQuery Integration

As both <a href="https://cadquery.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html"
class="reference external">CadQuery</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://cadquery.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html\]</span> and
**build123d** use a common OpenCascade Python wrapper
(<a href="https://github.com/CadQuery/OCP"
class="reference external">OCP</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/CadQuery/OCP\]</span>) it’s possible to interchange
objects both from CadQuery to build123d and vice-versa by transferring
the <span class="pre">`wrapped`</span> objects as follows (first from
CadQuery to build123d):

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    import build123d as b3d
    b3d_solid = b3d.Solid.make_box(1,1,1)

    ... some cadquery stuff ...

    b3d_solid.wrapped = cq_solid.wrapped

</div>

</div>

Secondly, from build123d to CadQuery as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    import build123d as b3d
    import cadquery as cq

    with b3d.BuildPart() as b123d_box:
        b3d.Box(1,2,3)

    cq_solid = cq.Solid.makeBox(1,1,1)
    cq_solid.wrapped = b123d_box.part.solid().wrapped

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="tips.xhtml_self-intersection" class="section">

## Self Intersection

Avoid creating objects that intersect themselves - even if at a single
vertex - as these topologies will almost certainly be invalid (even if
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape.is_valid"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape.is_valid"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">is_valid()</code></span></a>
reports a <span class="pre">`True`</span> value). An example of where
this may arise is with the thread of a screw (or any helical shape)
where after one complete revolution the part may contact itself. One is
likely be more successful if the part is split into multiple sections -
say 180° of a helix - which are then stored in an assembly.

</div>

<div id="tips.xhtml_packing-objects-on-a-plane"
class="section clearfix">

## Packing Objects on a Plane

When designing independent shapes it’s common to place each at or near
the global origin, which can make it tricky to visualize many shapes at
once. <a href="#assemblies.xhtml_pack.pack"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="pack.pack"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">pack.pack()</code></span></a>
will translate the <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Shape</code></span></a>’s
passed to it so that they don’t overlap, with an optional
padding/spacing. Here’s the result of packing a bunch of overlapping
boxes (left) using some padding (right):

<img src="_images/packed_boxes_input.svg" class="align-left"
style="width: 200px;" alt="_images/packed_boxes_input.svg" />
<img src="_images/packed_boxes_output.svg" class="align-right"
alt="_images/packed_boxes_output.svg" />

By default, the original Z value of all objects packed using the
<a href="#assemblies.xhtml_pack.pack"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="pack.pack"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">pack.pack()</code></span></a>
function is preserved. If you want to align all objects so that they are
“placed” on the zero Z coordinate, the
<a href="#assemblies.xhtml_module-pack"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal" title="pack"><span
class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">pack()</code></span></a>
function has an <cite>align_z</cite> argument. When set to
<cite>True</cite>, this will align all objects.

This can be useful, for example, when preparing print setups for 3D
printing, giving you full control over this alignment so you don’t have
to leave it to the slicer.

</div>

<div id="tips.xhtml_isnt-from-build123d-import-bad-practice"
class="section">

<span id="tips.xhtml_are-glob-imports-bad-practice"></span>

## Isn’t <span class="pre">`from`</span>` `<span class="pre">`build123d`</span>` `<span class="pre">`import`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span> bad practice?

Glob imports like
<span class="pre">`from`</span>` `<span class="pre">`build123d`</span>` `<span class="pre">`import`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>
are generally frowned upon when writing software, and for good reason.
They pollute the global namespace, cause confusing collisions, and are
not future-proof, as future changes to the library being imported could
collide with other names. It would be much safer to do something like
<span class="pre">`import`</span>` `<span class="pre">`build123d`</span>` `<span class="pre">`as`</span>` `<span class="pre">`bd`</span>
and then reference every item with, for example,
<span class="pre">`bd.BuildPart()`</span>. If your goal is to integrate
build123d into a larger piece of software, which many people work on, or
where long-term maintainability is a priority, using this approach is
definitely a good idea! Why then, are glob imports so often used in
build123d code and official examples?

build123d is most commonly used not as a library within a larger
application, but as a
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain-specific_language"
class="reference external">Domain-Specific Language</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain-specific_language\]</span> which,
together with something like the OCP CAD Viewer, acts as the user
interface for a CAD application. Writing build123d often involves live
coding in a REPL or typing in editors with limited space due to the rest
of the CAD GUI taking up screen space. Scripts are usually centred
around build123d usage, with usage of other libraries being limited
enough that naming conflicts are easily avoided. In this context, it’s
entirely reasonable to prioritise developer ergonomics over
“correctness” by making build123d’s primitives available in the global
namespace.

</div>

<div id="tips.xhtml_why-doesn-t-buildsketch-plane-xz-work"
class="section">

## Why doesn’t BuildSketch(Plane.XZ) work?

When creating a sketch not on the default
<span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span> users may expect that they are
drawing directly on the workplane / coordinate system provided. For
example:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildSketch(Plane.XZ) as vertical_sketch:
        Rectangle(1, 1)
        with Locations(vertices().group_by(Axis.X)[-1].sort_by(Axis.Z)[-1]):
            Circle(0.2)

</div>

</div>

![](_images/vertical_sketch.png)

In this case the circle is not positioned in the top right as one would
expect; in-fact, the position of the circle randomly switches between
the bottom and top corner.

This is because all sketches are created on a local
<span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span> independent of where they will be
ultimately placed; therefore, the
<span class="pre">`sort_by(Axis.Z)`</span> is sorting two points that
have a Z value of zero as they are located on
<span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span> and effectively return a random
point.

Why does <span class="pre">`BuildSketch`</span> work this way? Consider
an example where the user wants to work on a plane not aligned with any
Axis, as follows (this is often done when creating a sketch on a
<span class="pre">`Face`</span> of a 3D part but is simulated here by
rotating a <span class="pre">`Plane`</span>):

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildSketch(Plane.YZ.rotated((123, 45, 6))) as custom_plane:
        Rectangle(1, 1, align=Align.MIN)
        with Locations(vertices().group_by(Axis.X)[-1].sort_by(Axis.Y)[-1]):
            Circle(0.2)

</div>

</div>

![](_images/sketch_on_custom_plane.png)

Here one can see both <span class="pre">`sketch_local`</span> (with the
light fill on <span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span>) and the
<span class="pre">`sketch`</span> (with the darker fill) placed on the
user provided workplane. As the selectors work off global coordinates,
selection of the “top right” of this sketch would be quite challenging
and would likely change if the sketch was ever moved as could happen if
the 3D part changed. For an example of sketching on a 3D part, see
<a href="#build_sketch.xhtml_sketching-on-other-planes"
class="reference internal"><span class="std std-ref">Sketching on other
Planes</span></a>.

</div>

<div id="tips.xhtml_why-is-buildline-not-working-as-expected-within-the-scope-of-buildsketch"
class="section">

## Why is BuildLine not working as expected within the scope of BuildSketch?

As described above, all sketching is done on a local
<span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span>; however, the following is a common
issue:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildSketch() as sketch:
        with BuildLine(Plane.XZ):
            Polyline(...)
        make_face()

</div>

</div>

Here <span class="pre">`BuildLine`</span> is within the scope of
<span class="pre">`BuildSketch`</span>; therefore, all of the drawing
should be done on <span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span>; however, the user
has specified <span class="pre">`Plane.XZ`</span> when creating the
<span class="pre">`BuildLine`</span> instance. Although this isn’t
absolutely incorrect it’s almost certainly not what the user intended.
Here the face created by <span class="pre">`make_face`</span> will be
reoriented to <span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span> as all sketching must
be done on that plane. This reorienting of objects to
<span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span> allows a user to
<span class="pre">`add`</span> content from other sources to the sketch
without having to manually re-orient the object.

Unless there is a good reason and the user understands how the
<span class="pre">`BuildLine`</span> object will be reoriented, all
<span class="pre">`BuildLine`</span> instances within the scope of
<span class="pre">`BuildSketch`</span> should be done on the default
<span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span>.

</div>

<div id="tips.xhtml_don-t-builders-inherit-workplane-coordinate-systems-when-nested"
class="section">

## Don’t Builders inherit workplane/coordinate systems when nested

Some users expect that nested Builders will inherit the workplane or
coordinate system from their parent Builder - this is not true. When a
Builder is instantiated, a workplane is either provided by the user or
it defaults to <span class="pre">`Plane.XY`</span>. Having Builders
inherent coordinate systems from their parents could result in confusion
when they are nested as well as change their behaviour depending on
which scope they are in. Inheriting coordinate systems isn’t necessarily
incorrect, it was considered for build123d but ultimately the simple
static approach was taken.

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<span id="import_export.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="import_export.xhtml_import-export" class="section">

# Import/Export

Methods and functions specific to exporting and importing build123d
objects are defined below.

For example:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    with BuildPart() as box_builder:
        Box(1, 1, 1)
    export_step(box_builder.part, "box.step")

</div>

</div>

<div id="import_export.xhtml_file-formats" class="section">

## File Formats

<div id="import_export.xhtml_mf" class="section">

### 3MF

The 3MF (3D Manufacturing Format) file format is a versatile and modern
standard for representing 3D models used in additive manufacturing, 3D
printing, and other applications. Developed by the 3MF Consortium, it
aims to overcome the limitations of traditional 3D file formats by
providing a more efficient and feature-rich solution. The 3MF format
supports various advanced features like color information, texture
mapping, multi-material definitions, and precise geometry
representation, enabling seamless communication between design software,
3D printers, and other manufacturing devices. Its open and extensible
nature makes it an ideal choice for exchanging complex 3D data in a
compact and interoperable manner.

</div>

<div id="import_export.xhtml_brep" class="section">

### BREP

The BREP (Boundary Representation) file format is a widely used data
format in computer-aided design (CAD) and computer-aided engineering
(CAE) applications. BREP represents 3D geometry using topological
entities like vertices, edges, and faces, along with their connectivity
information. It provides a precise and comprehensive representation of
complex 3D models, making it suitable for advanced modeling and analysis
tasks. BREP files are widely supported by various CAD software, enabling
seamless data exchange between different systems. Its ability to
represent both geometric shapes and their topological relationships
makes it a fundamental format for storing and sharing detailed 3D
models.

</div>

<div id="import_export.xhtml_dxf" class="section">

### DXF

The DXF (Drawing Exchange Format) file format is a widely used standard
for representing 2D and 3D drawings, primarily used in computer-aided
design (CAD) applications. Developed by Autodesk, DXF files store
graphical and geometric data, such as lines, arcs, circles, and text, as
well as information about layers, colors, and line weights. Due to its
popularity, DXF files can be easily exchanged and shared between
different CAD software. The format’s simplicity and human-readable
structure make it a versatile choice for sharing designs, drawings, and
models across various CAD platforms, facilitating seamless collaboration
in engineering and architectural projects.

</div>

<div id="import_export.xhtml_gltf" class="section">

### glTF

The glTF (GL Transmission Format) is a royalty-free specification for
the efficient transmission and loading of 3D models and scenes by
applications. Developed by the Khronos Group, glTF is designed as a
compact, interoperable format that enables the quick display of assets
across various platforms and devices. glTF supports a rich feature set,
including detailed meshes, materials, textures, skeletal animations, and
more, facilitating complex 3D visualizations. It streamlines the process
of sharing and deploying 3D content in web applications, game engines,
and other visualization tools, making it the “JPEG of 3D.” glTF’s
versatility and efficiency have led to its widespread adoption in the 3D
content industry.

</div>

<div id="import_export.xhtml_stl" class="section">

### STL

The STL (STereoLithography) file format is a widely used file format in
3D printing and computer-aided design (CAD) applications. It represents
3D geometry using triangular facets to approximate the surface of a 3D
model. STL files are widely supported and can store both the geometry
and color information of the model. They are used for rapid prototyping
and 3D printing, as they provide a simple and efficient way to represent
complex 3D objects. The format’s popularity stems from its ease of use,
platform independence, and ability to accurately describe the surface of
intricate 3D models with a minimal file size.

</div>

<div id="import_export.xhtml_step" class="section">

### STEP

The STEP (Standard for the Exchange of Product model data) file format
is a widely used standard for representing 3D product and manufacturing
data in computer-aided design (CAD) and computer-aided engineering (CAE)
applications. It is an ISO standard (ISO 10303) and supports the
representation of complex 3D geometry, product structure, and metadata.
STEP files store information in a neutral and standardized format,
making them highly interoperable across different CAD/CAM software
systems. They enable seamless data exchange between various engineering
disciplines, facilitating collaboration and data integration throughout
the entire product development and manufacturing process.

</div>

<div id="import_export.xhtml_svg" class="section">

### SVG

The SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics) file format is an XML-based standard
used for describing 2D vector graphics. It is widely supported and can
be displayed in modern web browsers, making it suitable for web-based
graphics and interactive applications. SVG files define shapes, paths,
text, and images using mathematical equations, allowing for smooth
scalability without loss of quality. The format is ideal for logos,
icons, illustrations, and other graphics that require resolution
independence. SVG files are also easily editable in text editors or
vector graphic software, making them a popular choice for designers and
developers seeking flexible and versatile graphic representation.

</div>

</div>

<div id="import_export.xhtml_d-exporters" class="section">

## 2D Exporters

Exports to DXF (Drawing Exchange Format) and SVG (Scalable Vector
Graphics) are provided by the 2D Exporters: ExportDXF and ExportSVG
classes.

DXF is a widely used file format for exchanging CAD (Computer-Aided
Design) data between different software applications. SVG is a widely
used vector graphics format that is supported by web browsers and
various graphic editors.

The core concept to these classes is the creation of a DXF/SVG document
with specific properties followed by the addition of layers and shapes
to the documents. Once all of the layers and shapes have been added, the
document can be written to a file.

<div id="import_export.xhtml_d-to-2d-projection" class="section">

### 3D to 2D Projection

There are a couple ways to generate a 2D drawing of a 3D part:

- Generate a section: The
  <a href="#operations.xhtml_operations_part.section"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="operations_part.section"><span class="pre"><code
  class="sourceCode python xref py py-func docutils literal notranslate">section()</code></span></a>
  operation can be used to create a 2D cross section of a 3D part at a
  given plane.

- Generate a projection: The
  <span class="pre">`project_to_viewport()`</span> method can be used to
  create a 2D projection of a 3D scene. Similar to a camera, the
  <span class="pre">`viewport_origin`</span> defines the location of
  camera, the <span class="pre">`viewport_up`</span> defines the
  orientation of the camera, and the <span class="pre">`look_at`</span>
  parameter defined where the camera is pointed. By default,
  <span class="pre">`viewport_up`</span> is the positive z axis and
  <span class="pre">`look_up`</span> is the center of the shape. The
  return value is a tuple of lists of edges, the first the visible edges
  and the second the hidden edges.

Each of these Edges and Faces can be assigned different line color/types
and fill colors as described below (as
<span class="pre">`project_to_viewport`</span> only generates Edges,
fill doesn’t apply). The shapes generated from the above steps are to be
added as shapes in one of the exporters described below and written as
either a DXF or SVG file as shown in this example:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    view_port_origin=(-100, -50, 30)
    visible, hidden = part.project_to_viewport(view_port_origin)
    max_dimension = max(*Compound(children=visible + hidden).bounding_box().size)
    exporter = ExportSVG(scale=100 / max_dimension)
    exporter.add_layer("Visible")
    exporter.add_layer("Hidden", line_color=(99, 99, 99), line_type=LineType.ISO_DOT)
    exporter.add_shape(visible, layer="Visible")
    exporter.add_shape(hidden, layer="Hidden")
    exporter.write("part_projection.svg")

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="import_export.xhtml_linetype" class="section">

### LineType

ANSI (American National Standards Institute) and ISO (International
Organization for Standardization) standards both define line types in
drawings used in DXF and SVG exported drawings:

- ANSI Standards:  
  - ANSI/ASME Y14.2 - “Line Conventions and Lettering” is the standard
    that defines line types, line weights, and line usage in engineering
    drawings in the United States.

- ISO Standards:  
  - ISO 128 - “Technical drawings – General principles of presentation”
    is the ISO standard that covers the general principles of technical
    drawing presentation, including line types and line conventions.

  - ISO 13567 - “Technical product documentation (TPD) – Organization
    and naming of layers for CAD” provides guidelines for the
    organization and naming of layers in Computer-Aided Design (CAD)
    systems, which may include line type information.

These standards help ensure consistency and clarity in technical
drawings, making it easier for engineers, designers, and manufacturers
to communicate and interpret the information presented in the drawings.

The line types used by the 2D Exporters are defined by the
<span class="pre">`LineType`</span> Enum and are shown in the following
diagram:

<img src="_images/line_types.svg" class="align-center"
alt="_images/line_types.svg" />

</div>

<div id="import_export.xhtml_exportdxf" class="section">

### ExportDXF

*<span class="pre">class</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">ExportDXF</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">version:</span> <span class="pre">str</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">'AC1027'</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">unit:</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.build_enums.Unit</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">\<Unit.MM\></span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">color:</span> <span class="pre">~exporters.ColorIndex</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">None</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">None</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">line_weight:</span> <span class="pre">float</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">None</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">None</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">line_type:</span> <span class="pre">~exporters.LineType</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">None</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">None</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>  
The ExportDXF class provides functionality for exporting 2D shapes to
DXF (Drawing Exchange Format) format. DXF is a widely used file format
for exchanging CAD (Computer-Aided Design) data between different
software applications.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **version** (*str,* *optional*) – The DXF version to use for the
  output file. Defaults to ezdxf.DXF2013.

- **unit** (*Unit,* *optional*) – The unit used for the exported DXF. It
  should be one of the Unit enums: Unit.MC, Unit.MM, Unit.CM, Unit.M,
  Unit.IN, or Unit.FT. Defaults to Unit.MM.

- **color** (*Optional\[ColorIndex\],* *optional*) – The default color
  index for shapes. It can be specified as a ColorIndex enum or None..
  Defaults to None.

- **line_weight** (*Optional\[float\],* *optional*) – The default line
  weight (stroke width) for shapes, in millimeters. . Defaults to None.

- **line_type** (*Optional\[LineType\],* *optional*) – e default line
  type for shapes. It should be a LineType enum or None.. Defaults to
  None.

Example

<div class="highlight-python notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    exporter = ExportDXF(unit=Unit.MM, line_weight=0.5)
    exporter.add_layer("Layer 1", color=ColorIndex.RED, line_type=LineType.DASHED)
    exporter.add_shape(shape_object, layer="Layer 1")
    exporter.write("output.dxf")

</div>

</div>

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**ValueError** – unit not supported

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">METRIC_UNITS</span></span>*<span class="w"> </span><span class="p"><span class="pre">=</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">{\<Unit.CM\>,</span> <span class="pre">\<Unit.M\>,</span> <span class="pre">\<Unit.MM\>}</span>*  

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">add_layer</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">name</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">str</span></span>*, *<span class="o"><span class="pre">\*</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">color</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">ColorIndex</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\|</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">None</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o"><span class="pre">=</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="default_value"><span class="pre">None</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">line_weight</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">float</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\|</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">None</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o"><span class="pre">=</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="default_value"><span class="pre">None</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">line_type</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">LineType</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\|</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">None</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o"><span class="pre">=</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="default_value"><span class="pre">None</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span> <span class="sig-return"><span class="sig-return-icon">→</span> <span class="sig-return-typehint"><span class="pre">Self</span></span></span>  
Adds a new layer to the DXF export with the given properties.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **name** (*str*) – The name of the layer definition. Must be unique
  among all layers.

- **color** (*Optional\[ColorIndex\],* *optional*) – The color index for
  shapes on this layer. It can be specified as a ColorIndex enum or
  None. Defaults to None.

- **line_weight** (*Optional\[float\],* *optional*) – The line weight
  (stroke width) for shapes on this layer, in millimeters. Defaults to
  None.

- **line_type** (*Optional\[LineType\],* *optional*) – The line type for
  shapes on this layer. It should be a LineType enum or None. Defaults
  to None.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
DXF document with additional layer

### ExportSVG

class="pre">~build123d.geometry.Color</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">None</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">None</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span <span class="pre">~exporters.LineType</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">LineType.CONTINUOUS</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">dot_length:</span> <span class="pre">~exporters.DotLength</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">float</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">DotLength.INKSCAPE_COMPAT</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>  
SVG file export functionality.

The ExportSVG class provides functionality for exporting 2D shapes to
SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics) format. SVG is a widely used vector
graphics format that is supported by web browsers and various graphic
editors.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **unit** (*Unit,* *optional*) – The unit used for the exported SVG. It
  should be one of the Unit enums: Unit.MM, Unit.CM, or Unit.IN.
  Defaults to Unit.MM.

- **scale** (*float,* *optional*) – The scaling factor applied to the
  exported SVG. Defaults to 1.

- **margin** (*float,* *optional*) – The margin added around the
  exported shapes. Defaults to 0.

- **fit_to_stroke** (*bool,* *optional*) – A boolean indicating whether
  the SVG view box should fit the strokes of the shapes. Defaults to
  True.

- **precision** (*int,* *optional*) – The number of decimal places used
  for rounding coordinates in the SVG. Defaults to 6.

- **fill_color** (*ColorIndex* *\|* *RGB* *\|* *None,* *optional*) – The
  default fill color for shapes. It can be specified as a ColorIndex, an
  RGB tuple, or None. Defaults to None.

- **line_color** (*ColorIndex* *\|* *RGB* *\|* *None,* *optional*) – The
  default line color for shapes. It can be specified as a ColorIndex or
  an RGB tuple, or None. Defaults to Export2D.DEFAULT_COLOR_INDEX.

- **line_weight** (*float,* *optional*) – The default line weight
  (stroke width) for shapes, in millimeters. Defaults to
  Export2D.DEFAULT_LINE_WEIGHT.

- **line_type** (*LineType,* *optional*) – The default line type for
  shapes. It should be a LineType enum. Defaults to
  Export2D.DEFAULT_LINE_TYPE.

- **dot_length** (*DotLength* *\|* *float,* *optional*) – The width of
  rendered dots in a Can be either a DotLength enum or a float value in
  tenths of an inch. Defaults to DotLength.INKSCAPE_COMPAT.

Example

<div class="highlight-python notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    exporter = ExportSVG(unit=Unit.MM, line_weight=0.5)
    exporter.add_layer("Layer 1", fill_color=(255, 0, 0), line_color=(0, 0, 255))
    exporter.add_shape(shape_object, layer="Layer 1")
    exporter.write("output.svg")

</div>

</div>

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**ValueError** – Invalid unit.

The glTF (GL Transmission Format) specification primarily focuses on the
efficient transmission and loading of 3D models as a compact, binary
format that is directly renderable by graphics APIs like WebGL, OpenGL,
and Vulkan. It’s designed to store detailed 3D model data, including
meshes (vertices, normals, textures, etc.), animations, materials, and
scene hierarchy, among other aspects.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **to_export** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Shape"><em>Shape</em></a>) – object or assembly

- **file_path** (*Union\[PathLike,* *str,* *bytes\]*) – glTF file path

- **unit** (*Unit,* *optional*) – shape units. Defaults to Unit.MM.

- **binary** (*bool,* *optional*) – output format. Defaults to False.

- **linear_deflection** (*float,* *optional*) – A linear deflection
  setting which limits the distance between a curve and its
  tessellation. Setting this value too low will result in large meshes
  that can consume computing resources. Setting the value too high can
  result in meshes with a level of detail that is too low. The default
  is a good starting point for a range of cases. Defaults to 1e-3.

- **angular_deflection** (*float,* *optional*) – Angular deflection
  setting which limits the angle between subsequent segments in a
  polyline. Defaults to 0.1.

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**RuntimeError** – Failed to write glTF file

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
write status

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
*bool*

<!-- -->

Exports a shape to a specified STL file.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **to_export** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Shape"><em>Shape</em></a>) – object or assembly

- **file_path** (*Union\[PathLike,* *str,* *bytes\]*) – The path and

- **tolerance** (*float,* *optional*) – A linear deflection setting

  meshes with a level of detail that is too low. The default is a good
  starting point for a range of cases. Defaults to 1e-3.

- **angular_tolerance** (*float,* *optional*) – Angular deflection
  setting which limits the angle between subsequent segments in a
  polyline. Defaults to 0.1.

- **ascii_format** (*bool,* *optional*) – Export the file as ASCII
  (True) or binary (False) STL format. Defaults to False (binary).

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
Success

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
*bool*

<div id="import_export.xhtml_d-mesh-export" class="section">

### 3D Mesh Export

Both 3MF and STL export (and import) are provided with the
<a href="#import_export.xhtml_mesher.Mesher"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="mesher.Mesher"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Mesher</code></span></a>
class. As mentioned above, the 3MF format it provides is feature-rich
and therefore has a slightly more complex API than the simple Shape
exporters.

For example:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    # Create the shapes and assign attributes
    blue_shape = Solid.make_cone(20, 0, 50)
    blue_shape.color = Color("blue")
    blue_shape.label = "blue"
    blue_uuid = uuid.uuid1()
    red_shape = Solid.make_cylinder(5, 50).move(Location((0, -30, 0)))
    red_shape.color = Color("red")
    red_shape.label = "red"

    # Create a Mesher instance as an exporter, add shapes and write
    exporter = Mesher()
    exporter.add_shape(blue_shape, part_number="blue-1234-5", uuid_value=blue_uuid)
    exporter.add_shape(red_shape)
    exporter.add_meta_data(
        name_space="custom",
        name="test_meta_data",
        value="hello world",
        metadata_type="str",
        must_preserve=False,
    )
    exporter.add_code_to_metadata()
    exporter.write("example.3mf")
    exporter.write("example.stl")

</div>

</div>

*<span class="pre">class</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">Mesher</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">unit:</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.build_enums.Unit</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">\<Unit.MM\></span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>  
Tool for exporting and importing meshed objects stored in 3MF or STL
files.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
**unit** (*Unit,* *optional*) – model units. Defaults to Unit.MM.

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">add_code_to_metadata</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span><span class="sig-paren">)</span>  
Add the code calling this method to the 3MF metadata with the custom
name space <cite>build123d</cite>, name equal to the base file name and
the type as <cite>python</cite>

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">add_meta_data</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">name_space</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">str</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">name</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">str</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">value</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">str</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">metadata_type</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">str</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">must_preserve</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">bool</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>  
Add meta data to the models

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **name_space** (*str*) – categorizer of different metadata entries

- **name** (*str*) – metadata label

- **value** (*str*) – metadata content

- **metadata_type** (*str*) – metadata type

- **must_preserve** (*bool*) – metadata must not be removed if unused

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">add_shape</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="pre">shape:</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.topology.shape_core.Shape</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">~collections.abc.Iterable\[~build123d.topology.shape_core.Shape\],</span> <span class="pre">linear_deflection:</span> <span class="pre">float</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">0.001,</span> <span class="pre">angular_deflection:</span> <span class="pre">float</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">0.1,</span> <span class="pre">mesh_type:</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.build_enums.MeshType</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">\<MeshType.MODEL\>,</span> <span class="pre">part_number:</span> <span class="pre">str</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">None</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">None,</span> <span class="pre">uuid_value:</span> <span class="pre">~uuid.UUID</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">None</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">None</span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>  
Add a shape to the 3MF/STL file.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **shape**
  (*Union\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Shape"><em>Shape</em></a>*,*
  *Iterable\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Shape"><em>Shape</em></a>*\]\]*) – build123d object

- **linear_deflection** (*float,* *optional*) – mesh control for edges.
  Defaults to 0.001.

- **angular_deflection** (*float,* *optional*) – mesh control for
  non-planar surfaces. Defaults to 0.1.

- **mesh_type** (*MeshType,* *optional*) – 3D printing use of mesh.
  Defaults to MeshType.MODEL.

- **part_number** (*str,* *optional*) – part \#. Defaults to None.

- **uuid_value** (*uuid,* *optional*) – value from uuid package.
  Defaults to None.

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **RuntimeError** – 3mf mesh is invalid

- **Warning** – Degenerate shape skipped

- **Warning** – 3mf mesh is not manifold

<div id="import_export.xhtml_d-mesh-import" class="section">

### 3D Mesh Import

Both 3MF and STL import (and export) are provided with the
<a href="#import_export.xhtml_mesher.Mesher"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="mesher.Mesher"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Mesher</code></span></a>
class.

For example:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    importer = Mesher()
    cone, cyl = importer.read("example.3mf")
    print(
        f"{importer.mesh_count=}, {importer.vertex_counts=}, {importer.triangle_counts=}"
    )
    print(f"Imported model unit: {importer.model_unit}")
    print(f"{cone.label=}")
    print(f"{cone.color.to_tuple()=}")
    print(f"{cyl.label=}")
    print(f"{cyl.color.to_tuple()=}")

</div>

</div>

<div class="highlight-none notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    importer.mesh_count=2, importer.vertex_counts=[66, 52], importer.triangle_counts=[128, 100]
    Imported model unit: Unit.MM
    cone.label='blue'
    cone.color.to_tuple()=(0.0, 0.0, 1.0, 1.0)
    cyl.label='red'
    cyl.color.to_tuple()=(1.0, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0)

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>

<span id="algebra_performance.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="algebra_performance.xhtml_performance-considerations-in-algebra-mode"
class="section">

<span id="algebra_performance.xhtml_algebra-performance"></span>

# Performance considerations in algebra mode

Creating lots of Shapes in a loop means for every step
<span class="pre">`fuse`</span> and <span class="pre">`clean`</span>
will be called. In an example like the below, both functions get slower
and slower the more objects are already fused. Overall it takes on an M1
Mac 4.76 sec.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    diam = 80
    holes = Sketch()
    r = Rectangle(2, 2)
    for loc in GridLocations(4, 4, 20, 20):
        if loc.position.X**2 + loc.position.Y**2 < (diam / 2 - 1.8) ** 2:
            holes += loc * r

    c = Circle(diam / 2) - holes

</div>

</div>

One way to avoid it is to use lazy evaluation for the algebra
operations. Just collect all objects and then call
<span class="pre">`fuse`</span> (<span class="pre">`+`</span>) once with
all objects and <span class="pre">`clean`</span> once. Overall it takes
0.19 sec.

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    r = Rectangle(2, 2)
    holes = [
        loc * r
        for loc in GridLocations(4, 4, 20, 20).locations
        if loc.position.X**2 + loc.position.Y**2 < (diam / 2 - 1.8) ** 2
    ]

    c = Circle(diam / 2) - holes

</div>

</div>

Another way to leverage the vectorized algebra operations is to add a
list comprehension of objects to an empty
<span class="pre">`Part`</span>, <span class="pre">`Sketch`</span> or
<span class="pre">`Curve`</span>:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    polygons = Sketch() + [
        loc * RegularPolygon(radius=5, side_count=5)
        for loc in GridLocations(40, 30, 2, 2)
    ]

</div>

</div>

This again ensures one single <span class="pre">`fuse`</span> and
<span class="pre">`clean`</span> call.

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="location_arithmetic.xhtml_location-arithmetic-for-algebra-mode"
class="section">

<span id="location_arithmetic.xhtml_location-arithmetics"></span>

# Location arithmetic for algebra mode

<div id="location_arithmetic.xhtml_position-a-shape-relative-to-the-xy-plane"
class="section">

## Position a shape relative to the XY plane

For the following use the helper function:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    def location_symbol(location: Location, scale: float = 1) -> Compound:
        return Compound.make_triad(axes_scale=scale).locate(location)

    def plane_symbol(plane: Plane, scale: float = 1) -> Compound:
        triad = Compound.make_triad(axes_scale=scale)
        circle = Circle(scale * .8).edge()
        return (triad + circle).locate(plane.location)

</div>

</div>

1.  **Positioning at a location**

    > <div>
    >
    > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
    >
    > <div class="highlight">
    >
    > </div>
    >
    > </div>
    >
    > loc = Location((0.1, 0.2, 0.3), (10, 20, 30))
    >
    > face = loc \* Rectangle(1, 2)
    >
    > show_object(face, name=”face”) show_object(location_symbol(loc),
    > name=”location”)
    >
    > </div>

![](_images/location-example-01.png)

2.  **Positioning on a plane**

    > <div>
    >
    > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
    >
    > <div class="highlight">
    >
    > </div>
    >
    > </div>
    >
    > plane = Plane.XZ
    >
    > face = plane \* Rectangle(1, 2)
    >
    > show_object(face, name=”face”) show_object(plane_symbol(plane),
    > name=”plane”)
    >
    > </div>

![](_images/location-example-07.png)

Note: The <span class="pre">`x`</span>-axis and the
<span class="pre">`y`</span>-axis of the plane are on the
<span class="pre">`x`</span>-axis and the
<span class="pre">`z`</span>-axis of the world coordinate system (red
and blue axis).

</div>

<div id="location_arithmetic.xhtml_relative-positioning-to-a-plane"
class="section">

## Relative positioning to a plane

1.  **Position an object on a plane relative to the plane**

    > <div>
    >
    > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
    >
    > <div class="highlight">
    >
    > </div>
    >
    > </div>
    >
    > loc = Location((0.1, 0.2, 0.3), (10, 20, 30))
    >
    > face = loc \* Rectangle(1,2)
    >
    > box = Plane(loc) \* Pos(0.2, 0.4, 0.1) \* Box(0.2, 0.2, 0.2) \#
    > box = Plane(face.location) \* Pos(0.2, 0.4, 0.1) \* Box(0.2, 0.2,
    > 0.2) \# box = loc \* Pos(0.2, 0.4, 0.1) \* Box(0.2, 0.2, 0.2)
    >
    > show_object(face, name=”face”) show_object(location_symbol(loc),
    > name=”location”) show_object(box, name=”box”)
    >
    > </div>

![](_images/location-example-02.png)

The <span class="pre">`X`</span>, <span class="pre">`Y`</span>,
<span class="pre">`Z`</span> components of
<span class="pre">`Pos(0.2,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`0.4,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`0.1)`</span>
are relative to the <span class="pre">`x`</span>-axis,
<span class="pre">`y`</span>-axis or <span class="pre">`z`</span>-axis
of the underlying location <span class="pre">`loc`</span>.

Note:
<span class="pre">`Plane(loc)`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>,
<span class="pre">`Plane(face.location)`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>
and <span class="pre">`loc`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span> are
equivalent in this example.

2.  **Rotate an object on a plane relative to the plane**

    > <div>
    >
    > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
    >
    > <div class="highlight">
    >
    > </div>
    >
    > </div>
    >
    > loc = Location((0.1, 0.2, 0.3), (10, 20, 30))
    >
    > face = loc \* Rectangle(1,2)
    >
    > box = Plane(loc) \* Rot(Z=80) \* Box(0.2, 0.2, 0.2)
    >
    > show_object(face, name=”face”) show_object(location_symbol(loc),
    > name=”location”) show_object(box, name=”box”)
    >
    > </div>

![](_images/location-example-03.png)

The box is rotated via <span class="pre">`Rot(Z=80)`</span> around the
<span class="pre">`z`</span>-axis of the underlying location (and not of
the z-axis of the world).

More general:

> <div>
>
> <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
>
> <div class="highlight">
>
> </div>
>
> </div>
>
> loc = Location((0.1, 0.2, 0.3), (10, 20, 30))
>
> face = loc \* Rectangle(1,2)
>
> box = loc \* Rot(20, 40, 80) \* Box(0.2, 0.2, 0.2)
>
> show_object(face, name=”face”) show_object(location_symbol(loc),
> name=”location”) show_object(box, name=”box”)
>
> </div>

![](_images/location-example-04.png)

The box is rotated via
<span class="pre">`Rot(20,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`40,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`80)`</span>
around all three axes relative to the plane.

3.  **Rotate and position an object relative to a location**

    > <div>
    >
    > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
    >
    > <div class="highlight">
    >
    > </div>
    >
    > </div>
    >
    > loc = Location((0.1, 0.2, 0.3), (10, 20, 30))
    >
    > face = loc \* Rectangle(1,2)
    >
    > box = loc \* Rot(20, 40, 80) \* Pos(0.2, 0.4, 0.1) \* Box(0.2,
    > 0.2, 0.2)
    >
    > show_object(face, name=”face”) show_object(location_symbol(loc),
    > name=”location”) show_object(box, name=”box”)
    > show_object(location_symbol(loc \* Rot(20, 40, 80), 0.5),
    > options={“color”:(0, 255, 255)}, name=”local_location”)
    >
    > </div>

![](_images/location-example-05.png)

The box is positioned via
<span class="pre">`Pos(0.2,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`0.4,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`0.1)`</span>
relative to the location
<span class="pre">`loc`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Rot(20,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`40,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`80)`</span>

4.  **Position and rotate an object relative to a location**

    > <div>
    >
    > <div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">
    >
    > <div class="highlight">
    >
    > </div>
    >
    > </div>
    >
    > loc = Location((0.1, 0.2, 0.3), (10, 20, 30))
    >
    > face = loc \* Rectangle(1,2)
    >
    > box = loc \* Pos(0.2, 0.4, 0.1) \* Rot(20, 40, 80) \* Box(0.2,
    > 0.2, 0.2)
    >
    > show_object(face, name=”face”) show_object(location_symbol(loc),
    > name=”location”) show_object(box, name=”box”)
    > show_object(location_symbol(loc \* Pos(0.2, 0.4, 0.1), 0.5),
    > options={“color”:(0, 255, 255)}, name=”local_location”)
    >
    > </div>

![](_images/location-example-06.png)

Note: This is the same as
<span class="pre">`box`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`loc`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Location((0.2,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`0.4,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`0.1),`</span>` `<span class="pre">`(20,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`40,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`80))`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Box(0.2,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`0.2,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`0.2)`</span>

</div>

</div>
