<span id="algebra_definition.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="algebra_definition.xhtml_algebraic-definition" class="section">

<span id="algebra_definition.xhtml_algebra-definition"></span>

# Algebraic definition

<div id="algebra_definition.xhtml_objects-and-arithmetic"
class="section">

## Objects and arithmetic

**Set definitions:**

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\C^3\\</span> is the set of
all <span class="pre">`Part`</span> objects <span class="pre">`p`</span>
with
<span class="pre">`p._dim`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`3`</span>

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\C^2\\</span> is the set of
all <span class="pre">`Sketch`</span> objects
<span class="pre">`s`</span> with
<span class="pre">`s._dim`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`2`</span>

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\C^1\\</span> is the set of
all <span class="pre">`Curve`</span> objects
<span class="pre">`c`</span> with
<span class="pre">`c._dim`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`1`</span>

**Neutral elements:**

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\c^3_0\\</span> is the empty
<span class="pre">`Part`</span> object
<span class="pre">`p0`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Part()`</span>
with
<span class="pre">`p0._dim`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`3`</span>
and
<span class="pre">`p0.wrapped`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`None`</span>

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\c^2_0\\</span> is the empty
<span class="pre">`Sketch`</span> object
<span class="pre">`s0`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Sketch()`</span>
with
<span class="pre">`s0._dim`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`2`</span>
and
<span class="pre">`s0.wrapped`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`None`</span>

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\c^1_0\\</span> is the empty
<span class="pre">`Curve`</span> object
<span class="pre">`c0`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Curve()`</span>
with
<span class="pre">`c0._dim`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`1`</span>
and
<span class="pre">`c0.wrapped`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`None`</span>

**Sets of predefined basic shapes:**

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\B^3 := \lbrace\\</span>
<span class="pre">`Part`</span>, <span class="pre">`Box`</span>,
<span class="pre">`Cylinder`</span>, <span class="pre">`Cone`</span>,
<span class="pre">`Sphere`</span>, <span class="pre">`Torus`</span>,
<span class="pre">`Wedge`</span>, <span class="pre">`Hole`</span>,
<span class="pre">`CounterBoreHole`</span>,
<span class="pre">`CounterSinkHole`</span>
<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\rbrace\\</span>

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\B^2 := \lbrace\\</span>
<span class="pre">`Sketch`</span>, <span class="pre">`Rectangle`</span>,
<span class="pre">`Circle`</span>, <span class="pre">`Ellipse`</span>,
<span class="pre">`Rectangle`</span>,
<span class="pre">`Polygon`</span>,
<span class="pre">`RegularPolygon`</span>,
<span class="pre">`Text`</span>, <span class="pre">`Trapezoid`</span>,
<span class="pre">`SlotArc`</span>,
<span class="pre">`SlotCenterPoint`</span>,
<span class="pre">`SlotCenterToCenter`</span>,
<span class="pre">`SlotOverall`</span>
<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\rbrace\\</span>

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\B^1 := \lbrace\\</span>
<span class="pre">`Curve`</span>, <span class="pre">`Bezier`</span>,
<span class="pre">`FilletPolyline`</span>,
<span class="pre">`PolarLine`</span>,
<span class="pre">`Polyline`</span>, <span class="pre">`Spline`</span>,
<span class="pre">`Helix`</span>, <span class="pre">`CenterArc`</span>,
<span class="pre">`EllipticalCenterArc`</span>,
<span class="pre">`ParabolicCenterArc`</span>,
<span class="pre">`HyperbolicCenterArc`</span>,
<span class="pre">`RadiusArc`</span>,
<span class="pre">`SagittaArc`</span>,
<span class="pre">`TangentArc`</span>,
<span class="pre">`ThreePointArc`</span>,
<span class="pre">`JernArc`</span>
<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\rbrace\\</span>

with <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\B^3 \subset C^3, B^2
\subset C^2\\</span> and
<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\B^1 \subset C^1\\</span>

**Operations:**

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\+: C^n \times C^n
\rightarrow C^n\\</span> with
<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\(a,b) \mapsto a +
b\\</span>, <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\\\\</span> for
<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\n=1,2,3\\</span>

> <div>
>
> <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\\ a + b :=\\</span>
> <span class="pre">`a.fuse(b)`</span> for each operation
>
> </div>

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\-: C^n \rightarrow
C^n\\</span> with <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\a \mapsto
-a\\</span>, <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\\\\</span>
for <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\n=1,2,3\\</span>

> <div>
>
> <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\\ b + (-a) :=\\</span>
> <span class="pre">`b.cut(a)`</span> for each operation (implicit
> definition)
>
> </div>

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\\: C^n \times C^n
\rightarrow C^n\\</span> with
<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\(a,b) \mapsto a \\ \\ \\
b\\</span>, <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\\\\</span> for
<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\n=2,3\\</span>

> <div>
>
> <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\\ a \\ \\ \\ b
> :=\\</span> <span class="pre">`a.intersect(b)`</span> for each
> operation
>
> - <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\\\\</span> is not
>   defined for
>   <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\n=1\\</span> in
>   build123d
>
> - The following relationship holds:
>   <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\a \\ \\ \\ b =
>   (a + b) + -(a + (-b)) + -(b + (-a))\\</span>
>
> </div>

**Abelian groups**

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\( C^n, \\ c^n_0, \\ +, \\
-)\\</span> <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\\\\</span> are
abelian groups for
<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\n=1,2,3\\</span>.

- The implementation
  <span class="pre">`a`</span>` `<span class="pre">`-`</span>` `<span class="pre">`b`</span>` `<span class="pre">`=`</span>` `<span class="pre">`a.cut(b)`</span>
  needs to be read as <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\a +
  (-b)\\</span> since the group does not have a binary
  <span class="pre">`-`</span> operation. As such,
  <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\a - (b - c) = a + -(b +
  -c)) \ne a - b + c\\</span>

- This definition also includes that neither
  <span class="pre">`-`</span> nor <span class="pre">`&`</span> are
  commutative.

</div>

<div id="algebra_definition.xhtml_locations-planes-and-location-arithmetic"
class="section">

## Locations, planes and location arithmetic

**Set definitions:**

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\L := \lbrace\\</span>
<span class="pre">`Location((x,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`y,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`z),`</span>` `<span class="pre">`(a,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`b,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`c))`</span>
<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\: x,y,z \in R \land a,b,c
\in R \rbrace\\\\</span>

> <div>
>
> with <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\a,b,c\\</span> being
> angles in degrees.
>
> </div>

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\P := \lbrace\\</span>
<span class="pre">`Plane(o,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`x,`</span>` `<span class="pre">`z)`</span>
<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\: o,x,z ∈ R^3 \land \\x\\ =
\\z\\ = 1\rbrace\\</span>

> <div>
>
> with <span class="pre">`o`</span> being the origin and
> <span class="pre">`x`</span>, <span class="pre">`z`</span> the x- and
> z-direction of the plane.
>
> </div>

Neutral element: <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\\ l_0 \in
L\\</span>: <span class="pre">`Location()`</span>

**Operations:**

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\*: L \times L \rightarrow
L\\</span> with <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\(l_1,l_2)
\mapsto l_1 \* l_2\\</span>

> <div>
>
> <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\\ l_1 \* l_2 :=\\</span>
> <span class="pre">`l1`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`l2`</span>
> (multiply two locations)
>
> </div>

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\*: P \times L \rightarrow
P\\</span> with <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\(p,l)
\mapsto p \* l\\</span>

> <div>
>
> <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\\ p \* l :=\\</span>
> <span class="pre">`Plane(p.location`</span>` `<span class="pre">`*`</span>` `<span class="pre">`l)`</span>
> (move plane <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\p \in
> P\\</span> to location <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\l
> \in L\\</span>)
>
> </div>

Inverse element: <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\\ l^{-1}
\in L\\</span>: <span class="pre">`l.inverse()`</span>

**Placing objects onto planes**

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\*: P \times C^n
\rightarrow C^n \\\\</span> with
<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\(p,c) \mapsto p \*
c\\</span>, <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\\\\</span> for
<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\n=1,2,3\\</span>

> <div>
>
> Locate an object <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\c \in
> C^n\\</span> onto plane <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\p
> \in P\\</span>, i.e. <span class="pre">`c.moved(p.location)`</span>
>
> </div>

**Placing objects at locations**

<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\*: L \times C^n
\rightarrow C^n \\\\</span> with
<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\(l,c) \mapsto l \*
c\\</span>, <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\\\\\</span> for
<span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\n=1,2,3\\</span>

> <div>
>
> Locate an object <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\c \in
> C^n\\</span> at location
> <span class="math notranslate nohighlight">\\l \in L\\</span>, i.e.
> <span class="pre">`c.moved(l)`</span>
>
> </div>

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<span id="center.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="center.xhtml_cad-object-centers" class="section">

# CAD Object Centers

Finding the center of a CAD object is a surprisingly complex operation.
To illustrate let’s consider two examples: a simple isosceles triangle
and a curved line (their bounding boxes are shown with dashed lines):

<img src="_images/center.svg" style="width: 49%;"
alt="_images/center.svg" />
<img src="_images/one_d_center.svg" style="width: 49%;"
alt="_images/one_d_center.svg" />

One can see that there is are significant differences between the
different types of centers. To allow the designer to choose the center
that makes the most sense for the given shape there are three possible
values for the
<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.CenterOf"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_enums.CenterOf"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">CenterOf</code></span></a>
Enum:

| <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.CenterOf"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_enums.CenterOf"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">CenterOf</code></span></a> | Symbol | 1D | 2D | 3D | Compound |
|----|----|----|----|----|----|
| CenterOf.BOUNDING_BOX | □ | ✓ | ✓ | ✓ | ✓ |
| CenterOf.GEOMETRY | △ | ✓ | ✓ |  |  |
| CenterOf.MASS | ○ | ✓ | ✓ | ✓ | ✓ |

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<span id="debugging_logging.xhtml"></span>

<div class="body" role="main">

<div id="debugging_logging.xhtml_debugging-logging" class="section">

# Debugging & Logging

Debugging problems with your build123d design involves the same
techniques one would use to debug any Python source code; however, there
are some specific techniques that might be of assistance. The following
sections describe these techniques.

<div id="debugging_logging.xhtml_python-debugger" class="section">

## Python Debugger

Many Python IDEs have step by step debugging systems that can be used to
walk through your code monitoring its operation with full visibility of
all Python objects. Here is a screenshot of the Visual Studio Code
debugger in action:

<img src="_images/VSC_debugger.png" class="align-center"
alt="_images/VSC_debugger.png" />

This shows that a break-point has been encountered and the code
operation has been stopped. From here all of the Python variables are
visible and the system is waiting on input from the user on how to
proceed. One can enter the code that assigns
<span class="pre">`top_face`</span> by pressing the down arrow button on
the top right. Following code execution like this is a very powerful
debug technique.

</div>

<div id="debugging_logging.xhtml_logging" class="section">

## Logging

Build123d support standard python logging and generates its own log
stream. If one is using **cq-editor** as a display system there is a
built in
<span class="pre">`Log`</span>` `<span class="pre">`viewer`</span> tab
that shows the current log stream - here is an example of a log stream:

<div class="highlight-bash notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    [18:43:44.678646] INFO: Entering BuildPart with mode=Mode.ADD which is in different scope as parent
    [18:43:44.679233] INFO: WorkplaneList is pushing 1 workplanes: [Plane(o=(0.00, 0.00, 0.00), x=(1.00, 0.00, 0.00), z=(0.00, 0.00, 1.00))]
    [18:43:44.679888] INFO: LocationList is pushing 1 points: [(p=(0.00, 0.00, 0.00), o=(-0.00, 0.00, -0.00))]
    [18:43:44.681751] INFO: BuildPart context requested by Box
    [18:43:44.685950] INFO: Completed integrating 1 object(s) into part with Mode=Mode.ADD
    [18:43:44.690072] INFO: GridLocations is pushing 4 points: [(p=(-30.00, -20.00, 0.00), o=(-0.00, 0.00, -0.00)), (p=(-30.00, 20.00, 0.00), o=(-0.00, 0.00, -0.00)), (p=(30.00, -20.00, 0.00), o=(-0.00, 0.00, -0.00)), (p=(30.00, 20.00, 0.00), o=(-0.00, 0.00, -0.00))]
    [18:43:44.691604] INFO: BuildPart context requested by Hole
    [18:43:44.724628] INFO: Completed integrating 4 object(s) into part with Mode=Mode.SUBTRACT
    [18:43:44.728681] INFO: GridLocations is popping 4 points
    [18:43:44.747358] INFO: BuildPart context requested by chamfer
    [18:43:44.762429] INFO: Completed integrating 1 object(s) into part with Mode=Mode.REPLACE
    [18:43:44.765380] INFO: LocationList is popping 1 points
    [18:43:44.766106] INFO: WorkplaneList is popping 1 workplanes
    [18:43:44.766729] INFO: Exiting BuildPart

</div>

</div>

The build123d logger is defined by:

<div class="highlight-python notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    logging.getLogger("build123d").addHandler(logging.NullHandler())
    logger = logging.getLogger("build123d")

</div>

</div>

To export logs to a file, the following configuration is recommended:

<div class="highlight-python notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    logging.basicConfig(
        filename="myapp.log",
        level=logging.INFO,
        format="%(name)s-%(levelname)s %(asctime)s - [%(filename)s:%(lineno)s - \
        %(funcName)20s() ] - %(message)s",
    )

</div>

</div>

Logs can be easily placed in your code - here is an example:

<div class="highlight-python notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    logger.info("Exiting %s", type(self).__name__)

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div id="debugging_logging.xhtml_printing" class="section">

## Printing

Sometimes the best debugging aid is just placing a print statement in
your code. Many of the build123d classes are setup to provide useful
information beyond their class and location in memory, as follows:

<div class="highlight-build123d notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    plane = Plane.XY.offset(1)
    print(f"{plane=}")

</div>

</div>

<div class="highlight-bash notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    plane=Plane(o=(0.00, 0.00, 1.00), x=(1.00, 0.00, 0.00), z=(0.00, 0.00, 1.00))

</div>

</div>

which shows the origin, x direction, and z direction of the plane.

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_external-tools-and-libraries" class="section">

<span id="external.xhtml_external"></span>

# External Tools and Libraries

The following sections describe tools and libraries external to
build123d that extend its functionality.

<div id="external.xhtml_editors-viewers" class="section">

## Editors & Viewers

<div id="external.xhtml_ocp-vscode" class="section">

### ocp-vscode

A viewer for OCP based Code-CAD (CadQuery, build123d) integrated into VS
Code.

See: <a href="https://github.com/bernhard-42/vscode-ocp-cad-viewer"
class="reference external">ocp-vscode</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/bernhard-42/vscode-ocp-cad-viewer\]</span>
(formerly known as cq_vscode)

Watch Jern create three build123d designs in realtime with Visual Studio
Code and the ocp-vscode viewer extension in a timed event from the
TooTallToby 2024 Spring Open Tournament:
<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UhUmMInlJic"
class="reference external">build123d entry video</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UhUmMInlJic\]</span>

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_cq-editor-fork" class="section">

### cq-editor fork

GUI editor based on PyQT. This fork has changes from jdegenstein to
allow easier use with build123d.

See: <a href="https://github.com/jdegenstein/jmwright-CQ-Editor"
class="reference external">jdegenstein’s fork of cq-editor</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/jdegenstein/jmwright-CQ-Editor\]</span>

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_yet-another-cad-viewer" class="section">

### Yet Another CAD Viewer

A web-based CAD viewer for OCP models (CadQuery/build123d) that runs in
any modern browser and supports static site deployment. Features include
interactive inspection of faces, edges, and vertices, measurement tools,
per-model clipping planes, transparency control, and hot reloading via
<span class="pre">`yacv-server`</span>. It also has a build123d
playground for editing and sharing models directly in the browser (<a
href="https://yeicor-3d.github.io/yet-another-cad-viewer/#pg_code_url=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/gumyr/build123d/refs/heads/dev/examples/toy_truck.py"
class="reference external">demo</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://yeicor-3d.github.io/yet-another-cad-viewer/#pg_code_url=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/gumyr/build123d/refs/heads/dev/examples/toy_truck.py\]</span>).

See: <a href="https://github.com/yeicor-3d/yet-another-cad-viewer"
class="reference external">Yet Another CAD Viewer</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/yeicor-3d/yet-another-cad-viewer\]</span>

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_partcad-vs-code-extension" class="section">

### PartCAD VS Code extension

A wrapper around <span class="pre">`ocp-vscode`</span> (see above) which
requires build123d scripts to be packaged using
<span class="pre">`PartCAD`</span> (see below). While it requires the
overhead of maintaining the package, it provides some convenience
features (such as UI controls to export models) as well as functional
features (such as UI controls to pass parameters into build123d scripts
and AI-based generative design tools).

It’s also the most convenient tool to create new packages and parts.
More PDM and PLM features are expected to arrive soon.

</div>

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_part-libraries" class="section">

## Part Libraries

<div id="external.xhtml_bd-warehouse" class="section">

### bd_warehouse

On-demand generation of parametric parts that seamlessly integrate into
build123d projects.

Parts available include:

> <div>
>
> - fastener - Nuts, Screws, Washers and custom holes
>
> - flange - Standardized parametric flanges
>
> - pipe - Standardized parametric pipes
>
> - thread - Parametric helical threads (Iso, Acme, Plastic, etc.)
>
> </div>

See: <a href="https://bd-warehouse.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html"
class="reference external">bd_warehouse</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://bd-warehouse.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html\]</span>

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_bd-beams-and-bars" class="section">

### bd_beams_and_bars

2D sections and 3D beams generation (UPN, IPN, UPE, flat bars, …)

See: <a href="https://bd-beams-and-bars.3d.experimentslabs.com/"
class="reference external">bd_beams_and_bars</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://bd-beams-and-bars.3d.experimentslabs.com/\]</span>

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_superellipses-superellipsoids" class="section">

### Superellipses & Superellipsoids

Superellipses are a more sophisticated alternative to rounded
rectangles, with smoothly changing curvature. They are flexible shapes
that can be adjusted by changing the “exponent” to get a result that
varies between rectangular and elliptical, or from square, through
squircle, to circle, and beyond…

Superellipses can be found:

> <div>
>
> - in typefaces such as Melior, Eurostyle, and Computer Modern
>
> - as the shape of airliner windows, tables, plates
>
> - clipping the outline of iOS app icons
>
> </div>

They were named and popularized in the 1950s-1960s by the Danish
mathematician and poet Piet Hein, who used them in the winning design
for the Sergels Torg roundabout in Stockholm.

See: <a
href="https://github.com/fanf2/kbd/blob/model-b/keybird42/superellipse.py"
class="reference external">Superellipses &amp; Superellipsoids</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/fanf2/kbd/blob/model-b/keybird42/superellipse.py\]</span>

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_public-partcad-repository" class="section">

### Public PartCAD repository

See <a href="https://partcad.org/repository"
class="reference external">partcad.org</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://partcad.org/repository\]</span> for all the models packaged
and published using <span class="pre">`PartCAD`</span> (see below). This
repository contains individual parts, as well as large assemblies
created using those parts. See <a
href="https://partcad.org/repository/package/robotics/multimodal/openvmp/robots/don1"
class="reference external">the OpenVMP robot</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://partcad.org/repository/package/robotics/multimodal/openvmp/robots/don1\]</span>
as an example of an assembly

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_gggears-generator" class="section">

### gggears generator

A gear generation framework that allows easy creation of a wide range of
gears and drives.

See <a href="https://github.com/GarryBGoode/gggears"
class="reference external">gggears</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/GarryBGoode/gggears\]</span>

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_bd-vslot" class="section">

### bd_vslot

A library of V-Slot linear rail components, including V-Slot rails.

See: <a href="https://bd-vslot.readthedocs.io"
class="reference external">bd_vslot</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://bd-vslot.readthedocs.io\]</span>

</div>

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_tools" class="section">

## Tools

<div id="external.xhtml_blendquery" class="section">

### blendquery

CadQuery and build123d integration for Blender.

See: <a href="https://github.com/uki-dev/blendquery"
class="reference external">blendquery</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/uki-dev/blendquery\]</span>

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_nething" class="section">

### nething

3D generative AI for CAD modeling. Now everyone is an engineer. Make
your ideas real.

See:
<a href="https://nething.xyz/" class="reference external">nething</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://nething.xyz/\]</span>

Listen to the following podcast which discusses **nething** in detail:
<a
href="https://pod.link/wevolver/episode/74b11c1ff2bfc977adc96e5c7b4cd162"
class="reference external">The Next Byte Podcast</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://pod.link/wevolver/episode/74b11c1ff2bfc977adc96e5c7b4cd162\]</span>

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_ocp-freecad-cam" class="section">

### ocp-freecad-cam

CAM for CadQuery and Build123d by leveraging FreeCAD library. Visualizes
in CQ-Editor and ocp-cad-viewer. Spiritual successor of
<a href="https://github.com/voneiden/cq-cam"
class="reference external">cq-cam</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/voneiden/cq-cam\]</span>

See: <a href="https://github.com/voneiden/ocp-freecad-cam"
class="reference external">ocp-freecad-cam</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/voneiden/ocp-freecad-cam\]</span>

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_partcad" class="section">

### PartCAD

A package manager for CAD models. Build123d is the most supported
Code-CAD framework, but CadQuery and OpenSCAD are also supported. It can
be used by build123d designs <a
href="https://partcad.readthedocs.io/en/latest/use_cases.html#python-build123d"
class="reference external">to import parts</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://partcad.readthedocs.io/en/latest/use_cases.html#python-build123d\]</span>
from PartCAD repositories, and to <a
href="https://partcad.readthedocs.io/en/latest/use_cases.html#publish-packages"
class="reference external">publish build123d designs</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://partcad.readthedocs.io/en/latest/use_cases.html#publish-packages\]</span>
to be consumed by others.

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_dl4to4ocp" class="section">

### dl4to4ocp

Library that helps perform
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topology_optimization"
class="reference external">topology optimization</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topology_optimization\]</span> on your
<a href="https://github.com/CadQuery/OCP"
class="reference external">OCP</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/CadQuery/OCP\]</span>-based CAD models
(<a href="https://github.com/CadQuery/cadquery"
class="reference external">CadQuery</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/CadQuery/cadquery\]</span>/<a href="https://github.com/gumyr/build123d"
class="reference external">Build123d</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/gumyr/build123d\]</span>/…) using the
<a href="https://github.com/dl4to/dl4to"
class="reference external">dl4to</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/dl4to/dl4to\]</span> library.

See: <a href="https://github.com/yeicor-3d/dl4to4ocp/"
class="reference external">dl4to4ocp</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/yeicor-3d/dl4to4ocp/\]</span>

</div>

<div id="external.xhtml_ocp-wasm" class="section">

### OCP.wasm

This project ports the low-level dependencies required for build123d to
run in a browser. For a fully featured frontend, check out
<span class="pre">`Yet`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Another`</span>` `<span class="pre">`CAD`</span>` `<span class="pre">`Viewer`</span>
(see above).

See: <a href="https://github.com/yeicor/OCP.wasm"
class="reference external">OCP.wasm</a><span class="link-target">
\[https://github.com/yeicor/OCP.wasm\]</span>

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div class="clearer">

</div>

</div>

<div id="builder_api_reference.xhtml_builder-common-api-reference"
class="section">

<span id="builder_api_reference.xhtml_builder-api-reference"></span>

# Builder Common API Reference

The following are common to all the builders.

  else the radius is the minor radius (also known as inscribed radius).
  Defaults to False.

  (*Union\[*<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Align"

Location Context: Polar Array

Creates a context of polar array of locations for Part or Sketch

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **radius** (*float*) – array radius

- **count** (*int*) – Number of points to push

- **start_angle** (*float,* *optional*) – angle to first point from +ve
  X axis. Defaults to 0.0.

- **angular_range** (*float,* *optional*) – magnitude of array from
  start angle. Defaults to 360.0.

- **rotate** (*bool,* *optional*) – Align locations with arc tangents.
  Defaults to True.

- **endpoint** (*bool,* *optional*) – If True,
  <cite>start_angle</cite> + <cite>angular_range</cite> is the last
  sample. Otherwise, it is not included. Defaults to False.

Variables<span class="colon">:</span>  
**local_locations** (*list{Location}*) – locations relative to workplane

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**ValueError** – Count must be greater than or equal to 1

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">local_locations</span></span>  
values independent of workplanes

<div id="direct_api_reference.xhtml_direct-api-reference"
class="section">

# Direct API Reference

The Direct API is an interface layer between the primary user interface
API (the Builders) and the OpenCascade (OCCT) API. This API is based on
the CadQuery Direct API (thank you to all of the CadQuery contributors
that made this possible) with the following major changes:

- PEP8 compliance

- New Axis class

- New ShapeList class enabling sorting and filtering of shape objects

- Literal strings replaced with Enums

<div id="direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometric-objects" class="section">

parameters to the CAD objects described in the following section are
frequently of these types.

are axes skew

Returns True if this axis and another axis are skew, meaning they are
neither parallel nor coplanar. Two axes are skew if they do not lie in
the same plane and never intersect.

Mathematically, this means:

- The axes are **not parallel** (the cross product of their direction
  vectors is nonzero).

- The axes are **not coplanar** (the vector between their positions is
  not aligned with the plane spanned by their directions).

If either condition is false (i.e., the axes are parallel or coplanar),
they are not skew.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **other** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Axis"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="geometry.Axis"><em>Axis</em></a>) – axis to compare to

- **tolerance** (*float,* *optional*) – max deviation. Defaults to 1e-5.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
axes are skew

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
*bool*

class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Color"><span class="pre">Color</span></a><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span></span></span>  
Generate a palette of evenly spaced colors.

Creates a list of visually distinct colors suitable for representing
discrete categories (such as different parts, assemblies, or data
series). Colors are evenly spaced around the hue circle and share
consistent lightness and saturation levels, resulting in balanced
perceptual contrast across all hues.

Produces palettes similar in appearance to the **Tableau 10** and **D3
Category10** color sets—both widely recognized standards in data
visualization for their clarity and accessibility. These values have
been empirically chosen to maintain consistent perceived brightness
across hues while avoiding overly vivid or dark colors.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **color_count** (*int*) – Number of colors to generate.

- **starting_hue** (*ColorLike* *\|* *float*) – Either a Color-like
  object or a hue value in the range \[0.0, 1.0\] that defines the
  starting color.

- **alpha** (*float* *\|* *Iterable\[float\]*) – Alpha value(s) for the
  colors. Can be a single float or an iterable of length
  <cite>color_count</cite>.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
List of generated colors.

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
*list*\[<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Color"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Color"><em>Color</em></a>\]

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**ValueError** – If starting_hue is out of range or alpha length
mismatch.

class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Location"><span class="pre">Location</span></a></span></span>  
Return a new Location mirrored across the given plane.

This method reflects both the position and orientation of the current
Location across the specified mirror_plane using affine vector
mathematics.

Due to the mathematical properties of reflection:  
- The true mirror of a right-handed coordinate system is a *left-handed*
  one.

However, <cite>build123d</cite> requires all coordinate systems to be
right-handed. Therefore, this implementation: - Reflects the X and Z
directions across the mirror plane - Recomputes the Y direction as:
<cite>Y = X × Z</cite>

This ensures the resulting Location maintains a valid right-handed
frame, while remaining as close as possible to the geometric mirror.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
**mirror_plane** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Plane"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Plane"><em>Plane</em></a>) – The plane to mirror across.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
A new mirrored Location that preserves right-handedness.

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Location"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Location"><em>Location</em></a>

    with open("sample.json", "w") as outfile:

*<span class="pre">class</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">Matrix</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="o"><span class="pre">\*</span></span><span class="n"><span class="pre">args</span></span>*, *<span class="o"><span class="pre">\*\*</span></span><span class="n"><span class="pre">kwargs</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>  
A 3d , 4x4 transformation matrix.

Used to move geometry in space.

The provided “matrix” parameter may be None, a gp_GTrsf, or a nested
list of values.

If given a nested list, it is expected to be of the form:

> <div>
>
> \[\[m11, m12, m13, m14\],  
> \[m21, m22, m23, m24\], \[m31, m32, m33, m34\]\]
>
> </div>

A fourth row may be given, but it is expected to be: \[0.0, 0.0, 0.0,
1.0\] since this is a transform matrix.

**wrapped** (*gp_GTrsf*) – the OCP transformation function

*<span class="pre">class</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">Plane</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="o"><span class="pre">\*</span></span><span class="n"><span class="pre">args</span></span>*, *<span class="o"><span class="pre">\*\*</span></span><span class="n"><span class="pre">kwargs</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>  
A plane is positioned in space with a coordinate system such that the
plane is defined by the origin, x_dir (X direction), y_dir (Y
direction), and z_dir (Z direction) of this coordinate system, which is
the “local coordinate system” of the plane. The z_dir is a vector normal
to the plane. The coordinate system is right-handed.

A plane allows the use of local 2D coordinates, which are later
converted to global, 3d coordinates when the operations are complete.

Planes can be created from faces as workplanes for feature creation on
objects.

| Name      | x_dir | y_dir  | z_dir  |
|-----------|-------|--------|--------|
| XY        | +x    | +y     | +z     |
| YZ        | +y    | +z     | +x     |
| ZX        | +z    | +x     | +y     |
| XZ        | +x    | +z     | -y     |
| YX        | +y    | +x     | -z     |
| ZY        | +z    | +y     | -x     |
| front     | +x    | +z     | -y     |
| back      | -x    | +z     | +y     |
| left      | -y    | +z     | -x     |
| right     | +y    | +z     | +x     |
| top       | +x    | +y     | +z     |
| bottom    | +x    | -y     | -z     |
| isometric | +x+y  | -x+y+z | +x+y-z |

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **gp_pln** (*gp_Pln*) – an OCCT plane object

- **origin** (*tuple\[float,* *float,* *float\]* *\|*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Vector"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="geometry.Vector"><em>Vector</em></a>) – the origin in global
  coordinates

- **x_dir** (*tuple\[float,* *float,* *float\]* *\|*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Vector"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="geometry.Vector"><em>Vector</em></a> *\|* *None*) – an optional
  vector representing the X Direction. Defaults to None.

- **z_dir** (*tuple\[float,* *float,* *float\]* *\|*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Vector"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="geometry.Vector"><em>Vector</em></a> *\|* *None*) – the normal
  direction for the plane. Defaults to (0, 0, 1).

Variables<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **origin** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Vector"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="geometry.Vector"><em>Vector</em></a>) – global position of
  local (0,0,0) point

- **x_dir** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Vector"

Returns a copy of this plane, rotated about the specified axes

The origin of the workplane is unaffected by the rotation.

Rotations are done in order x, y, z. If you need a different order,
specify ordering. e.g. Intrinsic.ZYX changes rotation to (z angle, y
angle, x angle) and rotates in that order.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **rotation** (*VectorLike,* *optional*) – (x angle, y angle, z angle).
  Defaults to (0, 0, 0)

- **ordering** (*Intrinsic* *\|* *Extrinsic,* *optional*) – order of
  rotations in Intrinsic or Extrinsic rotation mode. Defaults to
  Intrinsic.XYZ

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
a copy of this plane rotated as requested.

<div id="direct_api_reference.xhtml_topological-objects"
class="section">

## Topological Objects

The topological object classes defined by build123d are defined below.

Note that the <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Mixin1D"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Mixin1D"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Mixin1D</code></span></a>
and <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Mixin3D"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Mixin3D"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Mixin3D</code></span></a>
classes add supplementary functionality specific to 1D
(<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Edge"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Edge"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Edge</code></span></a>
and <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Wire"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Wire"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Wire</code></span></a>)
and 3D (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Compound"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Compound"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Compound</code></span></a>
and <cite>~topology.Solid</cite>) objects respectively. Note that a
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Compound"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Compound"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Compound</code></span></a>
may be contain only 1D, 2D
(<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Face"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-class docutils literal notranslate">Face</code></span></a>)
or 3D objects.

A Compound in build123d is a topological entity representing a
collection of geometric shapes grouped together within a single
structure. It serves as a container for organizing diverse shapes like
edges, faces, or solids. This hierarchical arrangement facilitates the
construction of complex models by combining simpler shapes. Compound
plays a pivotal role in managing the composition and structure of
intricate 3D models in computer-aided design (CAD) applications,
allowing engineers and designers to work with assemblies of shapes as
unified entities for efficient modeling and analysis.

class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.composite.Compound"><span
class="pre">Compound</span></a></span></span>  
Text that optionally follows a path.

The text that is created can be combined as with other sketch features
by specifying a mode or rotated by the given angle. In addition, edges
have been previously created with arc or segment, the text will follow
the path defined by these edges. The start parameter can be used to
shift the text along the path to achieve precise positioning.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **txt** (*str*) – text to render

- **font_size** (*float*) – size of the font in model units

- **font** (*str,* *optional*) – font name. Defaults to “Arial”

- **font_path** (*str,* *optional*) – system path to font file. Defaults
  to None

- **font_style** (*Font_Style,* *optional*) – font style, REGULAR, BOLD,
  BOLDITALIC, or ITALIC. Defaults to Font_Style.REGULAR

- **text_align** (*tuple\[TextAlign,* *TextAlign\],* *optional*) –
  horizontal text align LEFT, CENTER, or RIGHT. Vertical text align
  BOTTOM, CENTER, TOP, or TOPFIRSTLINE. Defaults to (TextAlign.CENTER,
  TextAlign.CENTER)

- **align** (<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Align"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_enums.Align"><em>Align</em></a> *\|*
  *tuple\[*<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Align"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_enums.Align"><em>Align</em></a>*,*
  <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Align"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_enums.Align"><em>Align</em></a>*\],* *optional*) – align
  MIN, CENTER, or MAX of object. Defaults to None

- **position_on_path** (*float,* *optional*) – the relative location on
  path to position the text, values must be between 0.0 and 1.0.
  Defaults to 0.0

- **text_path** – (Edge \| Wire, optional): path for text to follow.
  Defaults to None Compound object containing multiple Shapes
  representing the text

- **single_line_width** (*float*) – width of outlined single line font.
  Defaults to 0.0

Examples:

<div class="highlight-default notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    fox = Compound.make_text(
        txt="The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog",
        font_size=10,
        position_on_path=0.1,
        text_path=jump_edge,
    )

</div>

</div>

An Edge in build123d is a fundamental element in the topological data
structure representing a one-dimensional geometric entity within a 3D
model. It encapsulates information about a curve, which could be a line,
arc, or other parametrically defined shape. Edge is crucial in for
precise modeling and manipulation of curves, facilitating operations
like filleting, chamfering, and Boolean operations. It serves as a
building block for constructing complex structures, such as wires and
faces.

and last control points represent the start and end of the curve
respectively. If weights are provided, there must be one provided for
each control point.

- **weights** (*list\[float\],* *optional*) – control point weights
  list. Defaults to None.

- **ValueError** – Too few control points

- **ValueError** – Too many control points

- **ValueError** – A weight is required for each control point

bezier curve

make ellipse

Makes an ellipse centered at the origin of plane.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **x_radius** (*float*) – x radius of the ellipse (along the x-axis of
  plane)

- **y_radius** (*float*) – y radius of the ellipse (along the y-axis of
  plane)

- **plane** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Plane"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="geometry.Plane"><em>Plane</em></a>*,* *optional*) – base plane.
  Defaults to Plane.XY.

- **start_angle** (*float,* *optional*) – Defaults to 360.0.

- **end_angle** (*float,* *optional*) – Defaults to 360.0.

- **angular_direction** (*AngularDirection,* *optional*) – arc
  direction. Defaults to AngularDirection.COUNTER_CLOCKWISE.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
full or partial ellipse

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>

title="topology.one_d.Wire"><span class="pre">Wire</span></a></span></span>  
Make a helix with a given pitch, height and radius. By default a
cylindrical surface is used to create the helix. If the :angle: is set
(the apex given in degree) a conical surface is used instead.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **pitch** (*float*) – distance per revolution along normal

- **height** (*float*) – total height

- **radius** (*float*)

- **center** (*VectorLike,* *optional*) – Defaults to (0, 0, 0).

- **normal** (*VectorLike,* *optional*) – Defaults to (0, 0, 1).

- **angle** (*float,* *optional*) – conical angle. Defaults to 0.0.

- **lefthand** (*bool,* *optional*) – Defaults to False.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
helix

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Wire"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Wire"><em>Wire</em></a>

Spline

Interpolate a spline through the provided points.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **points** (*list\[VectorLike\]*) – the points defining the spline

- **tangents** (*list\[VectorLike\],* *optional*) – start and finish
  tangent. Defaults to None.

- **periodic** (*bool,* *optional*) – creation of periodic curves.
  Defaults to False.

- **parameters** (*list\[float\],* *optional*) – the value of the
  parameter at each interpolation point. (The interpolated curve is
  represented as a vector-valued function of a scalar parameter.) If
  periodic == True, then len(parameters) must be len(interpolation
  points) + 1, otherwise len(parameters) must be equal to
  len(interpolation points). Defaults to None.

- **scale** (*bool,* *optional*) – whether to scale the specified
  tangent vectors before interpolating. Each tangent is scaled, so it’s
  length is equal to the derivative of the Lagrange interpolated curve.
  I.e., set this to True, if you want to use only the direction of the
  tangent vectors specified by <cite>tangents</cite> , but not their
  magnitude. Defaults to True.

- **tol** (*float,* *optional*) – tolerance of the algorithm (consult
  OCC documentation). Used to check that the specified points are not
  too close to each other, and that tangent vectors are not too short.
  (In either case interpolation may fail.). Defaults to 1e-6.

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **ValueError** – Parameter for each interpolation point

- **ValueError** – Tangent for each interpolation point

- **ValueError** – B-spline interpolation failed

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
the spline

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Edge"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"

Return the normalized parameter (∈ \[0.0, 1.0\]) of the location on this
edge closest to <cite>point</cite>.

This method always returns a **normalized** parameter across the edge’s
full OCCT parameter range, even though the underlying OCP/OCCT queries
work in native (non-normalized) parameters. It is robust to several OCCT
quirks:

1\) Vertex snap (fast path) If <cite>point</cite> coincides (within
tolerance) with one of the edge’s vertices, that vertex’s OCCT parameter
is used and normalized to \[0, 1\]. Note: for a closed edge, a vertex
may represent both start and end; the mapping is therefore ambiguous and
either end may be chosen.

2\) Projection via GeomAPI_ProjectPointOnCurve The OCCT projector’s
<cite>LowerDistanceParameter()</cite> can legitimately return a value
**outside** the edge’s \[param_min, param_max\] (e.g., periodic curves
or implementation behavior). The result is wrapped back into range using
a modulo by the parameter span and then normalized to \[0, 1\]. The
projected answer is accepted only if re-evaluating the 3D point at that
normalized parameter is within tolerance of the input
<cite>point</cite>.

3\) Fallback numeric search (robust path) If the projector fails the
validation, a bounded 1D search is performed over \[0, 1\] using
progressive subdivision and local minimization of the 3D distance
‖edge(u) - point‖. The first minimum found under geometric resolution is
returned.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
**point** (*VectorLike*) – A point expected to lie on this edge (within
tolerance).

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **ValueError** – If <cite>point</cite> is not on the edge within
  tolerance.

- **ValueError** – Can’t find param on empty edge

- **RuntimeError** – If no parameter can be found (e.g., extremely
  pathological curves or numerical failure).

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
Normalized parameter in \[0.0, 1.0\] corresponding to the point’s
closest location on the edge.

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
*float*

Project Edge

Project an Edge onto a Shape generating new wires on the surfaces of the
object one and only one of <cite>direction</cite> or <cite>center</cite>
must be provided. Note that one or more wires may be generated depending
on the topology of the target object and location/direction of
projection.

To avoid flipping the normal of a face built with the projected wire the
orientation of the output wires are forced to be the same as self.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **target_object** – Object to project onto

- **direction** – Parallel projection direction. Defaults to None.

- **center** – Conical center of projection. Defaults to None.

- **target_object** – Shape:

- **direction** – VectorLike: (Default value = None)

- **center** – VectorLike: (Default value = None)

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
Projected Edge(s)

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**ValueError** – Only one of direction or center must be provided

title="topology.Compound"><span class="pre">Compound</span></a><span class="w"> </span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\|</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">None</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o"><span class="pre">=</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="default_value"><span class="pre">None</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>  
A Face in build123d represents a 3D bounded surface within the
topological data structure. It encapsulates geometric information,
defining a face of a 3D shape. These faces are integral components of
complex structures, such as solids and shells. Face enables precise
modeling and manipulation of surfaces, supporting operations like
trimming, filleting, and Boolean operations.

*<span class="pre">property</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">area_without_holes</span></span>*<span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">float</span>*  
Calculate the total surface area of the face, including the areas of any
holes.

This property returns the overall area of the face as if the inner
boundaries (holes) were filled in.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
The total surface area, including the area of holes. Returns 0.0 if the
face is empty.

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
*float*

*<span class="pre">property</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">axes_of_symmetry</span></span>*<span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">list</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\[</span></span><span class="pre">Axis</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span>*  
Computes and returns the axes of symmetry for a planar face.

The method determines potential symmetry axes by analyzing the face’s
geometry:

- It first validates that the face is non-empty and planar.

- For faces with inner wires (holes), it computes the centroid of the
  holes and the face’s overall center (COG).

  > <div>
  >
  > - If the holes’ centroid significantly deviates from the COG (beyond
  >   a specified tolerance), the symmetry axis is taken along the line
  >   connecting these points; otherwise, each hole’s center is used to
  >   generate a candidate axis.
  >
  > </div>

- For faces without holes, candidate directions are derived by sampling
  midpoints along the outer wire’s edges.

  > <div>
  >
  > - If curved edges are present, additional candidate directions are
  >   obtained from an oriented bounding box (OBB) constructed around
  >   the face.
  >
  > </div>

For each candidate direction, the face is split by a plane (defined
using the candidate direction and the face’s normal). The top half of
the face is then mirrored across this plane, and if the area of the
intersection between the mirrored half and the bottom half matches the
bottom half’s area within a small tolerance, the direction is accepted
as an axis of symmetry.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
A list of Axis objects, each defined by the face’s  
center and a direction vector, representing the symmetry axes of the
face.

</p>

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
*list*\[<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Axis"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Axis"><em>Axis</em></a>\]

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **ValueError** – If the face or its underlying representation is
  empty.

- **ValueError** – If the face is not planar.

location_at

Get the location (origin and orientation) on the surface of the face.

This method supports two overloads:

1\. <cite>location_at(u: float, v: float, \*, x_dir: VectorLike \| None
= None) -\> Location</cite> - Specifies the point in normalized UV
parameter space of the face. - <cite>u</cite> and <cite>v</cite> are
floats between 0.0 and 1.0. - Optionally override the local X direction
using <cite>x_dir</cite>.

2\. <cite>location_at(surface_point: VectorLike, \*, x_dir: VectorLike
\| None = None) -\> Location</cite> - Projects the given 3D point onto
the face surface. - The point must be reasonably close to the face. -
Optionally override the local X direction using <cite>x_dir</cite>.

If no arguments are provided, the location at the center of the face
(u=0.5, v=0.5) is returned.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **u** (*float*) – Normalized horizontal surface parameter (optional).

- **v** (*float*) – Normalized vertical surface parameter (optional).

- **surface_point** (*VectorLike*) – A 3D point near the surface
  (optional).

- **x_dir** (*VectorLike,* *optional*) – Direction for the local X axis.
  If not given, the tangent in the U direction is used.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
A full 3D placement at the specified point on the face surface.

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Location"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Location"><em>Location</em></a>

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**ValueError** – If only one of <cite>u</cite> or <cite>v</cite> is
provided or invalid keyword args are passed.

title="topology.two_d.Face"><span class="pre">Face</span></a></span></span>  
Constructs a Gordon surface from a network of profile and guide curves.

Requirements: 1. Profiles and guides may be defined as points or
curves. 2. Only the first or last profile or guide may be a point. 3. At
least one profile and one guide must be a non-point curve. 4. Each
profile must intersect with every guide. 5. Both ends of every profile
must lie on a guide. 6. Both ends of every guide must lie on a profile.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **profiles** (*Iterable\[VectorLike* *\|*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Edge"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Edge"><em>Edge</em></a>*\]*) – Profiles defined as
  points or edges.

- **guides** (*Iterable\[VectorLike* *\|*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Edge"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Edge"><em>Edge</em></a>*\]*) – Guides defined as
  points or edges.

- **tolerance** (*float,* *optional*) – Tolerance used for surface
  construction and intersection calculations.

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**ValueError** – input Edge cannot be empty.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
the interpolated Gordon surface

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Face"><em>Face</em></a>

class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.two_d.Face"><span class="pre">Face</span></a></span></span>  
Make Holes in Face

Create holes in the Face ‘self’ from interior_wires which must be
entirely interior. Note that making holes in faces is more efficient
than using boolean operations with solid object. Also note that OCCT
core may fail unless the orientation of the wire is correct - use
<cite>Wire(forward_wire.wrapped.Reversed())</cite> to reverse a wire.

Example

For example, make a series of slots on the curved walls of a cylinder.

![](_images/slotted_cylinder.png)

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **interior_wires** – a list of hole outline wires

- **interior_wires** – list\[Wire\]:

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
‘self’ with holes

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Face"><em>Face</em></a>

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **RuntimeError** – adding interior hole in non-planar face with
  provided interior_wires

- **RuntimeError** – resulting face is not valid

title="topology.two_d.Face"><span class="pre">Face</span></a></span></span>  
Approximate a spline surface through the provided 2d array of points.
The first dimension correspond to points on the vertical direction in
the parameter space of the face. The second dimension correspond to
points on the horizontal direction in the parameter space of the face.
The 2 dimensions are U,V dimensions of the parameter space of the face.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **points** (*list\[list\[VectorLike\]\]*) – a 2D list of points, first
  dimension is V parameters second is U parameters.

- **tol** (*float,* *optional*) – tolerance of the algorithm. Defaults
  to 1e-2.

- **smoothing** (*Tuple\[float,* *float,* *float\],* *optional*) –
  optional tuple of 3 weights use for variational smoothing. Defaults to
  None.

- **min_deg** (*int,* *optional*) – minimum spline degree. Enforced only
  when smoothing is None. Defaults to 1.

- **max_deg** (*int,* *optional*) – maximum spline degree. Defaults to
  3.

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**ValueError** – B-spline approximation failed

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
a potentially non-planar face defined by points

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"

title="topology.two_d.Face"><span class="pre">Face</span></a></span></span>  
Create a potentially non-planar face patch bounded by exterior edges
which can be optionally refined using support faces to ensure e.g.
tangent surface continuity. Also can optionally refine the surface using
surface points.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **edge_face_constraints**
  (*list\[tuple\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Edge"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Edge"><em>Edge</em></a>*,*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Face"><em>Face</em></a>*,* *ContinuityLevel\]\],*
  *optional*) – Edges defining perimeter of face with adjacent support
  faces subject to ContinuityLevel. Defaults to None.

- **edge_constraints**
  (*list\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Edge"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Edge"><em>Edge</em></a>*\],* *optional*) – Edges
  defining perimeter of face without adjacent support faces. Defaults to
  None.

- **point_constraints** (*list\[VectorLike\],* *optional*) – Points on
  the surface that refine the shape. Defaults to None.

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **RuntimeError** – Error building non-planar face with provided
  constraints

- **RuntimeError** – Generated face is invalid

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
Potentially non-planar face

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Face"><em>Face</em></a>

Project Face to target Object

Project a Face onto a Shape generating new Face(s) on the surfaces of
the object.

A projection with no taper is illustrated below:

![flatProjection](_images/flatProjection.png)

Note that an array of faces is returned as the projection might result
in faces on the “front” and “back” of the object (or even more if there
are intermediate surfaces in the projection path). faces “behind” the
projection are not returned.

  (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Shape"><em>Shape</em></a>) – Object to project onto

- **direction** (*VectorLike*) – projection direction

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
Face(s) projected on target object ordered by distance

title="topology.two_d.Face"><span class="pre">Face</span></a></span></span>  
wrap

Wrap a planar 2D shape onto a 3D surface.

This method conforms a 2D shape defined on the XY plane (Edge, Wire, or
Face) to the curvature of a non-planar 3D Face (the target surface),
starting at a specified surface location. The operation attempts to
preserve the original edge lengths and shape as closely as possible
while minimizing the geometric distortion that naturally arises when
mapping flat geometry onto curved surfaces.

The wrapping process follows the local orientation of the surface and
progressively fits each edge along the curvature. To help ensure
continuity, the first and last edges are extended and trimmed to close
small gaps introduced by distortion. The final shape is tightly aligned
to the surface geometry.

This method is useful for applying flat features—such as decorative
patterns, cutouts, or boundary outlines—onto curved or freeform surfaces
while retaining their original proportions.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **planar_shape** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Edge"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Edge"><em>Edge</em></a> *\|*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Wire"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Wire"><em>Wire</em></a> *\|*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Face"><em>Face</em></a>) – flat shape to wrap around
  surface

- **surface_loc**
  (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Location"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="geometry.Location"><em>Location</em></a>) – location on surface
  to wrap

- **tolerance** (*float,* *optional*) – maximum allowed error. Defaults
  to 0.001

- **extension_factor** (*float,* *optional*) – amount to extend the
  wrapped first and last edges to allow them to cross. Defaults to 0.1

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**ValueError** – Invalid planar shape

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
wrapped shape

class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.two_d.Face"><span class="pre">Face</span></a><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span></span></span>  
Wrap a sequence of 2D faces onto a 3D surface, aligned along a guiding
path.

This method places multiple planar <cite>Face</cite> objects (defined in
the XY plane) onto a curved 3D surface (<cite>self</cite>), following a
given path (Wire or Edge) that lies on or closely follows the surface.
Each face is spaced along the path according to its original horizontal
(X-axis) position, preserving the relative layout of the input faces.

The wrapping process attempts to maintain the shape and size of each
face while minimizing distortion. Each face is repositioned to the
origin, then individually wrapped onto the surface starting at a
specific point along the path. The face’s new orientation is defined
using the path’s tangent direction and the surface normal at that point.

This is particularly useful for placing a series of features—such as
embossed logos, engraved labels, or patterned tiles—onto a freeform or
cylindrical surface, aligned along a reference edge or curve.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **faces**
  (*Iterable\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Face"><em>Face</em></a>*\]*) – An iterable of 2D
  planar faces to be wrapped.

- **path** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Wire"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Wire"><em>Wire</em></a> *\|*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Edge"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Edge"><em>Edge</em></a>) – A curve on the target
  surface that defines the alignment direction. The X-position of each
  face is mapped to a relative position along this path.

- **start** (*float,* *optional*) – The relative starting point on the
  path (between 0.0 and 1.0) where the first face should be placed.
  Defaults to 0.0.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
A list of wrapped face objects, aligned and conformed to the  
surface.

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">curvature_comb</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">count</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">int</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o"><span class="pre">=</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="default_value"><span class="pre">100</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">max_tooth_size</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">float</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\|</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">None</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o"><span class="pre">=</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="default_value"><span class="pre">None</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span> <span class="sig-return"><span class="sig-return-icon">→</span> <span class="sig-return-typehint"><a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.ShapeList"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.shape_core.ShapeList"><span
class="pre">ShapeList</span></a><span class="p"><span class="pre">\[</span></span><a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Edge"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.one_d.Edge"><span class="pre">Edge</span></a><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span></span></span>  
Build a *curvature comb* for a planar (XY) 1D curve.

A curvature comb is a set of short line segments (“teeth”) erected
perpendicular to the curve that visualize the signed curvature κ(u).
Tooth length is proportional to
[<span id="direct_api_reference.xhtml_id2"
class="problematic">\|κ\|</span>](#direct_api_reference.xhtml_id1) and
the direction encodes the sign (left normal for κ\>0, right normal for
κ\<0). This is useful for inspecting fairness and continuity (C0/C1/C2)
of edges and wires.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **count** (*int,* *optional*) – Number of uniformly spaced samples
  over the normalized parameter. Increase for a denser comb. Defaults to
  100.

- **max_tooth_size** (*float* *\|* *None,* *optional*) – Maximum tooth
  height in model units. If None, set to 10% maximum curve dimension.
  Defaults to None.

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **ValueError** – Empty curve.

- **ValueError** – If the curve is not planar on <cite>Plane.XY</cite>.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
A list of short <cite>Edge</cite> objects (lines) anchored on the curve
and oriented along the left normal <cite>n̂ = normalize(t) × +Z</cite>.

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.ShapeList"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.ShapeList"><em>ShapeList</em></a>\[<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Edge"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Edge"><em>Edge</em></a>\]

Notes

- On circles, κ = 1/R so tooth length is constant.

- On straight segments, κ = 0 so no teeth are drawn.

- At inflection points κ→0 and the tooth flips direction.

- At C0 corners the tangent is discontinuous; nearby teeth may jump. C1
  yields continuous direction; C2 yields continuous magnitude as well.

Example

<div class="doctest highlight-default notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    >>> comb = my_wire.curvature_comb(count=200, max_tooth_size=2.0)
    >>> show(my_wire, Curve(comb))

</div>

</div>

  plane creation along a 1D shape. Must be perpendicalar to shapes
  tangent. Defaults to None.

2d Offset

Offsets a planar edge/wire

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **distance** (*float*) – distance from edge/wire to offset

- **kind** (<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Kind"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_enums.Kind"><em>Kind</em></a>*,* *optional*) – offset
  corner transition. Defaults to Kind.ARC.

- **side** (*Side,* *optional*) – side to place offset. Defaults to
  Side.BOTH.

- **closed** (*bool,* *optional*) – if Side!=BOTH, close the LEFT or
  RIGHT offset. Defaults to True.

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **RuntimeError** – Multiple Wires generated

- **RuntimeError** – Unexpected result type

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
offset wire

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Wire"

title="topology.Wire"><em>Wire</em></a>

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">param_at</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">position</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">float</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span> <span class="sig-return"><span class="sig-return-icon">→</span> <span class="sig-return-typehint"><span class="pre">float</span></span></span>  
Map a normalized arc-length position to the underlying OCCT parameter.

The meaning of the returned parameter depends on the type of self:

- **Edge**: Returns the native OCCT curve parameter corresponding to the
  given normalized <cite>position</cite> (0.0 → start, 1.0 → end). For
  closed/periodic edges, OCCT may return a value **outside** the edge’s
  nominal parameter range <cite>\[param_min, param_max\]</cite> (e.g.,
  by adding/subtracting multiples of the period). If you require a value
  folded into the edge’s range, apply a modulo with the parameter span.

- **Wire**: Returns a *composite* parameter encoding both the edge index
  and the position within that edge: the **integer part** is the
  zero-based count of fully traversed edges, and the **fractional part**
  is the normalized position in <cite>\[0.0, 1.0\]</cite> along the
  current edge.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
**position** (*float*) – Normalized arc-length position along the shape,
where <cite>0.0</cite> is the start and <cite>1.0</cite> is the end.
Values outside <cite>\[0.0, 1.0\]</cite> are not validated and yield
OCCT-dependent results.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
OCCT parameter (for edges) **or** composite “edgeIndex + fraction”
parameter (for wires), as described above.

Find Maximum Fillet Size

Find the largest fillet radius for the given Shape and edges with a
recursive binary search.

Example

max_fillet_radius = my_shape.max_fillet(shape_edges) max_fillet_radius =
my_shape.max_fillet(shape_edges, tolerance=0.5, max_iterations=8)

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **edge_list**
  (*Iterable\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Edge"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Edge"><em>Edge</em></a>*\]*) – a sequence of Edge
  objects, which must belong to this solid

- **tolerance** (*float,* *optional*) – maximum error from actual value.
  Defaults to 0.1.

- **max_iterations** (*int,* *optional*) – maximum number of recursive
  iterations. Defaults to 10.

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **RuntimeError** – failed to find the max value

- **ValueError** – the provided Shape is invalid

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
maximum fillet radius

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
*float*

Return shallow copy or reference of self

Create an copy of this Shape that shares the underlying TopoDS_TShape.

Used when there is a need for many objects with the same CAD structure
but at different Locations, etc. - for examples fasteners in a larger
assembly. By sharing the TopoDS_TShape, the memory size of such
assemblies can be greatly reduced.

Changes to the CAD structure of the base object will be reflected in all
instances.

Check if two shapes are the same.

This method checks if the current shape is the same as the other shape.
Two shapes are considered the same if they share the same TShape with
the same Locations. Orientations may differ.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>

class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape"><em>Shape</em></a>) – The shape to compare with.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>

*bool*

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">get_top_level_shapes</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span><span class="sig-paren">)</span> <span class="sig-return"><span class="sig-return-icon">→</span> <span class="sig-return-typehint"><a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.ShapeList"

title="topology.shape_core.ShapeList"><span
class="pre">ShapeList</span></a><span class="p"><span class="pre">\[</span></span><a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.shape_core.Shape"><span class="pre">Shape</span></a><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span></span></span>  
Retrieve the first level of child shapes from the shape.

This method collects all the non-compound shapes directly contained in
the current shape. If the wrapped shape is a
<cite>TopoDS_Compound</cite>, it traverses its immediate children and
collects all shapes that are not further nested compounds. Nested
compounds are traversed to gather their non-compound elements without
returning the nested compound itself.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
A list of all first-level non-compound child shapes.

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.ShapeList"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.ShapeList"><em>ShapeList</em></a>\[<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape"><em>Shape</em></a>\]

Example

If the current shape is a compound containing both simple shapes (e.g.,
edges, vertices) and other compounds, the method returns a list of only
the simple shapes directly contained at the top level.

*<span class="pre">property</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">global_location</span></span>*<span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">Location</span>*  
The location of this Shape relative to the global coordinate system.

This property computes the composite transformation by traversing the
hierarchy from the root of the assembly to this node, combining the
location of each ancestor. It reflects the absolute position and
orientation of the shape in world space, even when the shape is deeply
nested within an assembly.

<div class="admonition note">

Note

This is only meaningful when the Shape is part of an assembly tree where
parent-child relationships define relative placements.

</div>

*<span class="pre">property</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">matrix_of_inertia</span></span>*<span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">list</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\[</span></span><span class="pre">list</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\[</span></span><span class="pre">float</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span>*  
Compute the inertia matrix (moment of inertia tensor) of the shape.

The inertia matrix represents how the mass of the shape is distributed
with respect to its reference frame. It is a 3×3 symmetric tensor that
describes the resistance of the shape to rotational motion around
different axes.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
A 3×3 nested list representing the inertia matrix. The elements of the
matrix are given as:

<div class="line-block">

<div class="line">

Ixx Ixy Ixz \|

</div>

<div class="line">

Ixy Iyy Iyz \|

</div>

<div class="line">

Ixz Iyz Izz \|

</div>

</div>

where: - Ixx, Iyy, Izz are the moments of inertia about the X, Y, and Z
axes. - Ixy, Ixz, Iyz are the products of inertia.

</p>

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
*list*\[*list*\[*float*\]\]

Example

<div class="doctest highlight-default notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    >>> obj = MyShape()
    >>> obj.matrix_of_inertia
    [[1000.0, 50.0, 0.0],
    [50.0, 1200.0, 0.0],
    [0.0, 0.0, 300.0]]

</div>

</div>

Notes

- The inertia matrix is computed relative to the shape’s center of mass.

- It is commonly used in structural analysis, mechanical simulations,
  and physics-based motion calculations.
