Projected Faces following the given path on Shape

Project by positioning each face of to the shape along the path and
projecting onto the surface.

Note that projection may result in distortion depending on the shape at
a position along the path.

![](_images/projectText.png)

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **faces**
  (*Union\[list\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Face"><em>Face</em></a>*\],*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Compound"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Compound"><em>Compound</em></a>*\]*) – faces to
  project

- **path** – Path on the Shape to follow

- **start** – Relative location on path to start the faces. Defaults to
  0.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
The projected faces

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">radius_of_gyration</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">axis</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">Axis</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span> <span class="sig-return"><span class="sig-return-icon">→</span> <span class="sig-return-typehint"><span class="pre">float</span></span></span>  
Compute the radius of gyration of the shape about a given axis.

The radius of gyration represents the distance from the axis at which
the entire mass of the shape could be concentrated without changing its
moment of inertia. It provides insight into how mass is distributed
relative to the axis and is useful in structural analysis, rotational
dynamics, and mechanical simulations.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
**axis** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Axis"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Axis"><em>Axis</em></a>) – The axis about which the
radius of gyration is computed. The axis should be defined in the same
coordinate system as the shape.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
The radius of gyration in the same units as the shape’s dimensions.

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
*float*

Example

<div class="doctest highlight-default notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    >>> obj = MyShape()
    >>> axis = Axis((0, 0, 0), (0, 0, 1))
    >>> obj.radius_of_gyration(axis)
    5.47

</div>

</div>

Notes

- The radius of gyration is computed based on the shape’s mass
  properties.

- It is useful for evaluating structural stability and rotational
  behavior.

Display internal topology

Display the internal structure of a Compound ‘assembly’ or Shape.
Example:

<div class="highlight-default notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    >>> c1.show_topology()

    c1 is the root         Compound at 0x7f4a4cafafa0, Location(...))
    ├──                    Solid    at 0x7f4a4cafafd0, Location(...))
    ├── c2 is 1st compound Compound at 0x7f4a4cafaee0, Location(...))
    │   ├──                Solid    at 0x7f4a4cafad00, Location(...))
    │   └──                Solid    at 0x7f4a11a52790, Location(...))
    └── c3 is 2nd          Compound at 0x7f4a4cafad60, Location(...))
        ├──                Solid    at 0x7f4a11a52700, Location(...))
        └──                Solid    at 0x7f4a11a58550, Location(...))

</div>

</div>

- **limit_class** – type of displayed leaf node. Defaults to ‘Vertex’.

- **show_center** (*bool,* *optional*) – If None, shows the Location of
  Compound ‘assemblies’ and the bounding box center of Shapes. True or
  False forces the display. Defaults to None.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
tree representation of internal structure

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
*str*

split

Split this shape by the provided plane or face.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **surface** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Plane"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="geometry.Plane"><em>Plane</em></a> *\|*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Face"><em>Face</em></a>) – surface to segment shape

- **keep** (<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Keep"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_enums.Keep"><em>Keep</em></a>*,* *optional*) – which
  object(s) to save. Defaults to Keep.TOP.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
result of split

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape"><em>Shape</em></a>

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
Self \| list\[Self\] \| None, Tuple\[Self \| list\[Self\] \| None\]: The
result of the split operation.

- **Keep.TOP**: Returns the top as a <cite>Self</cite> or
  <cite>list\[Self\]</cite>, or <cite>None</cite> if no top is found.

- **Keep.BOTTOM**: Returns the bottom as a <cite>Self</cite> or
  <cite>list\[Self\]</cite>, or <cite>None</cite> if no bottom is found.

- **Keep.BOTH**: Returns a tuple <cite>(inside, outside)</cite> where
  each element is either a <cite>Self</cite> or
  <cite>list\[Self\]</cite>, or <cite>None</cite> if no corresponding
  part is found.

</p>

split_by_perimeter

Divide the faces of this object into those within the perimeter and
those outside the perimeter.

Note: this method may fail if the perimeter intersects shape edges.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **perimeter**
  (*Union\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Edge"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Edge"><em>Edge</em></a>*,*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Wire"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Wire"><em>Wire</em></a>*\]*) – closed perimeter

- **keep** (<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Keep"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_enums.Keep"><em>Keep</em></a>*,* *optional*) – which
  object(s) to return. Defaults to Keep.INSIDE.

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **ValueError** – perimeter must be closed

- **ValueError** – keep must be one of Keep.INSIDE\|OUTSIDE\|BOTH

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
Union\[Face \| Shell \| ShapeList\[Face\] \| None, Tuple\[Face \| Shell
\| ShapeList\[Face\] \| None\]: The result of the split operation.

- **Keep.INSIDE**: Returns the inside part as a <cite>Shell</cite> or
  <cite>Face</cite>, or <cite>None</cite> if no inside part is found.

- **Keep.OUTSIDE**: Returns the outside part as a <cite>Shell</cite> or
  <cite>Face</cite>, or <cite>None</cite> if no outside part is found.

- **Keep.BOTH**: Returns a tuple <cite>(inside, outside)</cite> where
  each element is either a <cite>Shell</cite>, <cite>Face</cite>, or
  <cite>None</cite> if no corresponding part is found.

</p>

*<span class="pre">property</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">static_moments</span></span>*<span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">tuple</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\[</span></span><span class="pre">float</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">,</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">float</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">,</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">float</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span>*  
Compute the static moments (first moments of mass) of the shape.

The static moments represent the weighted sum of the coordinates with
respect to the mass distribution, providing insight into the center of
mass and mass distribution of the shape.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
The static moments (Mx, My, Mz), where: - Mx is the first moment of mass
about the YZ plane. - My is the first moment of mass about the XZ
plane. - Mz is the first moment of mass about the XY plane.

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
*tuple*\[*float*, *float*, *float*\]

Example

<div class="doctest highlight-default notranslate">

<div class="highlight">

    >>> obj = MyShape()
    >>> obj.static_moments
    (150.0, 200.0, 50.0)

</div>

</div>

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">tessellate</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">tolerance</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">float</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">angular_tolerance</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">float</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o"><span class="pre">=</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="default_value"><span class="pre">0.1</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span> <span class="sig-return"><span class="sig-return-icon">→</span> <span class="sig-return-typehint"><span class="pre">tuple</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\[</span></span><span class="pre">list</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\[</span></span><span class="pre">Vector</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">,</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">list</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\[</span></span><span class="pre">tuple</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\[</span></span><span class="pre">int</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">,</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">int</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">,</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">int</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span></span></span>  
General triangulated approximation

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">to_splines</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">degree</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">int</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o"><span class="pre">=</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="default_value"><span class="pre">3</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">tolerance</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">float</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o"><span class="pre">=</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="default_value"><span class="pre">0.001</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">nurbs</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">bool</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="o"><span class="pre">=</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="default_value"><span class="pre">False</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span> <span class="sig-return"><span class="sig-return-icon">→</span> <span class="sig-return-typehint"><span class="pre">Self</span></span></span>  
A shape-processing utility that forces all geometry in a shape to be
converted into BSplines. It’s useful when working with tools or export
formats that require uniform geometry, or for downstream processing that
only understands BSpline representations.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **degree** (*int,* *optional*) – Maximum degree. Defaults to 3.

- **tolerance** (*float,* *optional*) – Approximation tolerance.
  Defaults to 1e-3.

- **nurbs** (*bool,* *optional*) – Use rational splines. Defaults to
  False.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
Approximated shape

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
Self

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">transform_geometry</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">t_matrix</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">Matrix</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span> <span class="sig-return"><span class="sig-return-icon">→</span> <span class="sig-return-typehint"><span class="pre">Self</span></span></span>  
Apply affine transform

WARNING: transform_geometry will sometimes convert lines and circles to
splines, but it also has the ability to handle skew and stretching
transformations.

If your transformation is only translation and rotation, it is safer to
use <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape.transform_shape"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape.transform_shape"><span class="pre"><code
class="sourceCode python xref py py-meth docutils literal notranslate">transform_shape()</code></span></a>,
which doesn’t change the underlying type of the geometry, but cannot
handle skew transformations.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
**t_matrix** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Matrix"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Matrix"><em>Matrix</em></a>) – affine transformation
matrix

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
a copy of the object, but with geometry transformed

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape"><em>Shape</em></a>

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">transform_shape</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">t_matrix</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">Matrix</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span> <span class="sig-return"><span class="sig-return-icon">→</span> <span class="sig-return-typehint"><span class="pre">Self</span></span></span>  
Apply affine transform without changing type

Transforms a copy of this Shape by the provided 3D affine transformation
matrix. Note that not all transformation are supported - primarily
designed for translation and rotation. See :transform_geometry: for more
comprehensive transformations.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
**t_matrix** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Matrix"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="geometry.Matrix"><em>Matrix</em></a>) – affine transformation
matrix

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
copy of transformed shape with all objects keeping their type

filter by Axis, Plane, or GeomType

Either: - filter objects of type planar Face or linear Edge by their
normal or tangent (respectively) and sort the results by the given axis,
or - filter the objects by the provided type. Note that not all types
apply to all objects.

A Shell is a fundamental component in build123d’s topological data
structure representing a connected set of faces forming a closed surface
in 3D space. As part of a geometric model, it defines a watertight
enclosure, commonly encountered in solid modeling. Shells group faces in
a coherent manner, playing a crucial role in representing complex shapes
with voids and surfaces. This hierarchical structure allows for
efficient handling of surfaces within a model, supporting various
operations and analyses.

within the list nor between wires. Wires may be closed or opened.

A Solid in build123d represents a three-dimensional solid geometry in a
topological structure. A solid is a closed and bounded volume, enclosing
a region in 3D space. It comprises faces, edges, and vertices connected
in a well-defined manner. Solid modeling operations, such as Boolean
operations (union, intersection, and difference), are often performed on
Solid objects to create or modify complex geometries.

title="topology.three_d.Solid"><span class="pre">Solid</span></a></span></span>  
Extrude a cross section with a taper

Extrude a cross section into a prismatic solid in the provided
direction.

Note that two difference algorithms are used. If direction aligns with
the profile normal (which must be positive), the taper is positive and
the profile contains no holes the OCP LocOpe_DPrism algorithm is used as
it generates the most accurate results. Otherwise, a loft is created
between the profile and the profile with a 2D offset set at the
appropriate direction.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **section** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Face"><em>Face</em></a>*\]*) – cross section

- **normal** (*VectorLike*) – a vector along which to extrude the wires.
  The length of the vector controls the length of the extrusion.

- **taper** (*float*) – taper angle in degrees.

- **flip_inner** (*bool,* *optional*) – outer and inner geometry have
  opposite tapers to allow for part extraction when injection molding.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
extruded cross section

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Solid"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Solid"><em>Solid</em></a>

*<span class="pre">classmethod</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">extrude_until</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">profile:</span> <span class="pre">Face</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">target:</span> <span class="pre">Compound</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">Solid</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">direction:</span> <span class="pre">VectorLike</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">until:</span> <span class="pre">Until</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">\<Until.NEXT\></span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span> <span class="sig-return"><span class="sig-return-icon">→</span> <span class="sig-return-typehint"><a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Solid"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Solid"><span class="pre">Solid</span></a></span></span>  
Extrude <cite>profile</cite> in the provided <cite>direction</cite>
until it encounters a bounding surface on the <cite>target</cite>. The
termination surface is chosen according to the <cite>until</cite>
option:

> <div>
>
> - <span class="pre">`Until.NEXT`</span> — Extrude forward until the
>   first intersecting surface.
>
> - <span class="pre">`Until.LAST`</span> — Extrude forward through all
>   intersections, stopping at
>
> the farthest surface. \* <span class="pre">`Until.PREVIOUS`</span> —
> Reverse the extrusion direction and stop at the first intersecting
> surface behind the profile. \* <span class="pre">`Until.FIRST`</span>
> — Reverse the direction and stop at the farthest surface behind the
> profile.
>
> </div>

When <span class="pre">`Until.PREVIOUS`</span> or
<span class="pre">`Until.FIRST`</span> are used, the extrusion direction
is automatically inverted before execution.

<div class="admonition note">

Note

The bounding surface on the target must be large enough to completely
cover the extruded profile at the contact region. Partial overlaps may
yield open or invalid solids.

</div>

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **profile** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Face"><em>Face</em></a>) – The face to extrude.

- **target**
  (*Union\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Compound"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Compound"><em>Compound</em></a>*,*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Solid"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Solid"><em>Solid</em></a>*\]*) – The object that
  limits the extrusion.

- **direction** (*VectorLike*) – Extrusion direction.

- **until** (<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Until"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_enums.Until"><em>Until</em></a>*,* *optional*) – Surface
  selection mode controlling which intersection to stop at. Defaults to
  <span class="pre">`Until.NEXT`</span>.

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**ValueError** – If the provided profile does not intersect the target.

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
The extruded and limited solid.

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Solid"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Solid"><em>Solid</em></a>

Sweep

Sweep the given cross section into a prismatic solid along the provided
path

The is_frenet parameter controls how the profile orientation changes as
it follows along the sweep path. If is_frenet is False, the orientation
of the profile is kept consistent from point to point. The resulting
shape has the minimum possible twisting. Unintuitively, when a profile
is swept along a helix, this results in the orientation of the profile
slowly creeping (rotating) as it follows the helix. Setting is_frenet to
True prevents this.

If is_frenet is True the orientation of the profile is based on the
local curvature and tangency vectors of the path. This keeps the
orientation of the profile consistent when sweeping along a helix
(because the curvature vector of a straight helix always points to its
axis). However, when path is not a helix, the resulting shape can have
strange looking twists sometimes. For more information, see Frenet
Serret formulas
<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frenet%E2%80%93Serret_formulas"
class="reference external">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frenet%E2%80%93Serret_formulas</a>.

- **section**
  (*Union\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Face"><em>Face</em></a>*,*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Wire"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Wire"><em>Wire</em></a>*\]*) – cross section to sweep

- **path** (*Union\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Wire"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Wire"><em>Wire</em></a>*,*
  <a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Edge"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Edge"><em>Edge</em></a>*\]*) – sweep path

- **inner_wires**
  (*list\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Wire"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Wire"><em>Wire</em></a>*\]*) – holes - only used if
  section is a wire

- **make_solid** (*bool,* *optional*) – return Solid or Shell. Defaults
  to True.

- **is_frenet** (*bool,* *optional*) – Frenet mode. Defaults to False.

- **mode**
  (*Union\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Vector"

  additional sweep mode parameters. Defaults to None.

Multi section sweep

Sweep through a sequence of profiles following a path.

The is_frenet parameter controls how the profile orientation changes as
it follows along the sweep path. If is_frenet is False, the orientation
of the profile is kept consistent from point to point. The resulting
shape has the minimum possible twisting. Unintuitively, when a profile
is swept along a helix, this results in the orientation of the profile
slowly creeping (rotating) as it follows the helix. Setting is_frenet to
True prevents this.

If is_frenet is True the orientation of the profile is based on the
local curvature and tangency vectors of the path. This keeps the
orientation of the profile consistent when sweeping along a helix
(because the curvature vector of a straight helix always points to its
axis). However, when path is not a helix, the resulting shape can have
strange looking twists sometimes. For more information, see Frenet
Serret formulas
<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frenet%E2%80%93Serret_formulas"
class="reference external">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frenet%E2%80%93Serret_formulas</a>.

title="topology.three_d.Solid"><span class="pre">Solid</span></a></span></span>  
Thicken Face or Shell

Create a solid from a potentially non planar face or shell by thickening
along the normals.

![](_images/thickenFace.png)

Non-planar faces are thickened both towards and away from the center of
the sphere.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **depth** (*float*) – Amount to thicken face(s), can be positive or
  negative.

- **normal_override**
  (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_geometry.Vector"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="geometry.Vector"><em>Vector</em></a>*,* *optional*) – Face
  only. The normal_override vector can be used to indicate which way is
  ‘up’, potentially flipping the face normal direction such that many
  faces with different normals all go in the same direction (direction
  need only be +/- 90 degrees from the face normal). Defaults to None.

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**RuntimeError** – Opencascade internal failures

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
The resulting Solid object

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>

A Wire in build123d is a topological entity representing a connected
sequence of edges forming a continuous curve or path in 3D space. Wires
are essential components in modeling complex objects, defining
boundaries for surfaces or solids. They store information about the
connectivity and order of edges, allowing precise definition of paths
within a 3D model.

Return the normalized wire parameter for the point closest to this wire.

This method projects the given point onto the wire, finds the nearest
edge, and accumulates arc lengths to determine the fractional position
along the entire wire. The result is normalized to the interval \[0.0,
1.0\], where:

- 0.0 corresponds to the start of the wire

- 1.0 corresponds to the end of the wire

Unlike the edge version of this method, the returned value is **not** an
OCCT curve parameter, but a normalized parameter across the wire as a
whole.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
**point** (*VectorLike*) – The point to project onto the wire.

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**ValueError** – Can’t find point on empty wire

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
Normalized parameter in \[0.0, 1.0\] representing the relative position
of the projected point along the wire.

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
*float*

Project Wire

Project a Wire onto a Shape generating new wires on the surfaces of the
object one and only one of <cite>direction</cite> or <cite>center</cite>
must be provided. Note that one or more wires may be generated depending
on the topology of the target object and location/direction of
projection.

To avoid flipping the normal of a face built with the projected wire the
orientation of the output wires are forced to be the same as self.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **target_object** – Object to project onto

- **direction** – Parallel projection direction. Defaults to None.

- **center** – Conical center of projection. Defaults to None.

- **target_object** – Shape:

- **direction** – VectorLike: (Default value = None)

- **center** – VectorLike: (Default value = None)

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
Projected wire(s)

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**ValueError** – Only one of direction or center must be provided

*<span class="pre">class</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">Vertex</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">X</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">float</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">Y</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">float</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">Z</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">float</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>\
*<span class="pre">class</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">Vertex</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">v</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">Iterable</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\[</span></span><span class="pre">float</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>  
A Vertex in build123d represents a zero-dimensional point in the
topological data structure. It marks the endpoints of edges within a 3D
model, defining precise locations in space. Vertices play a crucial role
in defining the geometry of objects and the connectivity between edges,
facilitating accurate representation and manipulation of 3D shapes. They
hold coordinate information and are essential for constructing complex
structures like wires, faces, and solids.

Add

Add to a Vertex with a Vertex, Vector or Tuple

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
**other** – Value to add

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**TypeError** – other not in \[Tuple,Vector,Vertex\]

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
Result

Example

part.faces(“\>z”).vertices(“\<y and \<x”).val() + (0, 0, 15)

which creates a new Vertex 15 above one extracted from a part. One can
add or subtract a <cite>Vertex</cite> , <cite>Vector</cite> or
<cite>tuple</cite> of float values to a Vertex.

<div id="direct_api_reference.xhtml_import-export" class="section">

## Import/Export

Methods and functions specific to exporting and importing build123d
objects are defined below.

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">import_brep</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">file_name</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">PathLike</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\|</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">str</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\|</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">bytes</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span> <span class="sig-return"><span class="sig-return-icon">→</span> <span class="sig-return-typehint"><span class="pre">Shape</span></span></span>

**file_name** (*Union\[PathLike,* *str,* *bytes\]*) – brep file

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
build123d object

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>

class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Shape"><em>Shape</em></a>

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
contents of STEP file

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Compound"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Compound"><em>Compound</em></a>

<!-- -->

<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">import_stl</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">file_name:</span> <span class="pre">~os.PathLike</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">str</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">bytes</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">model_unit:</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.build_enums.Unit</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">\<Unit.MM\></span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span> <span class="sig-return"><span class="sig-return-icon">→</span> <span class="sig-return-typehint"><span class="pre">Face</span></span></span>  
Extract shape from an STL file and return it as a Face reference object.

Note that importing with this method and creating a reference is very
fast while creating an editable model (with Mesher) may take minutes
depending on the size of the STL file.

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **file_name** (*Union\[PathLike,* *str,* *bytes\]*) – file path of STL
  file to import

- **model_unit** (*Unit,* *optional*) – the default unit used when
  creating the model. For example, Blender defaults to Unit.M. Defaults
  to Unit.MM.

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **ValueError** – Could not import file

- **ValueError** – Invalid model_unit

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
STL model

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>  
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Face"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Face"><em>Face</em></a>

class="n"><span class="pre">flip_y:</span> <span class="pre">bool</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">True</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">align:</span> <span class="pre">~build123d.build_enums.Align\]</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">None</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">\<Align.MIN\></span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">ignore_visibility:</span> <span class="pre">bool</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">False</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">label_by:</span> <span class="pre">~typing.Literal\['id'</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">'class'</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">'inkscape:label'\]</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">str</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">'id'</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">is_inkscape_label:</span> <span class="pre">bool</span> <span class="pre">\|</span> <span class="pre">None</span> <span class="pre">=</span> <span class="pre">None</span></span>*<span class="pre">\[</span></span><span class="pre">Wire</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\|</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">Face</span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\]</span></span></span></span>  
Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **svg_file** (*Union\[str,* *Path,* *TextIO\]*) – svg file

- **flip_y** (*bool,* *optional*) – flip objects to compensate for svg
  orientation. Defaults to True.

- **align** (<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Align"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_enums.Align"><em>Align</em></a> *\|*
  *tuple\[*<a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Align"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_enums.Align"><em>Align</em></a>*,*
  <a href="#builder_api_reference.xhtml_build_enums.Align"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="build_enums.Align"><em>Align</em></a>*\]* *\|* *None,*
  *optional*) – alignment of the SVG’s viewbox, if None, the viewbox’s
  origin will be at <cite>(0,0,0)</cite>. Defaults to Align.MIN.

- **ignore_visibility** (*bool,* *optional*) – Defaults to False.

- **label_by** (*str,* *optional*) – XML attribute to use for imported
  shapes’ <cite>label</cite> property. Defaults to “id”. Use
  <cite>inkscape:label</cite> to read labels set from Inkscape’s “Layers
  and Objects” panel.

Raises<span class="colon">:</span>  
**ValueError** – unexpected shape type

Returns<span class="colon">:</span>  
objects contained in svg

Return type<span class="colon">:</span>

title="topology.ShapeList"><em>ShapeList</em></a>\[*Union*\[<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Wire"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Wire"><em>Wire</em></a>,

class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Face"><em>Face</em></a>\]\]

<div id="direct_api_reference.xhtml_joint-object" class="section">

## Joint Object

Base Joint class which is used to position Solid and Compound objects
relative to each other are defined below. The
<a href="#joints.xhtml_joints" class="reference internal"><span
class="std std-ref">Joints</span></a> section contains the class
description of the derived Joint classes.

*<span class="pre">class</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">Joint</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="n"><span class="pre">label</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><span class="pre">str</span></span>*, *<span class="n"><span class="pre">parent</span></span><span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="n"><a href="#build_part.xhtml_build_part.BuildPart"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="build_part.BuildPart"><span class="pre">BuildPart</span></a><span class="w"> </span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\|</span></span><span class="w"> </span><a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Solid"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Solid"><span class="pre">Solid</span></a><span class="w"> </span><span class="p"><span class="pre">\|</span></span><span class="w"> </span><a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Compound"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Compound"><span class="pre">Compound</span></a></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>  
Abstract Base Joint class - used to join two components together

Parameters<span class="colon">:</span>  
**parent**
(*Union\[*<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Solid"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Solid"><em>Solid</em></a>*,*
<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Compound"
class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
title="topology.Compound"><em>Compound</em></a>*\]*) – object that joint
to bound to

Variables<span class="colon">:</span>  
- **label** (*str*) – user assigned label

- **parent** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Shape"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Shape"><em>Shape</em></a>) – object joint is bound to

- **connected_to** (<a href="#direct_api_reference.xhtml_topology.Joint"
  class="hxr-hoverxref hxr-tooltip reference internal"
  title="topology.Joint"><em>Joint</em></a>) – joint that is connect to
  this joint

*<span class="pre">abstract</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">connect_to</span></span><span class="sig-paren">(</span>*<span class="o"><span class="pre">\*</span></span><span class="n"><span class="pre">args</span></span>*, *<span class="o"><span class="pre">\*\*</span></span><span class="n"><span class="pre">kwargs</span></span>*<span class="sig-paren">)</span>  
All derived classes must provide a connect_to method

*<span class="pre">abstract</span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">property</span><span class="w"> </span>*<span class="sig-name descname"><span class="pre">location</span></span>*<span class="p"><span class="pre">:</span></span><span class="w"> </span><span class="pre">Location</span>*
